### H-E-B Plus!

In 2004, the company launched three (in [Austin](Austin, Texas), [Christi](Corpus)(Corpus Christi, Texas), and [Waco](Waco, Texas)) H-E-B Plus! stores with an expanded focus on nonfood categories, such as entertainment and other general merchandise. The company added three additional locations in 2005 (Corpus Christi, [Rock](Round)(Round Rock, Texas), and [Antonio](San)(San Antonio)). The stores offered several new departments, including Do-It-Yourself and Texas Backyard, and greatly expanded product categories in baby, card and party, cosmetics, entertainment, housewares, and toys.

Several other locations were later added, including stores in [Bluff](Flour)(Flour Bluff), Corpus Christi, [Brownsville](Brownsville, Texas), [Burleson](Burleson, Texas), [Bastrop](Bastrop, Texas), [Beaumont](Beaumont, Texas), [Belton](Belton, Texas), [Boerne](Boerne, Texas), [Katy](Katy, Texas), [Killeen](Killeen, Texas), [Cypress](Cypress, Texas), [Victoria](Victoria, Texas), [Waxahachie](Waxahachie, Texas), [Braunfels](New)(New Braunfels, Texas), [Kyle](Kyle, Texas), [Laredo](Laredo, Texas), [Leander](Leander, Texas),[Plus to open Friday in Leander](https://archive.today/20120913234518/http://www.statesman.com/business/content/business/stories/employment/02/22/22leander.htmlH-E-B) *Austin American-Statesman*, February 22, 2007. [Mission](Mission, Texas), [Grande City](Rio)(Rio Grande City, Texas), [Juan](San)(San Juan, Texas), [Antonio](San)(San Antonio), [Midland](Midland, Texas), [Pearland](Pearland, Texas), [Cove](Copperas)(Copperas Cove, Texas) and [Hutto](Hutto, Texas).

## Charitable activity

The company gives 5% of annual pretax earnings to causes in the areas in which it operates, including education and food banks. The Excellence in Education Awards are an annual charitable program maintained by H-E-B since 2000, in which teachers, administrators and schools in Texas are recognized, with awards totaling $500,000 in contributions in 2009.

H-E-B coordinated donations to relief efforts in the wake of a [plant fire and explosion](fertilizer)(West Fertilizer Company explosion) in [Texas](West,)(West, Texas). The company donated $50,000 to the [Red Cross](American)(American Red Cross) and launched a checkstand campaign benefiting the organization to get the community involved in the relief effort. The company said in a news release 100% of the donations from the campaign will support the American Red Cross's disaster relief efforts. H-E-B also activated its emergency response units, sending the H-E-B Eddie Garcia Mobile Kitchen and water tanker to West, including donations of meals and water to the victims and first responders.

In the aftermath of [Harvey](Hurricane)(Hurricane Harvey) in 2017, H-E-B donated $100,000 toward relief efforts. Its campaign drive for customer contributions totaled $1,000,000. In addition, H-E-B's Mobile Kitchen and Disaster Relief Units distributed 10,000 hot meals to volunteers and victims in the affected areas in Texas.

After the [Elementary School shooting](Robb)(Robb Elementary School shooting) in [Texas](Uvalde,)(Uvalde, Texas), on May 24, 2022, in which 19 children and two teachers were killed, H-E-B and the Butt family donated $10 million toward building a new school as founding donors. Initial participants joining the family include Texas architectural firm, Huckabee, and Texas general contractor, Joeris General Contractors.
H-E-B donates 5% of its annual pretax earnings to charity.

## Cast and characters

* [Mitchell](Maia)(Maia Mitchell) as Callie Adams Foster (seasons 14, special guest season 5), a recent graduate of [UCSD](UCSD) Law School and Mariana's adopted sister. She leaves to join the [ACLU](American Civil Liberties Union) in Washington, D.C. in the second episode of season 4, though she has spoken to Mariana occasionally through web chat.

* [Ramirez](Cierra)(Cierra Ramirez) as Mariana Adams Foster, a software engineer and Callie's adopted sister who recently graduated from [MIT](Massachusetts Institute of Technology)

* Zuri Adele as Malika Williams, a bartender and political activist who lives with Callie and Mariana in the Coterie

* [Cola](Sherry)(Sherry Cola) as Alice Kwan, the building manager of The Coterie apartment building

* Tommy Martinez as Gael Martinez, a bisexual graphic designer and artist who falls for Callie

* [Bart](Roger)(Roger Bart) as Judge Curtis Wilson (seasons 1–2, guest season 3), a conservative judge for whom Callie worked as a clerk

* Emma Hunton as Davia Moss (season 2–present; recurring season 1), a body-positive influencer and teacher

* [Pence](Josh)(Josh Pence) as Dennis Cooper (season 2–present; recurring season 1), the oldest tenant in the Coterie who is an aspiring musician

* [Mirchoff](Beau)(Beau Mirchoff) as Jamie Hunter (seasons 3–4; recurring seasons 1–2; guest season 5), a lawyer and Callie's on-again-off-again boyfriend

* [Craig](Bryan)(Bryan Craig) as Joaquin Peréz (season 4–present), a mysterious new resident to the Coterie and investigative journalist who is looking for his estranged sister Jenna

* [Quintana](Priscilla)(Priscilla Quintana) as Isabella Tavez (season 4; recurring seasons 2–3; guest season 5), an aspiring actress and model

* [Stewart](Booboo)(Booboo Stewart) as Luca Ryusaki (season 5; recurring season 4), a homeless man whom Joaquin interviews for a story and is befriended by The Coterie inhabitants

### GRS Team

* [Krasinski](John)(John Krasinski) as Jack Silva, newest member of the team and former [Navy SEAL](US)(United States Navy SEALs)

* [Badge Dale](James)(James Badge Dale) as [S. "Rone" Woods](Tyrone)(American fatalities and injuries of the 2012 Benghazi attack#Tyrone S. Woods), commander of the GRS team and former [Navy SEAL](US)(United States Navy SEALs)

* [Martini](Max)(Max Martini) as Mark "Oz" Geist, team member and former [Marine](US)(United States Marine Corps)

* [Fumusa](Dominic)(Dominic Fumusa) as John "Tig" Tiegen, team member and former [Marine](US)(United States Marine Corps)

* [Schreiber](Pablo)(Pablo Schreiber) as ["Tanto" Paronto](Kris)(Kris Paronto), team member and former [Army Ranger](US)(75th Ranger Regiment)

* [Denman](David)(David Denman) as Dave "Boon" Benton, team member and former [Marine](US)(United States Marine Corps) [Sniper](Scout)(United States Marine Corps Scout Sniper)

* [Stephens](Toby)(Toby Stephens) as ["Bub" Doherty](Glen)(American fatalities and injuries of the 2012 Benghazi attack#Glen Doherty), GRS operator in Tripoli, former [Navy SEAL](US)(United States Navy SEALs), and good friend of Woods and Silva

The main security team members in *13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi* belonged to the U.S. Navy SEALs, the U.S. Marine Corps, and the Army Rangers. Specifically:

- The GRS (Guardsman Response Team) team members were former Navy SEALs, Marines, and Army Rangers.
- Key members include:
  - S. "Rone" Woods (Navy SEAL)
  - Mark "Oz" Geist (Marine)
  - John "Tig" Tiegen (Marine)
  - "Tanto" Paronto (Army Ranger)
  - Dave "Boon" Benton (Marine Scout Sniper)
  - "Bub" Doherty (Navy SEAL)

Thus, the primary military units represented in the main security team were the United States Navy SEALs, United States Marine Corps, and the 75th Ranger Regiment.

### 2016–present: Debut with Blackpink and solo ventures

[[블랙핑크 리사 2.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Lisa performing in May 2017](File:(17.05.17))]

In August 2016, Lisa debuted as one of four members of South Korean girl group [Blackpink](Blackpink), the first non-ethnically Korean artist under the label. Blackpink's debut single album *Square One* with lead singles "[Whistle](Whistle (Blackpink song))", which topped all South Korean charts upon debut, and "[Boombayah](Boombayah)". As of September 2022, the group has released three studio albums (*[in Your Area](Blackpink)(Blackpink in Your Area)*, *[Album](The)(The Album (Blackpink album))* and *[Pink](Born)(Born Pink)*), three extended plays (*[Blackpink](Blackpink (EP))*, *[Up](Square)(Square Up (EP))* and *[This Love](Kill)(Kill This Love)*) and two single albums (*Square One* and *Square Two*).

Lisa became a permanent cast member on the [Army Academy](Korea)(Korea Army Academy at Yeongcheon) edition of the [MBC](Munhwa Broadcasting Corporation) military variety program *[Man 300](Real)(Real Man 300)* from September 21, 2018, onward. Her first role on a television program since her debut, it earned her the unofficial Character of the Year award at the [MBC Entertainment Awards](2018)(2018 MBC Entertainment Awards).

On November 5, 2018, Lisa unveiled her [YouTube](YouTube) channel, Lilifilm Official, focusing on travelling, lifestyle, and dance. As of July 2019, she has over 1.3 million subscribers and received a YouTube [Play Button](Gold)(YouTube Play Buttons). One of her dance performance videos went viral in 2020 as a result of a meme derived from the video; celebrities such as [Parton](Dolly)(Dolly Parton), [Colbert](Stephen)(Stephen Colbert), [Corden](James)(James Corden), [Evans](Luke)(Luke Evans), and [Nas X](Lil)(Lil Nas X) participated in the trend.

In March 2020, Lisa served as the dance mentor on [iQIYI](iQIYI)'s Chinese girl group survival program *[With You Season 2](Youth)(Youth With You (season 2))*. In February 2021, she returned as dance mentor in the show's [season](third)(Youth With You (season 3)) for boy groups*.*

On April 19, 2021, [Entertainment](YG)(YG Entertainment) revealed to *[Korea Herald](The)(The Korea Herald)* that Lisa would be the third member of Blackpink to debut as a soloist, with the official schedule to be announced later. On July 12, through *Star News*, the label revealed that filming for her music video was underway. Lisa's debut single album *[Lalisa](Lalisa (single album))* and [lead single](its)(Lalisa (song)) of the same name were released on September 10, 2021. The music video for "Lalisa" became the most-viewed video by a soloist in 24 hours with 73.6 million views, breaking the record held by [Swift](Taylor)(Taylor Swift)'s "[Me!](Me!)" featuring [Urie](Brendon)(Brendon Urie), which received 65.2 million views in 24 hours, for which she earned two [World Records](Guinness)(Guinness World Records). The song debuted at number 84 on the US [Hot 100](*Billboard*)(Billboard Hot 100) and at number two on the [Global 200](*Billboard*)(Billboard Global 200), becoming Lisa's first top 10 song on the latter. The album sold 736,221 copies in South Korea in its first week, setting the record for the highest first-week sales among female artists domestically and making Lisa the first female soloist to surpass the 500,000-copy mark in one week. "[Money](Money (Lisa song))" was sent to US contemporary hit radio as the album's second single, peaking at number 90 on the Hot 100 and number ten on the Global 200, earning Lisa her second career entries on both charts and second top-10 entry on the latter.

In October 2021, Lisa collaborated with [Snake](DJ)(DJ Snake), [Ozuna](Ozuna), and [Thee Stallion](Megan)(Megan Thee Stallion) on the single "[SG](SG (song))". It was released on October 22 alongside a music video and featured songwriting and composition credits by Lisa. "SG" debuted at number 19 on the Global 200 and number two on the [Under Hot 100](Bubbling)(Bubbling Under Hot 100) chart and became her first number-one song on the [Airplay](Latin)(Latin Airplay) chart.

On August 28, 2022, Lisa won the [Video Music Award for Best K-Pop Video](MTV)(MTV Video Music Award for Best K-Pop Video) for "Lalisa" and became the first K-pop solo artist to win an MTV Video Music Award. On November 13, she won the [Europe Music Award for Best K-Pop](MTV)(MTV Europe Music Award for Best K-Pop) and became the first solo K-pop artist in history to win an MTV Europe Music Award as well. Lisa was awarded two Guinness World Records in 2023 for the achievements, in addition to a third for becoming the most followed K-pop artist on Instagram.

In April 2023, it was announced through *Osen* that Lisa would feature on [BigBang](BigBang (South Korean band)) member [Taeyang](Taeyang)'s second extended play *[to Earth](Down)(Down to Earth (EP))*. The collaboration, titled "[Shoong!](Shoong!)", was released on April 25 alongside a video in which Taeyang and Lisa performed the song's choreography together.

Lisa's music video for "Lalisa" holds the record for the most views in 24 hours on YouTube by a solo artist, with 73.6 million views, breaking the previous record held by Taylor Swift's "Me!" featuring Brendon Urie.

# Parthenon

*Revision ID: 1159057312 | Timestamp: 2023-06-07T23:40:11Z*

---

| start_date = 447 BC[Parthenon](http://academic.reed.edu/humanities/110Tech/Parthenon.html) . Academic.reed.edu. Retrieved on 4 September 2013.[The Parthenon](http://www.ancientgreece.com/s/Parthenon/) . Ancientgreece.com. Retrieved on 4 September 2013.

| destruction_date = Partially on 26 September 1687

The **Parthenon** (; , , ; , , ) is a former [temple](Ancient Greek temple)Sacks, David. "Parthenon." *Encyclopedia of the Ancient Greek World*, David Sacks, Facts On File, 3rd edition, 2015. Accessed 15 July 2022. on the [Acropolis](Athenian)(Acropolis of Athens), Greece, that was dedicated to the [goddess](Greek gods) [Athena](Athena) during the fifth century BC. Its decorative sculptures are considered some of the high points of classical [art](Greek)(Art in Ancient Greece), an enduring symbol of [Greece](Ancient)(Ancient Greece), [democracy](democracy) and [civilization](Western)(western culture).

The Parthenon was built in thanksgiving for the Hellenic victory over [Empire](Persian)(Achaemenid Empire) invaders during the [Wars](Greco-Persian)(Greco-Persian Wars). Like most Greek temples, the Parthenon also served as the city [treasury](treasury).

Construction started in 447 BC when the [League](Delian)(Delian League) was at the peak of its power. It was completed in 438; work on the decoration continued until 432. For a time, it served as the treasury of the Delian League, which later became the [Empire](Athenian)(Athenian Empire). In the final decade of the 6th century AD, the Parthenon was converted into a Christian church dedicated to the [Mary](Virgin)(Mary, the mother of Jesus). After the [conquest](Ottoman)(Ottoman Greece) in the mid-fifteenth century, it became a [mosque](Parthenon mosque). In the [War](Morean)(Morean War), a Venetian bomb landed on the Parthenon, which the Ottomans had used as a munitions dump, during the 1687 [of the Acropolis](siege)(Siege of the Acropolis (1687)). The resulting explosion severely damaged the Parthenon. From 1800 to 1803, [7th Earl of Elgin](the)(Thomas Bruce, 7th Earl of Elgin) took down some of the surviving sculptures, now known as the [Marbles](Elgin)(Elgin Marbles), in an act widely considered, both in its time and subsequently, to constitute vandalism and looting.

The Parthenon replaced an older temple of Athena, which historians call the Pre-Parthenon or [Parthenon](Older)(Older Parthenon), that was demolished in the [invasion](Persian)(Greco-Persian wars) of 480 BC.

Since 1975, numerous large-scale restoration projects have been undertaken to preserve remaining artefacts and ensure its structural integrity.
The two architects responsible for the design of the Parthenon were Iktinos and Callicrates.

# Pom Klementieff

*Revision ID: 1160114424 | Timestamp: 2023-06-14T14:01:50Z*

---

| birth_place        = [City](Quebec)(Quebec City), Quebec, Canada

| nationality        = French

| education          = [Florent](Cours)(Cours Florent)

| occupation         = Actress

| years_active       = 2007–present

| signature          = Pom Klementieff signature.svg

}}

**Pom Alexandra Klementieff** (; born 3 May 1986Additional  on 1 January 2018.) is a French actress. She was trained at the [Florent](Cours)(Cours Florent) drama school in Paris and appeared in such French films as *[Easy Way](The)(The Easy Way (film))* (2008) and *[Night](Sleepless)(Sleepless Night (2011 film))* (2011), before making her American film debut in *[Oldboy](Oldboy (2013 film))* (2013). In 2019, she also made an appearance in *[Vipers](Striking)(Striking Vipers)*, the first episode of the fifth series of the anthology series *[Mirror](Black)(Black Mirror)*.

Klementieff received worldwide recognition for her role as [Mantis](Mantis (Marvel Cinematic Universe)) in the [Cinematic Universe](Marvel)(Marvel Cinematic Universe) films *[of the Galaxy Vol. 2](Guardians)(Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2)* (2017), *[Infinity War](Avengers:)(Avengers: Infinity War)* (2018), *[Endgame](Avengers:)(Avengers: Endgame)* (2019), *[Love and Thunder](Thor:)(Thor: Love and Thunder)* (2022), the television film *[Guardians of the Galaxy Holiday Special](The)(The Guardians of the Galaxy Holiday Special)* (2022), and *[of the Galaxy Vol. 3](Guardians)(Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3)* (2023).
Pom Klementieff made her American film debut in *Oldboy* (2013).

## Music

The single 'Leeds United' was released in April 1972 to coincide with the team reaching the 1972 FA Cup Final, composed by [Reed](Les)(Les Reed (songwriter)) and [Mason](Barry)(Barry Mason) with the team providing the vocals. The record stayed in the [Singles Chart](UK)(UK Singles Chart) for almost three months, peaking at number 10. The B-side [Leeds! Leeds!']('Leeds!)(Marching On Together) (commonly known as *Marching on Together*) has since become the club's anthem and is regularly sung by supporters.
The song known as the anthem regularly sung by Leeds United supporters is "Marching On Together."

### Kherson Oblast

[[File:Meeting of the Council for Civil Society and Human Rights 2019-12-10 (7).jpg|thumb|[Kiriyenko](Sergey)(Sergey Kiriyenko) (left) became Putin's point man in the Russian-occupied territories of Ukraine.]]

: *Read more: [occupation of Kherson Oblast](Russian)(Russian occupation of Kherson Oblast)*

On February 24, 2022, Russian troops from Crimea invaded [Henichesk](Henichesk Raion) and [Skadovsk](Skadovsk Raion) Raions. During the first days of the offensive, the Russians surrounded most of the cities and towns in the oblast, blocking the entrances to them with roadblocks, but not entering the cities themselves. Significant battles were fought for the [Bridge](Antonivskyi)(Antonivka Road Bridge), which crosses the [River](Dnipro)(Dnieper) between Russian positions on the South bank and the Ukrainian city of [Kherson](Kherson) on the North bank. The Russian military's overwhelming firepower forced the Ukrainian forces to retreat, and the city [to Russian control](fell)(Battle of Kherson) on March 2. On June 29, the [occupation authorities in Kherson Oblast](Russian)(Russian occupation of Kherson Oblast) announced preparations for holding a [of annexation](referendum)(2022 Russian-occupied Ukraine annexation referendums). On July 9, the Ukrainian government announced preparations for an [counteroffensive in the South](imminent)(2022 Kherson counteroffensive), and urged the residents of occupied parts of [Kherson](Kherson Oblast) and [Zaporizhzhia](Zaporizhzhia Oblast) Oblasts to shelter or evacuate to minimize civilian casualties in the operation. Following the destruction of the Antonivskyi Bridge and the advance of Ukrainian troops from the west, the lack of sustainable supply lines amid heavy Ukrainian shelling compelled the Russian forces to retreat. They eventually retreated from all areas on the North bank of the [River](Dnipro)(Dnieper), including the city of Kherson, which the Ukrainian forces recaptured soon after, known as the [of Kherson](liberation)(liberation of Kherson).

[[File:Kherson after Russian shelling, 2023-01-15 (02).jpg|thumb|Liberated [Kherson](Kherson) after shelling by the Russian army on 15 January 2023]]

[Raions](Raions of Ukraine) of [Oblast](Kherson)(Kherson Oblast) that are occupied:

* [Raion](Henichesk)(Henichesk Raion)

* [Raion](Kakhovka)(Kakhovka Raion)

* [Raion](Skadovsk)(Skadovsk Raion)

* Half of [Raion](Kherson)(Kherson Raion)
The Ukrainian city recaptured by Ukrainian forces on 11 November 2022 during the Kherson counteroffensive was Kherson.

# Miles Teller

*Revision ID: 1159837845 | Timestamp: 2023-06-12T21:15:25Z*

---

| birth_place        = [Pennsylvania](Pennsylvania), U.S.

**Miles Teller** (born February 20, 1987) is an American actor. He made his feature film debut with the independent drama *[Hole](Rabbit)(Rabbit Hole (2010 film))* (2010), and gained recognition for his starring role in the coming-of-age film *[Spectacular Now](The)(The Spectacular Now)* (2013) and the [film trilogy](*Divergent*)(The Divergent Series) (2014–2016), both opposite [Woodley](Shailene)(Shailene Woodley). His starring role in the drama *[Whiplash](Whiplash (2014 film))* (2014) served as his breakthrough and earned him praise. He went on to star in the superhero film *[Four](Fantastic)(Fantastic Four (2015 film))* (2015) and the biographical film *[Dogs](War)(War Dogs (2016 film))* (2016).

Teller gained wider success for starring in the action film *[Gun: Maverick](Top)(Top Gun: Maverick)* (2022). On television, he has starred in the [Prime Video](Amazon)(Amazon Prime Video) crime drama *[Old to Die Young](Too)(Too Old to Die Young)* (2019) and the [Paramount+](Paramount+) miniseries *[Offer](The)(The Offer)* (2022).
Miles Teller attended New York University for his Bachelor of Fine Arts degree.

**Korea** (,  or , ) is a [peninsula](peninsula)r [region](region) in [Asia](East)(East Asia). Since 1945, it has been divided at or near the [parallel](38th)(38th parallel north), with [Korea](North)(North Korea) (Democratic People's Republic of Korea) comprising its northern half and [Korea](South)(South Korea) (Republic of Korea) comprising its southern half. Korea consists of the **Korean Peninsula**, [Island](Jeju)(Jeju Island), and several minor islands near the peninsula. The peninsula is bordered by [China](China) ([Manchuria](Manchuria)) to the north and [Russia](Russia) to the northeast, across the [Amrok](Yalu River) and [Duman](Tumen River) rivers. It is separated from [Japan](Japan) to the southeast by the [Strait](Korea)(Korea Strait).

During the first half of the 1st millennium, Korea was divided between three states, [Goguryeo](Goguryeo), [Baekje](Baekje), and [Silla](Silla), together known as the [Kingdoms of Korea](Three)(Three Kingdoms of Korea). In the second half of the 1st millennium, Silla defeated and conquered Baekje and Goguryeo, leading to the "[Silla](Unified)(Unified Silla)" period. Meanwhile, [Balhae](Balhae) formed in the north, superseding former Goguryeo. Unified Silla eventually collapsed into three separate states due to [war](civil)(civil war), ushering in the [Three Kingdoms](Later)(Later Three Kingdoms). Toward the end of the 1st millennium, [Goguryeo](Goguryeo) was resurrected as [Goryeo](Goryeo), which defeated the two other states and unified the Korean Peninsula as a single sovereign state. Around the same time, Balhae collapsed and its last crown prince fled south to Goryeo. Goryeo (also spelled as *Koryŏ*), whose name developed into the modern [exonym](exonym) "Korea", was a highly cultured state that created the world's first metal [type](movable)(movable type) in 1234. Chronology  Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History  The Metropolitan Museum of Art|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/ht/07/eak.html|website=The Met's Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History|publisher=The Metropolitan Museum of Art|access-date=19 August 2016}} However, multiple incursions by the [Empire](Mongol)(Mongol Empire) during the 13th century greatly weakened the nation, which eventually agreed to become a [state](vassal)(Korea under Yuan rule) after decades of fighting. Following military resistance under [Gongmin](King)(King Gongmin) that ended Mongol political influence in Goryeo, severe political strife followed, and Goryeo eventually fell to a coup led by General [Seong-gye](Yi)(Yi Seong-gye), who established [Joseon](Joseon) on 17 July 1392. The first 200 years of the Joseon era were marked by relative peace, and during this time the [alphabet](Korean)(Hangul) was created by [the Great](Sejong)(Sejong the Great) and [Confucianism](Confucianism) became increasingly influential in the kingdom.

Joseon's two centuries of peace were broken by foreign invasions and internal factional strife from 1592 to 1637. Most notable of these invasions is the [invasions of Korea](Japanese)(Japanese invasions of Korea (1592–1598)), which marked the end of the Joseon dynasty's early period. Several decades later, Joseon was invaded by the [Jurchens](Later Jin (1616–1636)) and the [Manchus](Qing dynasty) in [1627](Later Jin invasion of Joseon) and [1636](Qing invasion of Joseon) respectively, leading to an increasingly harsh isolationist policy, for which the country became known as the "[kingdom](hermit)(hermit kingdom)" in [literature](Western)(Western literature). After the end of these invasions from [Manchuria](Manchuria), Joseon experienced a nearly 200-year period of peace and prosperity, along with cultural and technological development. What power the kingdom recovered during its isolation waned as the 18th century came to a close. Faced with internal strife, power struggles, international pressure, and rebellions at home, the kingdom declined rapidly in the late 19th century.

During the later years of the dynasty, Korea's isolationist policy earned it the Western nickname of the "[kingdom](hermit)(hermit kingdom)". By the mid 19th century, with the country [to modernize, and under encroachment of European powers](unwilling)(hermit kingdom), Joseon Korea was forced to sign [treaties](unequal)(Unequal treaty) with foreign powers. After the assassination of [Myeongseong](Empress)(Empress Myeongseong) in 1895, the [Peasant Revolution](Donghak)(Donghak Peasant Revolution), and the [Reforms of 1894 to 1896](Gabo)(Gabo Reform), the [Empire](Korean)(Korean Empire) (1897–1910) came into existence, heralding a brief but rapid period of social reform and modernization. However, in 1905, the Korean Empire signed a [treaty](protectorate)(Japan–Korea Treaty of 1905) and in 1910, [annexed the Korean Empire](Japan)(Japan–Korea Treaty of 1910).

Japan relinquished control over Korea after [surrendering](formally)(Surrender of Japan) to the [Allies](Allies of World War II) on 2 September 1945, in the aftermath of [War II](World)(World War II). The [Union](Soviet)(Soviet Union) and the [States](United)(United States) had agreed to partition Korea along the 38th parallel, with the [occupying the north](Soviets)(Soviet Civil Administration) and the [occupying the south](Americans)(United States Army Military Government in Korea). These circumstances became the basis for the [of Korea](division)(division of Korea) by the two [superpower](superpower)s with two different [ideologies](ideology), exacerbated by their inability to agree on the terms of Korean independence. The communist government in the north received backing from the Soviet Union in opposition to the pro-Western government in the south, leading to Korea's division into two [state](sovereign)(sovereign state)s in 1948: North Korea and South Korea. Tensions between the two resulted in North Korea invading South Korea and the outbreak of the [War](Korean)(Korean War) in 1950. With involvement by foreign troops, the war ended in a stalemate in 1953, but without a formalised [treaty](peace)(peace treaty). This status contributes to the high tensions that continue to divide the peninsula, and both states continue to claim to be the sole legitimate government of Korea. A breakthrough in the peace process came on 27 April 2018, when North Korea and South Korea signed the [Declaration](Panmunjom)(Panmunjom Declaration), pledging to work toward ending the [conflict](Korean)(Korean conflict) and reaffirming the goal of reunifying the two countries.

**Roseanne Park** (born 11 February 1997), known mononymously as **Rosé** (), is a Korean-New Zealand singer and dancer based in South Korea. Born in New Zealand and raised in Australia, Rosé signed with South Korean label [Entertainment](YG)(YG Entertainment) following a successful audition in 2012 and trained for four years before debuting as a member of the girl group [Blackpink](Blackpink) in August 2016.

In March 2021, Rosé made her solo debut with her [album](single)(single album) *[R](R (single album))*. The album sold 448,089 copies in its first week, the highest for a Korean female soloist. Its lead single "[the Ground](On)(On the Ground)" was a commercial success, peaking in the top five domestically and becoming the highest-charting song by a Korean female soloist on the US [Hot 100](*Billboard*)(Billboard Hot 100), the [Singles Chart](ARIA)(ARIA charts) and the [Singles Chart](UK)(UK Singles Chart). It was the first song by a Korean solo artist to top the [Global 200](*Billboard*)(Billboard Global 200) and earned Rosé two [World Records](Guinness)(Guinness World Records). The album's second single "[Gone](Gone (Rosé song))" peaked in the top ten in South Korea as well.

### 2016–present: Debut with Blackpink and *R*

Rosé trained at YG Entertainment for four years before she was revealed as the final member of the girl group [Blackpink](Blackpink) on 22 June 2016. The group debuted on 8 August 2016 with the [album](single)(single album) *[One](Square)(Square One (Blackpink album))*, which featured the singles "[Whistle](Whistle (Blackpink song))" and "[Boombayah](Boombayah)".

Rosé appeared on a variety of broadcast programs, such as *[of Masked Singer](King)(King of Masked Singer)*. Her vocal performance on the show was met with warm reception by the audience, to which Rosé commented that she "didn't know if the audience would like [her] singing" and that she felt "happy and relieved" at the positive result. She later appeared as a performer on the second season of *[Duo](Fantastic)(Fantastic Duo)*. The show's production staff stated that her appearance was intended to "reveal Rosé's vocal appeal, which is different from Blackpink".

On 1 June 2020, it was announced that Rosé would debut as a solo artist following the release of Blackpink's first Korean language full-length album. On 30 December 2020, in an interview with South Korean media outlet *Osen*, her label revealed that filming for her debut music video would begin in mid-January 2021. On 26 January 2021, a promotional teaser of Rosé's solo debut was released, revealing that a preview of her solo debut would be revealed through *Blackpink Livestream Concert: The Show* on 31 January 2021.

[[File:Rosé Met Gala 2021.png|thumb|Rosé and [Vaccarello](Anthony)(Anthony Vaccarello) attending the [Gala](Met)(Met Gala) in 2021]]

Rosé's debut single album, titled *[R](R (single album))*, was released on 12 March 2021. With 41.6 million views in 24 hours of the music video for the lead single "[the Ground](On)(On the Ground)", she broke the almost eight-year record held by former labelmate [Psy](Psy)'s "[Gentleman](Gentleman (Psy song))" for the most viewed music video by a Korean soloist in 24 hours. "On the Ground" peaked at number 70 on the [Hot 100](*Billboard*)(Billboard Hot 100), becoming the highest-charting song by a Korean female soloist in the US. The song also debuted and peaked at number one on both the [200](Global)(Billboard Global 200) and [Excl. U.S.](Global)(Billboard Global 200#Billboard Global Excl. US) charts, the first song by a Korean solo artist to do so. *R* also set the record for the highest first-week sales by a Korean female soloist, with 448,089 copies sold. On 24 March, Rosé received her first-ever music show win as a soloist with her single "On the Ground" on South Korean cable music program *[Champion](Show)(Show Champion)* and would go on to win five more. On 5 April, the music video for Rosé's song "[Gone](Gone (Rosé song))" was released.

"Hard to Love", a pop-disco solo sung by Rosé, is featured as the fifth track of Blackpink's second studio album *[Pink](Born)(Born Pink)*, which was released on 16 September 2022.
## Life and career

### 1997–2012: Early life

Roseanne Park (; *Park Chae-young*) was born on 11 February 1997 in [Auckland](Auckland), New Zealand, to South Korean immigrant parents. She has an older sister. In 2004, at the age of seven, Rosé and her family moved to [Melbourne](Melbourne), Australia. She began singing and learned to play guitar and piano as a child and performed in church choirs. She attended Kew East Primary School, and [Girls' Secondary College](Canterbury)(Canterbury Girls' Secondary College) but dropped out before Year 11, after signing with South Korean record label [Entertainment](YG)(YG Entertainment).
Lisa debuted under YG Entertainment as a member of Blackpink.

## Cards

American Express executives discussed the possibility of launching a travel [card](charge)(charge card) as early as 1946, but it was not until [Club](Diners)(Diners Club) launched a card in March 1950, that American Express began to seriously consider the possibility. At the end of 1957, American Express CEO [Reed](Ralph)(Ralph Reed (American Express)) decided to get into the card business, and by the launch date of October 1, 1958, public interest had become so significant that 250,000 cards were issued prior to the official launch date. The card was launched with an annual fee of $6, $1 higher than Diners Club, to be seen as a premium product. The first cards were made of paper, with the account number and card member's name typed. In 1959, American Express began issuing embossed plastic cards, an industry first., the company had 133.3 million cards in force, including 56.4million cards in force in the United States, each with average annual spending of $23,496. These include consumer, small business and corporate cards issued by American Express themselves and cards issued by its Global Service Network partners that run on its network (such as Commonwealth Bank, Westpac, and NAB in Australia and Lloyds Bank and Barclays Bank in the UK). On March 1, 2017, Australia's fourth-largest bank ANZ announced that it was no longer issuing American Express cards, with the support phased out entirely by August 5, 2017. American Express is the fourth largest general-purpose card network on a global basis based on purchase volume, behind China UnionPay, Visa and MasterCard. It is the 4th largest card network in the world, based on the number of cards it has in circulation. American Express is one of the partner banks to both [Google](Google) and [Apple](Apple Inc.)'s mobile wallet systems ([Pay](Google)(Google Wallet) and [Pay](Apple)(Apple Pay), respectively) meaning that cardholders can use their American Express-issued cards to pay at establishments where [NFC](Near field communication) payments are accepted. American Express offers various [credit cards](contactless)(Contactless smart card).

### Consumer cards

[[File:HK West Kln Waterfront Promenade Hong Kong Wine & Dine Festival Nov-2012 booths American Express sponsor view ICC.JPG|thumb|260px|An advertisement for the Platinum Credit Card in [Kong](Hong)(Hong Kong), 2012]]American Express is best known for its Green, Gold, and Platinum charge cards. The Gold Card was converted to a credit card for U.K. residents in 2018, but remains a charge card in the U.S. In 1958, American Express issued its first [card](charge)(charge card), which required payment at the end of every month. In 1966, the company issued its first gold card, in an effort to cater to the upper echelon of business travel. Its platinum card debuted in 1984. In 1999, American Express introduced the [Card](Centurion)(Centurion Card), often referred to as the "black card," which caters to an even more affluent customer segment. The card was initially available only to select users of the Platinum card. The annual fee for the card in the United States is $5,000 (up from $1,000 at introduction) with an additional one-time initiation fee of $10,000. American Express created the card line amid rumors and [legend](urban)(urban legend)s in the 1980s that it produced an ultra-exclusive black card for elite users who could purchase anything with it. American Express cards publicly issued in the United States range in cost between no annual fee (for Blue and many other consumer and business cards) and a $695 annual fee (for the Platinum card). Annual fees for the Green card start at $150, while Gold card annual fees start at $250.

As of January 2023, the company produces the following core suite of cards for consumers, some of which have corresponding business variants, along with their respective fees:

American Express has several co-branded credit cards, with most falling into one of three categories:

* Airlines: [Argentinas](Aerolíneas)(Aerolíneas Argentinas), [Aeroméxico](Aeroméxico), [Canada](Air)(Air Canada), [France](Air)(Air France), [Alitalia](Alitalia), [Airways](British)(British Airways), [Pacific](Cathay)(Cathay Pacific), [Air Lines](Delta)(Delta Air Lines), [Icelandair](Icelandair), [KLM](KLM), [Qantas](Qantas), [Airlines](Scandinavian)(Scandinavian Airlines), [Airlines](Singapore)(Singapore Airlines), [Airlines](SriLankan)(SriLankan Airlines), [Airways](Thai)(Thai Airways), [Australia](Virgin)(Virgin Australia), among others.

* Hotels: [Western](Best)(Best Western), [Hotels](Hilton)(Hilton Hotels), [International](Marriott)(Marriott International), and [Peninsula Hotels](The)(The Peninsula Hotels)

* Retailers: [Jones](David)(David Jones Limited), [Renfrew](Holt)(Holt Renfrew), [Harrods](Harrods), [Macy's](Macy's), [Bloomingdales](Bloomingdales), [Lowe's](Lowe's), [Mercedes-Benz](Mercedes-Benz), [Dillard's](Dillard's) and others.

A credit card aimed at young adults is called *Blue*, which has no annual fee and a [program](loyalty)(loyalty program). A television media campaign for Blue adopted the 1979 UK [Synthpop](Synthpop) hit "[Cars](Cars (song))" by [Numan](Gary)(Gary Numan) as its [music](theme)(theme music). A [reward program](cashback)(cashback reward program) version, "Blue Cash", quickly followed. American Express also targeted young adults with City Reward Cards that earn INSIDE Rewards points to eat, drink, and play in New York, Chicago, and LA hot spots. American Express began phasing out the INSIDE cards in mid-2008, with no new applications being taken as of July 2008.

In 2002, American Express introduced Clear, advertised as the first credit card with no fees of any kind. Other cards introduced in 2005, included "The Knot" and "The Nest" Credit Cards from American Express, co-branded cards developed with the wedding planning website theknot.com. In 2006, the UK division of American Express joined the [Red](Product)(Product Red) coalition and issued a Red Card, donating with each purchase through [Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria](The)(The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria) to help African women and children with HIV/AIDS, malaria, and other diseases. In 2009, American Express introduced the ZYNC charge card. White in color, this card was created for people aged 20–40. The Zync charge card has since been discontinued with the exception of current cardholders who are [grandfathered](grandfathered) into the ZYNC. In late 2012, American Express and [Walmart](Walmart) announced the launch of Bluebird, a [debit card](prepaid)(prepaid debit card) similar to that of [Dot](Green)(Green Dot Corporation). Bluebird is being touted as having some of the benefits of traditional American Express cards, such as [assistance](roadside)(roadside assistance) and [theft](identity)(identity theft) protection. The card can also be used as a substitute for a traditional [account](checking)(Transactional account). Unlike other such cards, Bluebird is [FDIC](Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation)-insured. Bluebird accounts have standard FDIC deposit insurance and check writing capabilities, and as of March 2013 customers can have Social Security payments, military pay, Tax Return, paycheck, and other government benefits deposited directly into their accounts.
The American Express card introduced in 1999 that is often referred to as the "black card" is the Centurion Card.

***The Town*** is a 2010 American [crime](Crime film) [drama](Drama (film and television)) film co-written, directed by, and starring [Affleck](Ben)(Ben Affleck), adapted from [Hogan](Chuck)(Chuck Hogan)'s 2004 novel *Prince of Thieves*. It also stars [Hall](Rebecca)(Rebecca Hall), [Hamm](Jon)(Jon Hamm), [Renner](Jeremy)(Jeremy Renner), [Lively](Blake)(Blake Lively), [Welliver](Titus)(Titus Welliver), [Postlethwaite](Pete)(Pete Postlethwaite), [Cooper](Chris)(Chris Cooper) and [Slaine](Slaine (rapper)), and follows a [Boston](Boston) [robber](bank)(Bank robbery) who begins to develop romantic feelings for a victim of one of his previous robberies, while he and his crew set out to get one final score by robbing [Park](Fenway)(Fenway Park).

The film premiered on September 8, 2010, at the [Film Festival](Venice)(Venice Film Festival) before being released in the United States on September 17, 2010. Based on actual events, it received praise from critics for its direction, screenplay, editing, and the performances of the cast (particularly Renner) and grossed $154 million worldwide. The film was chosen by the [Board of Review](National)(National Board of Review) as one of the [ten films of 2010](top)(National Board of Review Awards 2010#Top 10 Films), while Renner was nominated for the [Award for Best Supporting Actor](Academy)(Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor) and Postlethwaite was posthumously nominated for the [Award for Best Supporting Actor](BAFTA)(BAFTA Award for Best Supporting Actor).

## Cast

* [Affleck](Ben)(Ben Affleck) as Douglas "Doug" MacRay

* [Hall](Rebecca)(Rebecca Hall) as Claire Keesey

* [Hamm](Jon)(Jon Hamm) as [FBI](Federal Bureau of Investigation) Special Agent Adam Frawley

* [Renner](Jeremy)(Jeremy Renner) as James "Jem" Coughlin

* [Lively](Blake)(Blake Lively) as Krista "Kris" Coughlin

* [Cooper](Chris)(Chris Cooper) as Stephen "Big Mac" MacRay

* [Postlethwaite](Pete)(Pete Postlethwaite) as Fergus "Fergie" Colm

* [Slaine](Slaine (rapper)) as Albert "Gloansy" MacGloan

* Owen Burke as Desmond "Dez" Elden

* [Welliver](Titus)(Titus Welliver) as Detective Dino Ciampa

* Dennis McLaughlin as Russell "Rusty"

* Brian Scannell as Henry

* Isaac Bordoy as Alex Colazzo

* Jack Neary as Arnold Washton

* Edward O'Keefe as Morton Previt

* [Garber](Victor)(Victor Garber) as David

## The play called *The King in Yellow*

The fictional play *The King in Yellow* has at least two acts and at least three characters: Cassilda, Camilla and "the Stranger", who may or may not be the titular character.

Chambers' story collection excerpts some sections from the play to introduce the book as a whole, or individual stories. For example, "Cassilda's Song" comes from Act 1, Scene 2 of the play:"The King in Yellow" in e.g.

The short story "The Mask" is introduced by an excerpt from Act 1, Scene 2d:"The Mask" in e.g.

It is also stated, in "The Repairer of Reputations", that the final moment of the first act involves the character Camilla's "agonized scream and [...] awful words echoing through the dim streets of Carcosa".

All of the excerpts come from Act I. The stories describe Act I as quite ordinary, but reading Act II drives the reader mad with the "irresistible" revealed truths: "The very banality and innocence of the first act only allowed the blow to fall afterward with more awful effect". Even seeing the first page of the second act is enough to draw the reader in: "If I had not caught a glimpse of the opening words in the second act I should never have finished it" ("[Repairer of Reputations](The)(The Repairer of Reputations)").

Chambers usually gives only scattered hints of the contents of the full play, as in this extract from "The Repairer of Reputations":

He mentioned the establishment of the Dynasty in Carcosa, the lakes which connected Hastur, Aldebaran and the mystery of the Hyades. He spoke of Cassilda and Camilla, and sounded the cloudy depths of Demhe, and the Lake of Hali. "The scolloped tatters of the King in Yellow must hide Yhtill forever", he muttered, but I do not believe Vance heard him. Then by degrees he led Vance along the ramifications of the Imperial family, to Uoht and Thale, from Naotalba and Phantom of Truth, to Aldones, and then tossing aside his manuscript and notes, he began the wonderful story of the Last King.

A similar passage occurs in "The Yellow Sign", in which two protagonists have read *The King in Yellow*:

Night fell and the hours dragged on, but still we murmured to each other of the King and the Pallid Mask, and midnight sounded from the misty spires in the fog-wrapped city. We spoke of Hastur and of Cassilda, while outside the fog rolled against the blank window-panes as the cloud waves roll and break on the shores of Hali.

The fictional play within *The King in Yellow* that induces despair or madness is titled **"The King in Yellow"**. Reading the second act of the play is said to drive readers mad with "irresistible" revelations, and even glimpsing the opening words of the second act is enough to cause profound psychological effects.

### 2021–present: *Desire, I Want to Turn Into You*

[[Polachek - First Avenue 12-7-2021 45.jpg|thumb|right|Polachek performing in 2021](File:Caroline)]

In September 2021, Polachek was announced as one of the opening acts on [Lipa](Dua)(Dua Lipa)'s [Nostalgia Tour](Future)(Future Nostalgia Tour). The tour began on February 9, 2022. On November 4, 2021, Charli XCX released "[Shapes](New)(New Shapes)" featuring Christine and the Queens and Polachek as the second single from her studio album *[Crash](Crash (Charli XCX album))* (2022).

On July 14, 2021, Polachek released the single "[Is a Rider](Bunny)(Bunny Is a Rider)", another collaboration with Harle; she told *[Crack](Crack (magazine))* magazine that the song was part of a future project. In December, *[Pitchfork](Pitchfork (website))* ranked "Bunny Is a Rider" at the top of their list of "The 100 Best Songs of 2021". On February 9, 2022, Polachek released the single "[Billions](Billions (Caroline Polachek song))". In March, she was featured on Australian electronic music producer [Flume](Flume (musician))'s single "Sirens", released ahead of his upcoming studio album [*Palaces*](Palaces (album)). In June, Polachek confirmed that she was working on her fourth studio album, posting a picture of herself in studio with Danny L Harle on [Instagram](Instagram). She recorded a cover version of "[Bang (My Baby Shot Me Down)](Bang)(Bang Bang (My Baby Shot Me Down))" for the [The Rise of Gru* soundtrack album](*Minions:)(Minions: The Rise of Gru (soundtrack)), released on July 1, 2022. On October 17, her flamenco-inspired single "Sunset", a co-production with [Bodega](Sega)(Sega Bodega), was released.

On December 5, 2022, Polachek released the single "[to My Island](Welcome)(Welcome to My Island)" and announced her second studio album under her full name, *[I Want to Turn Into You](Desire,)(Desire, I Want to Turn Into You)*, for release on February 14, 2023. The album received critical acclaim and includes "Bunny Is a Rider", "Billions", "Sunset", and "Welcome to My Island".
The 2023 album Caroline Polachek released that received critical acclaim and includes the single "Bunny Is a Rider" is *Desire, I Want to Turn Into You*.

**David Foster Wallace** (February 21, 1962 – September 12, 2008) was an American novelist, short story writer, essayist, and university professor of English and [writing](creative)(creative writing). Wallace is widely known for his 1996 novel *[Jest](Infinite)(Infinite Jest)*, which *[Time](Time (magazine))* magazine cited as one of the 100 best English-language novels from 1923 to 2005. His posthumous novel, *[Pale King](The)(The Pale King)* (2011), was a finalist for the [Prize for Fiction](Pulitzer)(Pulitzer Prize for Fiction) in 2012.  The *[Angeles Times](Los)(Los Angeles Times)*s David Ulin called Wallace "one of the most influential and innovative writers of the last twenty years".

Wallace grew up in Illinois and attended [College](Amherst)(Amherst College). He taught English at [College](Emerson)(Emerson College), [State University](Illinois)(Illinois State University), and [College](Pomona)(Pomona College). After struggling with [depression](Depression (mood)) for many years, he died by [suicide](suicide) in 2008, at age 46.
The novel by David Foster Wallace cited by *Time* magazine as one of the 100 best English-language novels from 1923 to 2005 is *Infinite Jest*.

# Pom Klementieff

*Revision ID: 1160114424 | Timestamp: 2023-06-14T14:01:50Z*

---

| birth_place        = [City](Quebec)(Quebec City), Quebec, Canada

| nationality        = French

| education          = [Florent](Cours)(Cours Florent)

| occupation         = Actress

| years_active       = 2007–present

| signature          = Pom Klementieff signature.svg

}}

**Pom Alexandra Klementieff** (; born 3 May 1986Additional  on 1 January 2018.) is a French actress. She was trained at the [Florent](Cours)(Cours Florent) drama school in Paris and appeared in such French films as *[Easy Way](The)(The Easy Way (film))* (2008) and *[Night](Sleepless)(Sleepless Night (2011 film))* (2011), before making her American film debut in *[Oldboy](Oldboy (2013 film))* (2013). In 2019, she also made an appearance in *[Vipers](Striking)(Striking Vipers)*, the first episode of the fifth series of the anthology series *[Mirror](Black)(Black Mirror)*.

Klementieff received worldwide recognition for her role as [Mantis](Mantis (Marvel Cinematic Universe)) in the [Cinematic Universe](Marvel)(Marvel Cinematic Universe) films *[of the Galaxy Vol. 2](Guardians)(Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2)* (2017), *[Infinity War](Avengers:)(Avengers: Infinity War)* (2018), *[Endgame](Avengers:)(Avengers: Endgame)* (2019), *[Love and Thunder](Thor:)(Thor: Love and Thunder)* (2022), the television film *[Guardians of the Galaxy Holiday Special](The)(The Guardians of the Galaxy Holiday Special)* (2022), and *[of the Galaxy Vol. 3](Guardians)(Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3)* (2023).
## Career

### 2007–2012: Early career

[[Klementieff Comic Con Brussels 2018 (39983390974).jpg|thumb|right|150px|Klementieff at the 2018 Brussels Comic Con](File:Pom)]

Klementieff's first professional acting job was the French independent film *Après lui* (2007), portraying the stepdaughter of the protagonist played by [Deneuve](Catherine)(Catherine Deneuve). Filming for her scenes took three days. In one scene, Klementieff was supposed to push someone down a set of stairs but accidentally fell down the stairs herself, and director [Morel](Gaël)(Gaël Morel) kept that shot in the final film.

Her first leading role was in *Loup* (2009), a French film about a tribe of reindeer herders in the [Siberia](Siberia)n mountains. During filming, Klementieff stayed in a camp, hours from the nearest village, where temperatures dropped well below zero. She befriended nomads who lived there, worked with real wolves, rode reindeer, and swam with a horse in a lake.

### 2013–present: Breakthrough

Klementieff made her Hollywood debut in [Lee](Spike)(Spike Lee)'s *[Oldboy](Oldboy (2013 film))* (2013), a remake of the South Korean [of the same name](film)(Oldboy (2003 film)). She portrayed Haeng-bok, the bodyguard of the antagonist played by [Copley](Sharlto)(Sharlto Copley). A fan of the original film, Klementieff heard about the part through [Lee](Roy)(Roy Lee), a producer with the remake, and took boxing lessons after learning the role involved martial arts. After showcasing her boxing skills during her audition, Lee asked her to go home and come back wearing a more feminine outfit and make-up, like her character in the film. She contributed some of her own clothes to the character's wardrobe, and trained three hours a day for two months for an on-screen fight with star [Brolin](Josh)(Josh Brolin). Klementieff came up with the name Haeng-bok, Korean for "happiness", herself after Lee asked her to research possible names for the character.

Klementieff moved to Los Angeles after *Oldboy* was filmed and began pursuing more Hollywood auditions. She continued [taekwondo](taekwondo) after the film, and has a purple belt as of the summer of 2014. Her next acting role was the film ''Hacker's Game* (2015), in which she plays a hacker she compared to [Salander](Lisbeth)(Lisbeth Salander) from the novel *[Girl with the Dragon Tattoo](The)(The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo)''. Klementieff used her boxing skills again in the film, and due to the movie's low budget, she had to do her own make-up and choose her own wardrobe. It was her idea to dye her hair purple for the role, to which the directors first objected but later acquiesced. In 2017, she appeared in the romance drama *[Newness](Newness)* and the black comedy-drama *[Goes West](Ingrid)(Ingrid Goes West)*.

Klementieff received worldwide recognition when she joined the [Cinematic Universe](Marvel)(Marvel Cinematic Universe) as [Mantis](Mantis (Marvel Comics)), appearing in the films *[of the Galaxy Vol. 2](Guardians)(Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2)* (2017), *[Infinity War](Avengers:)(Avengers: Infinity War)* (2018), and *[Endgame](Avengers:)(Avengers: Endgame)* (2019). In 2019, she appeared in an episode of the [Netflix](Netflix) science fiction anthology series *[Mirror](Black)(Black Mirror)*, the thriller film *[Gems](Uncut)(Uncut Gems)*, and had voice roles in the animated supernatural comedy film *[Addams Family](The)(The Addams Family (2019 film))*. In 2020, she had a recurring role as Martel in the [HBO](HBO) science fiction series *[Westworld](Westworld (TV series))*. She reprised her role as Mantis in the 2023 sequel *[of the Galaxy Vol. 3](Guardians)(Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3)*, as well as appearing in the upcoming *[Impossible – Dead Reckoning Part One](Mission:)(Mission: Impossible – Dead Reckoning Part One)* and *[Impossible – Dead Reckoning Part Two](Mission:)(Mission: Impossible – Dead Reckoning Part Two)* in 2023 and 2024, respectively.
Pom Klementieff practices taekwondo, in which she holds a purple belt.

# Playground Games

*Revision ID: 1156763010 | Timestamp: 2023-05-24T13:48:39Z*

---

**Playground Games Limited** is a British [game developer](video)(video game developer) based in [Spa](Leamington)(Leamington Spa), England. It is known for developing the *[Horizon](Forza)(Forza#Horizon)* series, which is part of the larger *[Forza](Forza)* franchise. In 2018, Playground Games became part of [Studios](Microsoft)(Microsoft Studios) (now known as Xbox Game Studios). They are also developing the next game in the *[Fable](Fable (video game series))* series.

## History

Playground Games was founded by Gavin Raeburn, Trevor Williams and Ralph Fulton; the studio was announced in November 2009, with its opening scheduled for early 2010. Playground Games announced their first project, *[Horizon](Forza)(Forza Horizon)*, in 2012. The title was developed in collaboration with [10 Studios](Turn)(Turn 10 Studios) and published by [Studios](Microsoft)(Microsoft Studios) for [360](Xbox)(Xbox 360) in October that year. The studio released *[Horizon 2](Forza)(Forza Horizon 2)* on Xbox 360 and [One](Xbox)(Xbox One) in September 2014, and *[Horizon 3](Forza)(Forza Horizon 3)* on Xbox One and [Windows](Microsoft)(Microsoft Windows) in September 2016.

In February 2014, Playground Games announced that they were forming a new development team focused on [game](mobile)(mobile game)s. In February 2017, the studio detailed plans to open a second studio, focusing on a non-racing open-world video game project. In November, they announced they had leased St. Albans House in Leamington Spa, which would provide the new studio with more than 17,000 square feet of office space. Expected headcounts for both studios were in excess of 200 people.

At [2018](E3)(E3 2018), [Microsoft](Microsoft) announced they had acquired Playground Games, which became part of Microsoft Studios (now known as Xbox Game Studios). At the same time, Microsoft Studios also announced *[Horizon 4](Forza)(Forza Horizon 4)*, which would be released on 2 October 2018, and that the studio was working on an unannounced AAA Open-World Action RPG project, later revealed to be in the *Fable* franchise.

In January 2022, it was reported that co-founder and [director](studio)(studio director) Gavin Raeburn left Playground Games to open his own studio, while [GM](General manager) Trevor Williams replaced him as studio head.
The three founders of Playground Games are Gavin Raeburn, Trevor Williams, and Ralph Fulton.

***Reacher*** is an American [crime](action)(action crime) [television](streaming)(streaming television) series developed by [Santora](Nick)(Nick Santora) for [Prime Video](Amazon)(Amazon Prime Video). Based on the [Reacher* book series](*Jack)(Jack Reacher (book series)) by [Child](Lee)(Lee Child), it stars [Ritchson](Alan)(Alan Ritchson) as the title character, a self-proclaimed [hobo](hobo) and former [policeman](military)(Military police) with formidable abilities. Reacher always encounters and is forced to battle dangerous criminals throughout his travels.

The first season, based on *[Floor](Killing)(Killing Floor (novel))*, Child's 1997 [novel](debut)(debut novel), was released on February 4, 2022. A second season has been ordered, and will be based on *[Luck and Trouble](Bad)(Bad Luck and Trouble)*.
## Cast and characters

### Main

* [Ritchson](Alan)(Alan Ritchson) as [Reacher](Jack)(Jack Reacher)

* [Fitzgerald](Willa)(Willa Fitzgerald) as Roscoe Conklin, Margrave PD

* [Goodwin](Malcolm)(Malcolm Goodwin) as Oscar Finlay, Margrave PD Police Captain and Chief Detective

* Chris Webster as Kliner Jr., Kliner Sr.'s son

* [McGill](Bruce)(Bruce McGill) as Mayor Grover Teale and subsequently Police Chief

* [Sten](Maria)(Maria Sten) as Frances Neagley
The actor who plays the title character Jack Reacher in the Amazon Prime Video series is Alan Ritchson.

# List of largest cruise ships

*Revision ID: 1158022562 | Timestamp: 2023-06-01T13:42:21Z*

---

[[File:Wonder of the Seas - August 2021.png|thumb|right|*[of the Seas](Wonder)(Wonder of the Seas)* is the latest ship of Royal Caribbean's  of cruise ships.]]

[ship](Cruise)(Cruise ship)s are large [ship](passenger)(passenger ship)s used mainly for vacationing. Unlike [liner](ocean)(ocean liner)s, they typically embark on round-trip voyages to various ports-of-call, where passengers may go on [tours](Tourism) known as "shore excursions". They may carry thousands of passengers in a single trip, and are some of the largest ships in the world by the [tonnage](gross)(gross tonnage)(GT), bigger than many [ships](cargo)(List of largest container ships). Cruise ships started to exceed ocean liners in size and capacity in the mid-1990s; before then, few were more than 50,000GT. In the decades since, the size of the largest vessels has more than doubled. There have been nine or more new cruise ships added every year since 2001, most of which are 100,000GT or greater. In the two decades between 1988 and 2009, the largest cruise ships grew a third longer (268 m to 360 m), almost doubled their widths (32.2 m to 60.5 m), doubled the total passengers (2,744 to 5,400), and tripled in volume (73,000 GT to 225,000 GT). , the largest cruise ship, , has a gross tonnage of 236,857, is  long,  wide, and holds up to 6,988 passengers.

Cruise ships are organized much like floating hotels, with a complete hospitality staff in addition to the usual ship's crew. Modern cruise ships, while sacrificing some qualities of [seaworthiness](seakeeping), have added amenities to cater to [tourists](nautical)(nautical tourism), with recent vessels being described as "balcony-laden floating condominiums". The "megaships" went from a single deck with verandas to all decks with verandas, and feature ameneties such as theaters, fine-dining and chain restaurants, spas, fitness centers, casinos, sports facilities, and even amusement park attractions.

Cruise ships require electricity for powering both hotel services and for [propulsion](Marine propulsion). Cruise ships are designed with all the heavy machinery at the bottom of the ship and lightweight materials at the top, making them inherently stable even as ship designs are getting taller and taller, and most passenger ships utilize [fins](stabilizer)(Stabilizer (ship)) to further reduce rolling of tall ships in heavy weather. While some cruise ships use traditional fixed [propeller](propeller)s and [rudder](rudder)s to steer, most larger ships use propellers that can swivel left and right to steer the ship, known as [thruster](azimuth)(azimuth thruster)s, which allow even the largest ship designs to have adequate maneuverability.

Cruise ships are operated by [line](cruise)(cruise line)s, which are [companies](company) that market cruises to the public. In the 1990s, many cruise lines were bought by much larger holding companies and continue to operate as brands or subsidiaries of the holding company. For instance, [Corporation & plc](Carnival)(Carnival Corporation & plc) owns both the [mass-market](Mass market) [Cruise Line](Carnival)(Carnival Cruise Line), focused on larger party ships for younger travelers, and [America Line](Holland)(Holland America Line), whose smaller ships cultivate an image of classic elegance. The common practice in the cruise industry in ship sales and orders is to list the smaller operating company, not the larger holding corporation, as the recipient cruise line of the ship.
As of 2023, the largest cruise ship, *Wonder of the Seas*, has a gross tonnage of 236,857.

### Mentored by Balakirev; time with The Five

The Five}}

Once back in Saint Petersburg in May 1865, Rimsky-Korsakov's onshore duties consisted of a couple of hours of clerical duty each day, but he recalled that his desire to compose "had been stifled ... I did not concern myself with music at all."Rimsky-Korsakov, *My Musical Life*, p. 55. He wrote that contact with Balakirev in September 1865 encouraged him "to get accustomed to music and later to plunge into it".Rimsky-Korsakov, *My Musical Life*, p. 56. At Balakirev's suggestion, he wrote a trio to the [scherzo](scherzo) of the E-flat minor symphony, which it had lacked up to that point, and reorchestrated the entire symphony.Rimsky-Korsakov, *My Musical Life*, pp. 58–59. Its first performance came in December of that year under Balakirev's direction in Saint Petersburg.Abraham, *New Grove (1980)*, 16:28. A second performance followed in March 1866 under the direction of Konstantin Lyadov (father of composer [Lyadov](Anatoly)(Anatoly Lyadov)).

Correspondence between Rimsky-Korsakov and Balakirev clearly shows that some ideas for the symphony originated with Balakirev, who seldom stopped at merely correcting a piece of music, and would often recompose it at the piano. Rimsky-Korsakov recalled,

A pupil like myself had to submit to Balakirev a proposed composition in its embryo, say, even the first four or eight bars. Balakirev would immediately make corrections, indicating how to recast such an embryo; he would criticize it, would praise and extol the first two bars, but would censure the next two, ridicule them, and try hard to make the author disgusted with them. Vivacity of composition and fertility were not at all in favor, frequent recasting was demanded, and the composition was extended over a long period of time under the cold control of self-criticism.Rimsky-Korsakov, *My Musical Life*, p. 29.

[[File:Balakirev from 1914 Windsor Magazine.png|thumb|upright|alt=A man in his late 20s or early 30s with dark hair and a bushy beard, wearing a dark coat, dress shirt and tie|[Balakirev](Mily)(Mily Balakirev) encouraged Rimsky-Korsakov to continue composing.]]

Rimsky-Korsakov recalled that "Balakirev had no difficulty in getting along with me. At his suggestion I most readily rewrote the symphonic movements composed by me and brought them to completion with the help of his advice and improvisations".Rimsky-Korsakov, *My Musical Life*, p. 30. Though Rimsky-Korsakov later found Balakirev's influence stifling, and broke free from it,Maes, p. 44. this did not stop him in his memoirs from extolling the older composer's talents as a critic and improviser. Under Balakirev's mentoring, Rimsky-Korsakov turned to other compositions. He began a symphony in B minor, but felt it too closely followed [Beethoven](Ludwig van Beethoven)'s [Symphony](Ninth)(Symphony No. 9 (Beethoven)) and abandoned it. He completed an Overture on Three Russian Themes, based on Balakirev's folksong overtures, as well as a [on Serbian Themes](Fantasia)(Fantasy on Serbian Themes) that was performed at a concert given for the delegates of the [Congress](Slavonic)(Pan-Slavism) in 1867. In his review of this concert, nationalist critic [Stasov](Vladimir)(Vladimir Stasov) coined the phrase *Moguchaya kuchka* for the Balakirev circle (*Moguchaya kuchka* is usually translated as "The Mighty Handful" or "The Five"). Rimsky-Korsakov also composed the initial versions of *Sadko* and *[Antar](Antar (Rimsky-Korsakov))*, which cemented his reputation as a writer of orchestral works.

Rimsky-Korsakov socialized and discussed music with the other members of The Five; they critiqued one another's works in progress and collaborated on new pieces. He became friends with [Borodin](Alexander)(Alexander Borodin), whose music "astonished" him.Rimsky-Korsakov, *My Musical Life*, p. 57. He spent an increasing amount of time with Mussorgsky. Balakirev and Mussorgsky played piano four-hand music, Mussorgsky would sing, and they frequently discussed other composers' works, with preferred tastes running "toward Glinka, Schumann and Beethoven's late quartets".Rimsky-Korsakov, *My Musical Life*, p. 21. [Mendelssohn](Felix Mendelssohn) was not thought of highly, [Mozart](Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart) and [Haydn](Joseph Haydn) "were considered out of date and naïve", and [Bach](J.S.)(Johann Sebastian Bach) merely mathematical and unfeeling. Berlioz "was highly esteemed", Liszt "crippled and perverted from a musical point of view ... even a caricature", and Wagner discussed little. Rimsky-Korsakov "listened to these opinions with avidity and absorbed the tastes of Balakirev, Cui and Mussorgsky without reasoning or examination". Often, the musical works in question "were played before me only in fragments, and I had no idea of the whole work". This, he wrote, did not stop him from accepting these judgments at face value and repeating them "as if I were thoroughly convinced of their truth".

Rimsky-Korsakov became especially appreciated within The Five, and among those who visited the circle, for his talents as an orchestrator. He was asked by Balakirev to orchestrate a [Schubert](Franz Schubert) march for a concert in May 1868, by Cui to orchestrate the opening chorus of his opera *[Ratcliff](William)(William Ratcliff (Cui))* and by [Dargomyzhsky](Alexander)(Alexander Dargomyzhsky), whose works were greatly appreciated by The Five and who was close to death, to orchestrate his opera *[Stone Guest](The)(The Stone Guest (Dargomyzhsky))*.

In late 1871, Rimsky-Korsakov moved into Voin's former apartment, and invited Mussorgsky to be his roommate. The working arrangement they agreed upon was that Mussorgsky used the piano in the mornings while Rimsky-Korsakov worked on copying or orchestration. When Mussorgsky left for his civil service job at noon, Rimsky-Korsakov then used the piano. Time in the evenings was allotted by mutual agreement. "That autumn and winter the two of us accomplished a good deal", Rimsky-Korsakov wrote, "with constant exchange of ideas and plans. Mussorgsky composed and orchestrated the Polish act of *[Godunov](Boris)(Boris Godunov (opera))* and the folk scene 'Near Kromy.' I orchestrated and finished my *[of Pskov](Maid)(The Maid of Pskov)*."Rimsky-Korsakov, *My Musical Life*, p. 123.

## Compositions

[[File:Walentin Alexandrowitsch Serow 004.jpg|thumb|alt=A man with dark gray hair, glasses and a long beard seated at a desk, looking at a music manuscript|Portrait of Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov by [Serov](Valentin)(Valentin Serov) (1898)]]

Rimsky-Korsakov followed the musical ideals espoused by The Five. He employed Orthodox liturgical themes in the *[Easter Festival Overture](Russian)(Russian Easter Festival Overture)*, folk song in *[Espagnol](Capriccio)(Capriccio Espagnol)* and orientalism in *[Scheherazade](Scheherazade (Rimsky-Korsakov))*, possibly his best known work.Maes, pp. 175–176. He proved a prolific composer but also a perpetually self-critical one. He revised every orchestral work up to and including his Third Symphony—some, like *[Antar](Antar (Rimsky-Korsakov))* and *[Sadko](Sadko (musical tableau))*, more than once. These revisions range from minor changes of tempo, phrasing and instrumental detail to wholesale [transposition](transposition (music)) and complete recomposition.Abraham, *Slavonic*, pp. 197–198.

Rimsky-Korsakov was open about the influences in his music, telling Vasily Yastrebtsev, "Study Liszt and Balakirev more closely, and you'll see that a great deal in me is not mine".Yastrebtsev, p. 37. He followed Balakirev in his use of the whole tone scale, treatment of folk songs and musical [orientalism](orientalism) and Liszt for harmonic adventurousness. (The violin melody used to portray [Scheherazade](Scheherazade) is very closely related to its counterpart in Balakirev's symphonic poem *[Tamara](Tamara (Balakirev))*, while the *Russian Easter Overtures* follows the design and plan of Balakirev's Second Overture on Russian Themes.)

Nevertheless, while he took Glinka and Liszt as his harmonic models, his use of [tone](whole)(whole tone scale) and [scale](octatonic)(octatonic scale)s do demonstrate his originality. He developed both these compositional devices for the "fantastic" sections of his operas, which depicted magical or supernatural characters and events.

Rimsky-Korsakov maintained an interest in harmonic experiments and continued exploring new idioms throughout his career. He tempered this interest with an abhorrence of excess and kept his tendency to experiment under constant control. The more radical his harmonies became, the more he attempted to control them with strict rules—applying his "musical conscience", as he called it. In this sense, he was both a progressive and a conservative composer.Maes, p. 180. The whole tone and octatonic scales were both considered adventurous in the Western classical tradition, and Rimsky-Korsakov's use of them made his harmonies seem radical. Conversely, his care about how or when in a composition he used these scales made him seem conservative compared with later composers like [Stravinsky](Igor)(Igor Stravinsky), though they were often building on Rimsky-Korsakov's work.Maes, pp. 180, 195.
The Russian composer who was a member of the group known as The Five and is famous for the orchestral suite *Scheherazade* is Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov.

**Aldi** (stylised as **ALDI**) is the common company brand name of two German multinational family-owned [supermarket](discount)(discount supermarket) [chains](Chain store) operating over 10,000 stores in 20 countries. The chain was founded by brothers [Karl](Karl Albrecht) and [Albrecht](Theo)(Theo Albrecht) in 1946, when they took over their mother's store in [Essen](Essen). The business was split into two separate groups in 1960, that later became **Aldi Nord**, headquartered in [Essen](Essen), and **Aldi Süd**, headquartered in [Mülheim](Mülheim an der Ruhr)."[Impressum](http://www.aldi-nord.de/impressum.html)" Aldi Nord. Retrieved on 14 February 2011. "Aldi Einkauf GmbH & Co. oHG Eckenbergstraße 16 45307 Essen.""[Impressum](http://www.aldi-sud.de/de/html/impressum.htm) ." Aldi Süd. Retrieved on 14 February 2011. "Burgstraße 37 45476 Mülheim an der Ruhr Amtsgericht Duisburg HRA 8577."

In 1962, they introduced the name **Aldi** (a [abbreviation](syllabic)(syllabic abbreviation) for **Al**brecht **Di**skont), which is pronounced . In Germany, Aldi Nord and Aldi Süd have been financially and legally separate since 1966, although both divisions' names may appear as if they were a single enterprise with certain [brand](store)(store brand)s or when negotiating with [contractor](General contractor) companies. The formal business name of Aldi Nord is Aldi Einkauf GmbH & Co., while the formal business name of Aldi Süd is ALDI SÜD Dienstleistungs-SE & Co.  Each company is owned and operated independently, but do have contractual business with one another.

Aldi's German operations consist of Aldi Nord's 35 individual regional companies with about 2,500 stores in western, northern, and eastern Germany, and Aldi Süd's 32 regional companies with 1,900 stores in western and southern Germany. How Does Aldi Make Money  Strategy and Insights – Vizologi  rethinking business model design|date=13 December 2017|work=Vizologi  rethinking business model design|access-date=5 July 2018}} Internationally, Aldi Nord operates in [Denmark](Denmark), [France](France), the [Benelux](Benelux) countries, [Portugal](Portugal), [Spain](Spain) and [Poland](Poland), while Aldi Süd operates in [Ireland](Republic of Ireland), the [Kingdom](United)(United Kingdom), [Hungary](Hungary), [Switzerland](Switzerland), [Australia](Australia), [China](China), [Italy](Italy), [Austria](Austria) and [Slovenia](Slovenia). Both Aldi Nord (owner of [Joe's](Trader)(Trader Joe's)) and Aldi Süd (as Aldi) also operate in the [States](United)(United States) with 1,600 stores between them as of 2017, and the U.S. is the only country to have both Aldi companies operating outside of Germany.

The name "Aldi" is an abbreviation for "Albrecht Diskont," which translates to "Albrecht's discount" in German. It is derived from the founders' surnames, Karl and Theo Albrecht, and the word "Diskont," meaning discount.

### Background

After the success of [Nintendo](Nintendo)'s [Boy family](Game)(Game Boy family) of [game console](handheld)(handheld game console)s throughout the 1990s and early 2000s, with little market competition, and [Sony](Sony)'s massive success with its [PlayStation](PlayStation (console)) and [2](PlayStation)(PlayStation 2) [video game console](home)(home video game console)s around the same time, Sony entered the handheld market as well. In 2004, it released the [Portable](PlayStation)(PlayStation Portable) (PSP) to compete with the [DS](Nintendo)(Nintendo DS) as part of the [generation of video game consoles](seventh)(seventh generation of video game consoles). After a slow start in the worldwide market, it was invigorated in Japan with multiple releases in the *[Hunter](Monster)(Monster Hunter)* series. With the series being less popular in western regions, it failed to revive the platform in the same way. The PSP ended up being a mixed result for the company. It was seen as a success in that it was the only handheld video game platform that had ever significantly competed with Nintendo for market share, with almost 80 million units sold in its lifespan, roughly the same amount as Nintendo's [Boy Advance](Game)(Game Boy Advance) had during the [generation of video game consoles](sixth)(sixth generation of video game consoles). This is only a little more than half of the sales of its actual market competitor, the DS, which was more than 150 million units by the end of 2011.

Rumors of a successor to the PSP came as early as July 2009 when *[Eurogamer](Eurogamer)* reported that Sony was working on such a device, which would utilize the PowerVR SGX543MP processor and perform at a level similar to the original [Xbox](Xbox (console)). Through mid-2010, websites continued to run stories about accounts of the existence of a "PSP 2". Reports arose during the [Game Show](Tokyo)(Tokyo Game Show) that the device was unveiled internally during a private meeting during mid-September held at Sony Computer Entertainment's headquarters in Aoyama, Tokyo. Shortly after, reports of [kits](development)(development kits) for the handheld had reportedly already been shipped to numerous video game developers including both [first-party](SIE Worldwide Studios) and third-party developers to start making games for the device, a report later confirmed by *[Kombat](Mortal)(Mortal Kombat (2011 video game))* Executive Producer Shaun Himmerick. By November, Senior Vice President of [Arts](Electronic)(Electronic Arts), Patrick Soderlund, confirmed that he had seen that the PlayStation Portable successor existed, but could not confirm details. In the same month, [VG247](VG247) released pictures of an early prototype version showing a [Go](PSP)(PSP Go)-like slide-screen design along with two analog sticks, two cameras and a microphone, though the report mentioned that overheating issues had since caused them to move away from the design in favor of a model more similar to the original PlayStation Portable device.

Throughout 2010, Sony would not confirm these reports of a PSP successor but would make comments regarding making future hardware. [Yoshida](Shuhei)(Shuhei Yoshida), President of [Worldwide Studios](SCE)(SCE Worldwide Studios) revealed that his studio, despite usually being more involved with software, had a continued role in future hardware development at the time. In December, [Computer Entertainment](Sony)(Sony Computer Entertainment) CEO [Hirai](Kazuo)(Kazuo Hirai) stated that Sony aimed to appeal to a wide demographic of people by using multiple input methods on future hardware; buttons and joysticks for traditional handheld game system users, and touchscreens for [phone](smart)(smart phone) users. The device was officially announced by Sony on January 27, 2011, at their "PlayStation Meeting" press conference held by the company in Japan. The system, only known by its code name "Next Generation Portable", was announced to be a handheld gaming device that aimed for [3](PlayStation)(PlayStation 3) quality visuals, which was later clarified to not be taken at a literal level because, according to David Coombes, platform research manager at [Computer Entertainment America](Sony)(Sony Computer Entertainment America), "Well, it's not going to run at 2 GHz [the PS3](like) because the battery would last five minutes and it would probably set fire to your pants". Its power was later described by Sony engineers as about halfway between the PSP and PS3. As rumors had suggested, the device was designed to present "the best of both worlds" between mobile and handheld gaming, including a 5-inch OLED touchscreen, a rear touchpad coupled with physical buttons and dual analog sticks. Sony also revealed that the device would be using a mix of retail and digital distribution of games. Further details were announced at [Developers Conference](Game)(Game Developers Conference) 2011, including that Sony would be dropping the PSP's [UMD](Universal Media Disc) disc format in favor of small game cartridges of 2 GB or 4 GB size variants.  along with two cameras, facial detection, head detection and tracking capabilities.
The codename used for the PlayStation Vita before its official announcement was "Next Generation Portable."
