### 2001–2005: Breakthrough

Wood made her teenage debut as a leading film actress in 2001's *[Secrets](Little)(Little Secrets (2001 film))*, directed by [Treu](Blair)(Blair Treu), where she played 14-year-old aspiring concert violinist Emily Lindstrom. For that role, she was nominated for Best Leading Young Actress at the [Young Artist Awards](24th)(24th Young Artist Awards). Wood next played a supporting role in [Niccol](Andrew)(Andrew Niccol)'s 2002 satirical [fiction](science)(science fiction) film *[Simone](Simone (2002 film))*, which starred [Pacino](Al)(Al Pacino). That same year, Wood was recognized as One to Watch at the [Hollywood Awards](Young)(Young Hollywood Awards). }}

Wood's breakout movie role followed with [Hardwicke](Catherine)(Catherine Hardwicke)'s 2003 film *[Thirteen](Thirteen (2003 film))*. She starred as Tracy Louise Freeland, a young teen who sinks into a downward spiral of hard drugs, sex, and petty crime. Her performance garnered critical acclaim, earning her [Globe](Golden)(Golden Globe Award for Best Actress in a Motion Picture – Drama) and [Actors Guild](Screen)(Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Leading Role) nominations for Best Lead Actress. During the time of *Thirteen*s release, Wood was featured on the cover of *[Vogue](Vogue (magazine))*, with the magazine naming her as one of the "It Girls" of Hollywood. She similarly appeared, along with eight other teen actresses, on the cover of *[Fair](Vanity)(Vanity Fair (magazine))*s Young Hollywood issue in July 2003. A supporting role opposite [Blanchett](Cate)(Cate Blanchett) and [Lee Jones](Tommy)(Tommy Lee Jones) in [Howard](Ron)(Ron Howard)'s *[Missing](The)(The Missing (2003 film))*, in which she played the kidnapped daughter Lilly Gilkeson, followed the same year, earning her a nomination for Best Leading Young Actress at the [Young Artist Awards](25th)(25th Young Artist Awards).

In 2005, Wood appeared opposite [Costner](Kevin)(Kevin Costner) and [Allen](Joan)(Joan Allen) in the [Binder](Mike)(Mike Binder)-directed *[Upside of Anger](The)(The Upside of Anger)*, a well-reviewed film in which Wood played Lavender "Popeye" Wolfmeyer, one of four sisters dealing with their father's absence. Her character also narrated the film. Wood's next two starring roles were in dark independent films. In the 2005 [Film Festival](Sundance)(Sundance Film Festival) Grand Jury Prize nominee *[Persuasion](Pretty)(Pretty Persuasion)*, a [comedy](black)(black comedy) focusing on the themes of [harassment in schools](sexual)(sexual harassment in education) and attitudes about women in media and society, Wood played Kimberly Joyce, a manipulative, sexually active high-schooler. One critic commented, "Wood does flip cynicism with such precise, easy rhythms and with such obvious pleasure in naughtiness that she's impossible to hate." [Jacobson](David)(David Jacobson (director))'s [neo-western](neo-western) *[in the Valley](Down)(Down in the Valley (film))* premiered later that year, in which Wood's character, Tobe, falls in love with an older man, played by [Norton](Edward)(Edward Norton), a cowboy who is at odds with modern society. Of her performance, it was written that "Wood conveys every bit of the adamant certainty and aching vulnerability inherent in late adolescence." Wood has commented on her sexually-themed roles, saying that she is not aiming for the "shock factor" in her film choices. Also in 2005, Wood starred in the music videos for [Eyes](Bright)(Bright Eyes (band))' "At the Bottom of Everything" and [Day](Green)(Green Day)'s "[Me Up When September Ends](Wake)(Wake Me Up When September Ends)".
In the 2001 film *Little Secrets*, Evan Rachel Wood's character, Emily Lindstrom, aspired to play the violin.

# Unicursal hexagram

*Revision ID: 1154828308 | Timestamp: 2023-05-14T22:37:52Z*

---

[[unicursal hexagram.svg|upright|thumb|Non-interlaced unicursal hexagram](File:Solid)]

The **unicursal hexagram** is a [hexagram](hexagram) or six-pointed star that can be traced or drawn [unicursally](unicursal curve), in one continuous line rather than by two overlaid triangles. The hexagram can also be depicted inside a circle with the points touching it. It is often depicted in an interlaced form with the lines of the hexagram passing over and under one another to form a [knot](knot (mathematics)). It is a specific instance of the far more general shape discussed in [Pascal](Blaise)(Blaise Pascal)'s 1639 *[Mysticum](Hexagrammum)(Hexagrammum Mysticum)*.
The unicursal hexagram is an example of a curve discussed in Blaise Pascal's 1639 work *Hexagrammum Mysticum*.

# Polar bear

*Revision ID: 1155842960 | Timestamp: 2023-05-20T00:17:38Z*

---

| image_caption = Sow near [Kaktovik](Kaktovik, Alaska), [Island](Barter)(Barter Island), [Alaska](Alaska), [States](United)(United States)

The **polar bear** (***Ursus maritimus***) is a [hypercarnivorous](hypercarnivore) [species](species) of [bear](bear). Its [range](native)(species distribution) lies largely within the [Circle](Arctic)(Arctic Circle), encompassing the [Ocean](Arctic)(Arctic Ocean) and its surrounding seas and landmasses, which includes the northernmost regions of [America](North)(North America) and [Eurasia](Eurasia). It is the largest [extant](extant taxon) bear species, as well as the largest extant land carnivore. A boar (adult male) weighs around , while a sow (adult female) is about half that size. Although it is the [species](sister)(sister species) of the [bear](brown)(brown bear), it has evolved to occupy a narrower [niche](ecological)(ecological niche), with many body characteristics adapted for cold temperatures, for moving across snow, ice and open water, and for hunting [seals](Pinniped), which make up most of its diet. Although most polar bears are born on land, they spend most of their time on the [ice](sea)(sea ice). Their scientific name means "[maritime](sea) bear" and derives from this fact. Polar bears hunt their preferred food of seals from the edge of sea ice, often living off fat reserves when no sea ice is present. Because of their dependence on the sea ice, polar bears are classified as [mammal](marine)(marine mammal)s.

Because of expected [loss](habitat)(habitat loss) caused by [change](climate)(climate change), the polar bear is classified as a [species](vulnerable)(vulnerable species). For decades, large-scale hunting raised international concern for the future of the species, but populations rebounded after controls and quotas began to take effect. For thousands of years, the polar bear has been a key figure in the material, spiritual, and cultural life of [peoples](circumpolar)(circumpolar peoples), and polar bears remain important in their cultures. Historically, the polar bear has also been known as the "white bear". It is sometimes referred to as the "nanook", based on the [Inuit](Inuit languages) term *nanuq*.

### Contemporary regulations

[[sign warning about the presence of bears. The Norwegian text translates into "Applies to all of Svalbard".](File:Polar-Bear-Warning-Longyearbyen.jpg|thumb|right|Road)]

Concerns over the future survival of the species led to the development of national regulations on polar bear hunting, beginning in the mid-1950s. The Soviet Union banned all hunting in 1956. Canada began imposing hunting quotas in 1968. Norway passed a series of increasingly strict regulations from 1965 to 1973, and has completely banned hunting since then. The United States began regulating hunting in 1971 and adopted the [Mammal Protection Act](Marine)(Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972) in 1972. In 1973, the [Agreement on the Conservation of Polar Bears](International)(International Agreement on the Conservation of Polar Bears) was signed by all five nations whose territory is inhabited by polar bears: Canada, Denmark, Norway, the [Union](Soviet)(Soviet Union), and the United States. Member countries agreed to place restrictions on recreational and commercial hunting, ban hunting from aircraft and icebreakers, and conduct further research.[International Agreement on the Conservation of Polar Bears](https://web.archive.org/web/20030409113042/http://pbsg.npolar.no/ConvAgree/agreement.htm), 15 November 1973, Oslo The treaty allows hunting "by local people using traditional methods". Norway is the only country of the five in which all harvest of polar bears is banned. The agreement was a rare case of international cooperation during the [War](Cold)(Cold War). Biologist [Stirling](Ian)(Ian Stirling (biologist)) commented, "For many years, the conservation of polar bears was the only subject in the entire Arctic that nations from both sides of the Iron Curtain could agree upon sufficiently to sign an agreement. Such was the intensity of human fascination with this magnificent predator, the only marine bear."[Ian](Stirling,)(Ian Stirling (biologist)) *Foreword* in

Agreements have been made between countries to co-manage their shared polar bear subpopulations. After several years of negotiations, Russia and the United States signed an agreement in October 2000 to jointly set quotas for indigenous subsistence hunting in Alaska and [Chukotka](Chukotka Autonomous Okrug). The treaty was ratified in October 2007. In September 2015, the polar bear range states agreed upon a "circumpolar action plan" describing their conservation strategy for polar bears.

The species is listed in Appendix II of the [on International Trade in Endangered Species](Convention)(Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species) (CITES) meaning international trade, including in parts or derivatives, is controlled by the CITES system of permits and certificates. The United States government has proposed that polar bears be transferred to Appendix I of [CITES](CITES) which would ban all commercial international trade in polar bear parts. The decision to leave the species listed under Appendix II was endorsed by the IUCN and [TRAFFIC](TRAFFIC), who determined that such an uplisting was unlikely to confer a conservation benefit.

The five nations that are signatories of the Agreement on the Conservation of Polar Bears are:

1. Canada  
2. Denmark (representing Greenland)  
3. Norway  
4. Russia (Soviet Union)  
5. United States

## Acting career

[[File:Richard Thomas 1 2 3 Go 1961.JPG|thumb|left|Thomas at age 10 in *[2, 3 Go!](1,)(1, 2, 3 Go!)*]]

In 1958, at age seven, Thomas made his Broadway debut in *[at Campobello](Sunrise)(Sunrise at Campobello (play))*. In 1959, he appeared in the *[Hall of Fame](Hallmark)(Hallmark Hall of Fame)* NBC television presentation of [Ibsen](Henrik Ibsen)'s ''[Doll's House](A)(A Doll's House (1959 TV drama))'' with [Harris](Julie)(Julie Harris (American actress)), [Plummer](Christopher)(Christopher Plummer), and [Cronyn](Hume)(Hume Cronyn).[" 'A Doll's House' 1959"](http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/461319/Doll-s-House-A/) tcm.com, retrieved October 25, 2017 He then began acting in daytime TV, appearing in [opera](soap)(soap opera)s such as *[Edge of Night](The)(The Edge of Night)* (as Ben Schultz, 1961), *[Flame in the Wind](A)(A Flame in the Wind)* and *[the World Turns](As)(As the World Turns)* (as [Hughes](Tom)(Tom Hughes (As the World Turns)), 1966–67) which were broadcast from his native Manhattan. In 1970, he guest starred in [NBC](NBC)'s *[Bonanza](Bonanza)* ("The Weary Willies").

Thomas' first major film roles were in *[Winning](Winning (film))* (1969) with [Newman](Paul)(Paul Newman) (about auto racing)[*Winning*](http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/21812/Winning/) [Classic Movies](Turner)(Turner Classic Movies), retrieved October 25, 2017 and *[Summer](Last)(Last Summer (1969 film))* (also 1969) with [Davison](Bruce)(Bruce Davison) and [Hershey](Barbara)(Barbara Hershey) (a summer [coming-of-age](coming-of-age) movie).Canby, Vincent. ["Screen: 'Last Summer':Cinema I Film Brings Trio of Newcomers"](https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9402E7DB1E3AEE34BC4952DFB0668382679EDE) *The New York Times*, June 11, 1969

In 1971, he starred in *[Sky at Morning](Red)(Red Sky at Morning (1971 film))*, and played the lead in *Cactus in the Snow* (an independent production, considered lost and difficult to acquire through VHS, DVD or any other format).

[[File:Richard Thomas John-Boy Walton 1973.JPG|right|thumb|200px|Thomas on the set of *[Waltons](The)(The Waltons)* in 1973]]

***The Waltons***

Beginning in 1972, Thomas became recognized worldwide for his portrayal of [Walton](John-Boy)(John-Boy Walton) in the TV series *[Waltons](The)(The Waltons),* based on the life story of writer [Hamner, Jr.](Earl)(Earl Hamner, Jr.)  He appeared in the original CBS television film *The Homecoming: A Christmas Story* in 1971,[*The Homecoming*](http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/469474/Homecoming-The/) Turner Classic Movies, retrieved October 25, 2017 which inspired the commissioning of the otherwise largely recast series) and then played the role continuously in 122 episodes. In March 1977, Thomas left the series and his role was taken over by [Wightman](Robert)(Robert Wightman). However, Thomas returned to the role in three *Waltons* TV movies in the 1990s, including *A Walton Thanksgiving Reunion* in 1993.[*A Walton Thanksgiving Reunion*](http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/482133/Walton-Thanksgiving-Reunion-A/) tcm.com, retrieved October 25, 2017  Thomas won an [Award](Emmy)(Emmy Award) for Best Actor in a Dramatic Series in 1973.

Thomas played against type as murderer and rapist Kenneth Kinsolving in ''[Like My Mother](You'll)(You'll Like My Mother)* in 1972 with [Duke](Patty)(Patty Duke).[*You’ll Like My Mother*](http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/96483/You-ll-Like-My-Mother/) Turner Classic Movies, retrieved October 25, 2017 He played the lead roles of Private Henry Fleming in the [NBC](NBC) TV movie *[Red Badge of Courage](The)(The Red Badge of Courage (1974 film))* in 1974[*The Red Badge of Courage*](http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/476456/Red-Badge-of-Courage-The/) Turner Classic Movies, retrieved October 25, 2017 and Paul Bäumer in the 1979 [CBS](CBS) TV movie on *[Quiet on the Western Front](All)(All Quiet on the Western Front (1979 film))*.[*All Quiet on the Western Front''](http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/415120/All-Quiet-on-the-Western-Front/) Turner Classic Movies, retrieved October 25, 2017

In other TV films, he played Col. Warner's younger son Jim in *[The Next Generations](Roots:)(Roots: The Next Generations)* (the 1979 sequel to 1977's *[Roots](Roots (1977 miniseries))*),[*Roots: The Next Generations*](http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/479068/Roots-The-Next-Generations/) Turner Classic Movies, retrieved October 25, 2017 the title role in the biopic *[Proof: The Hank Williams Jr. Story](Living)(Living Proof: The Hank Williams Jr. Story)* in 1983,[*Living Proof: The Hank Williams, Jr., Story*](http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/25441/Living-Proof-The-Hank-Williams-Jr-Story/) Turner Classic Movies, retrieved October 25, 2017 Will Mossup in CBS' ''Hobson's Choice* in 1983,[*Hobson’s Choice*](http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/468820/Hobson-s-Choice/) tcm.com, retrieved October 25, 2017 Henry Durie in *[Master of Ballantrae](The)(The Master of Ballantrae (1984 film))* for Hallmark Hall of Fame,[*The Master of Ballantrae*](http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/414258/Master-Of-Ballantrae-The/) Turner Classic Movies, retrieved October 25, 2017 Martin Campbell in *[Jeopardy](Final)(Final Jeopardy (1985 film))*[*Final Jeopardy''](http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/19654/Final-Jeopardy/) Turner Classic Movies, retrieved October 25, 2017 and the adult [Denbrough](Bill)(Bill Denbrough) in the 1990 television mini-series adaptation of [King](Stephen)(Stephen King)'s epic horror novel *[It](It (novel))*.[*Stephen King’s It*](http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/478610/Stephen-King-s-It/) Turner Classic Movies, retrieved October 25, 2017

In 1980, Thomas made his first Broadway appearance in more than 12 years when he was a replacement in [Wilson](Lanford)(Lanford Wilson)'s *[of July](Fifth)(Fifth of July)*.[*Fifth of July*](http://www.playbill.com/production/fifth-of-july-new-apollo-theatre-vault-0000001253) *[Playbill](Playbill)*, retrieved October 25, 2017 In the same year, he appeared as Shad (the young farmer entrusted to employ mercenaries to save his planet from Sador and his invading forces) in *[Beyond the Stars](Battle)(Battle Beyond the Stars)*.[*Battle Beyond the Stars*](http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/22737/Battle-Beyond-The-Stars/full-credits.html) Turner Classic Movies, retrieved October 25, 2017

"On stage: reliving historic turning points. Howard Fast's 'Citizen Tom Paine'." *The [Science Monitor](Christian)(Christian Science Monitor)*. In 1993, he played the title role in a Shakespeare Theater stage production of *[II](Richard)(Richard II (play))* in Washington, D.C.Brantley, Ben. ["Review/Theater: Richard II; Richard Thomas Puts His Stamp On Giving Up a Throne Vigorously"](https://www.nytimes.com/1993/09/22/movies/review-theater-richard-ii-richard-thomas-puts-his-stamp-giving-up-throne.html?pagewanted=) *The New York Times*, September 22, 1993

Thomas starred with [O'Hara](Maureen)(Maureen O'Hara) and his *[It](It (miniseries))* co-star [O'Toole](Annette)(Annette O'Toole) in the [Channel](Hallmark)(Hallmark Channel) movie *[Christmas Box](The)(The Christmas Box)* in 1995.McCarthy, John P. ["Cbs Sunday Movie 'the Christmas Box' "](https://variety.com/1995/tv/reviews/cbs-sunday-movie-the-christmas-box-1200444090/) *[Variety](Variety (magazine))*, December 13, 1995

As of January 2023, Thomas has been credited on [Audible](Audible (service)) for narrating over 340 books.

## Early history

[[Express Company 1865.JPG|thumb|Share of the American Express Company, 1865](File:American)]

In 1850, American Express was started as an [mail](express)(express mail) business in [New York](Buffalo,)(Buffalo, New York). It was founded as a joint-stock corporation by the merger of the express companies owned by [Wells](Henry)(Henry Wells) (Wells & Company), [G. Fargo](William)(William G. Fargo) (Livingston, Fargo & Company), and [Warren Butterfield](John)(John Warren Butterfield) (Wells, Butterfield & Company, the successor earlier in 1850 of Butterfield, Wasson & Company). Wells and Fargo also started [Fargo & Co.](Wells)(History of Wells Fargo) in 1852 when Butterfield and other directors objected to the proposal that American Express extend its operations to California. American Express initially established its headquarters in a building at the intersection of Jay Street and [Street](Hudson)(Hudson Street (Manhattan)) in what was later called the [Tribeca](Tribeca) section of Manhattan. For years it enjoyed a virtual monopoly on the movement of express shipments (goods, securities, currency, etc.) throughout New York State. In 1874, American Express moved its headquarters to 65 Broadway in what was becoming the [District](Financial)(Financial District, Manhattan) of Manhattan, a location it was to retain through two buildings.[[express dog 1890.jpg|thumb|181x181px|An advert from 1890 featuring a watchdog on an American Express shipping trunk |left](File:Amer)]In 1854, the American Express Co. purchased a lot on Vesey Street in New York City as the site for its stables. The company's first New York headquarters was an 1858 marble Italianate palazzo at 55–61 [Street](Hudson)(Hudson Street (Manhattan)), which had a busy freight depot on the ground story with a spur line from the [River Railroad](Hudson)(Hudson River Railroad). A stable was constructed in 1867, five blocks north at 4–8 Hubert Street. The company prospered sufficiently that headquarters were moved in 1874 from the wholesale shipping district to the budding Financial District and into rented offices in two five-story brownstone commercial buildings at 63 and 65 Broadway that were owned by the Harmony family.

In 1880, American Express built a new warehouse behind the Broadway Building at 46 Trinity Place. The designer is unknown, but it has a façade of brick arches that are reminiscent of pre-skyscraper New York. American Express has long been out of this building, but it still bears a [terracotta](terracotta) seal with the American Express Eagle. In 1890–91 the company constructed a new ten-story building by [H. Kendall](Edward)(Edward H. Kendall) on the site of its former headquarters on [Street](Hudson)(Hudson Street (Manhattan)). By 1903, the company had assets of some $28 million, second only to the [City Bank of New York](National)(Citibank) among [institution](financial)(financial institution)s in the city. To reflect this, the company purchased the Broadway buildings and site. At the end of the Wells-Fargo reign in 1914, an aggressive new president, George Chadbourne Taylor (1868–1923), who had worked his way up through the company over the previous thirty years, decided to build a new headquarters. The old buildings, dubbed by *[New York Times](The)(The New York Times)* as "among the ancient landmarks" of lower Broadway, were inadequate for such a rapidly expanding concern.

After some delays due to the First World War, the 21-story [neo-classical](Neoclassicism) [Express Co. Building](American)(65 Broadway) was constructed in 1916–17 to the design of James L. Aspinwall, of the firm of Renwick, Aspinwall & Tucker, the successor to the architectural practice of the eminent [Renwick Jr.](James)(James Renwick Jr.) The building consolidated the two lots of the former buildings with a single address: [Broadway](65)(65 Broadway). This building was part of the "Express Row" section of lower Broadway at the time. The building completed the continuous masonry wall of its block-front and assisted in transforming Broadway into the "canyon" of neo-classical masonry office towers familiar to this day. American Express sold this building in 1975, but retained travel services there. The building was also the headquarters over the years of other prominent firms, including investment bankers [W. Seligman & Co](J.&)(J. & W. Seligman & Co.). (1940–74), the [Bureau of Shipping](American)(American Bureau of Shipping), a maritime concern (1977–86), and later J.J. Kenny, and [& Poor's](Standard)(Standard & Poor's), the latter of which renamed the building for itself.
### 1980s to present

### National expansion

American Express extended its reach nationwide by arranging affiliations with other express companies (including [Fargo](Wells)(History of Wells Fargo) – the replacement for the two former companies that merged to form American Express), railroads, and steamship companies. In 1857, American Express started its expansion in the area of financial services by launching a [order](money)(money order) business to compete with the [States Post Office](United)(United States Post Office)'s money orders. Sometime between 1888 and 1890, [C. Fargo](J.)(J. C. Fargo) took a trip to Europe and returned frustrated and infuriated. Despite the fact that he was president of American Express and that he carried with him traditional [of credit](letters)(letter of credit), he found it difficult to obtain cash anywhere except in major cities. Fargo went to [Flemming Berry](Marcellus)(Marcellus Flemming Berry) and asked him to create a better solution than the letter of credit. Berry introduced the American Express [Cheque](Traveler's)(traveler's cheque) which was launched in 1891 in denominations of $10, $20, $50, and $100.

Traveler's cheques established American Express as a truly international company. In 1914, at the onset of [War I](World)(World War I), American Express in Europe was among the few companies to honor the letters of credit (issued by various banks) held by Americans in Europe, because other financial institutions refused to assist these stranded travelers. The British government appointed American Express its official agent at the beginning of World War I. They were to deliver letters, money, and relief parcels to British prisoners of war. Their employees went into camps to cash drafts for both British and French prisoners and arranged for them to receive money from home. By the end of the war they were delivering 150 tonnes of parcels per day to prisoners in six countries.

### Railroad express business

[[Amerikanen bij American Express Damrak om geld en dergelijke in te wisselen, Bestanddeelnr 924-8211.jpg|thumb|An American Express branch in 1974](File:Veel)]

American Express was one of the monopolies that [Theodore Roosevelt](President)(Theodore Roosevelt) had the [Commerce Commission](Interstate)(Interstate Commerce Commission) (ICC) investigate during his administration. The interest of the ICC was drawn to its strict control of the railroad express business. However, the solution did not come immediately to hand. The solution to this problem came as a coincidence to other problems during World War I. During the winter of 1917, the United States suffered a severe coal shortage and on December 26 [President](President of the United States) [Wilson](Woodrow)(Woodrow Wilson) commandeered the railroads on behalf of the United States government to move [troops](federal)(United States Armed Forces), their supplies, and coal. Treasury Secretary [Gibbs McAdoo](William)(William Gibbs McAdoo) was assigned the task of consolidating the railway lines for the [effort](war)(war effort). All contracts between express companies and railroads were nullified and McAdoo proposed that all existing express companies be consolidated into a single company to serve the country's needs. This ended American Express's express business and removed them from the ICC's interest. The result was that a new company called the [Railway Express Agency](American)(Railway Express Agency) formed in July 1918. The new entity took custody of all the pooled equipment and property of existing express companies (the largest share of which, 40%, came from American Express, who had owned the rights to the express business over  of railroad lines, and had 10,000 offices, with over 30,000 employees). In 1966, American Express introduced the Gold Card. American Express formed a venture with [Communications](Warner)(Warner Communications) in 1979, called [Satellite Entertainment](Warner-Amex)(Warner-Amex Satellite Entertainment), which created MTV, [Nickelodeon](Nickelodeon), and [Movie Channel](The)(The Movie Channel). The partnership lasted only until 1984. The properties were sold to [Viacom](Viacom (1971–2005)) soon after.

The joint venture formed by American Express and Warner Communications in 1979 that created MTV and Nickelodeon was called Satellite Entertainment, specifically known as Warner-Amex Satellite Entertainment.

### Later life

[[File:Miyamoto Musashi Self-Portrait.jpg|thumb|upright|Miyamoto Musashi, *[Self-portrait](Self-portrait),* c. 1640]]Twenty-one years later, in 1633, Musashi began staying with [Tadatoshi](Hosokawa)(Hosokawa Tadatoshi), *[daimyō](Daimyo)* of [Castle](Kumamoto)(Kumamoto Castle), who had moved to the [Kumamoto](Kumamoto) fief and Kokura, to train and paint. While he engaged in very few duels; one would occur in 1634 at the arrangement of Lord Ogasawara, in which Musashi defeated a lance specialist by the name of [Matabei](Takada)(Takada Matabei). Musashi would officially become the retainer of the Hosokowa lords of Kumamoto in 1640. The *Niten Ki* records "[he] received from Lord Tadatoshi: 17 retainers, a stipend of 300 [koku](koku), the rank of *ōkumigashira* 大組頭, and [Castle](Chiba)(Chiba Castle) in Kumamoto as his residence."Toyota, p. 250

[[File:Tombe de Miyamoto Musashi à Ōhara, province de Mimasaka.jpg|thumb|Miyamoto Musashi's grave in [Ōhara-chō](Ōhara, Okayama), [of Mimasaka](province)(Mimasaka Province)]]

[[park.JPG|thumb|upright|The grave-marker of Miyamoto Musashi, in present-day Kumamoto Prefecture (熊本県)](File:Musashizuka)]

[[File:Miyamoto_Musashi_killing_a_giant_nue.jpg|thumb|Miyamoto Musashi kills a shark fish (Yamazame) in the mountains across the border of [Province](Echizen)(Echizen Province), by [Kuniyoshi](Utagawa)(Utagawa Kuniyoshi)]]

[[File:Musashi_ts_pic.jpg|thumb|Miyamoto Musashi in his prime, wielding two [bokken](bokken); woodblock print by [Kuniyoshi](Utagawa)(Utagawa Kuniyoshi)]]

In the second month of 1641, Musashi wrote a work called the *Hyoho Sanju Go* ("Thirty-five Instructions on Strategy") for [Tadatoshi](Hosokawa)(Hosokawa Tadatoshi). This work overlapped and formed the basis for the later *[Book of Five Rings](The)(The Book of Five Rings)*. This was the year that his adopted son, [Yoemon](Hirao)(Hirao Yoemon), became Master of Arms for the Owari fief. In 1642, Musashi suffered attacks of [neuralgia](neuralgia), foreshadowing his future ill-health. In 1643 he retired to a cave named *[Reigandō](Reigandō)* as a hermit to write *[Book of Five Rings](The)(The Book of Five Rings)*. He finished it in the second month of 1645. On the twelfth of the fifth month, sensing his impending death, Musashi bequeathed his worldly possessions, after giving his manuscript copy of *The Book of Five Rings* to the younger brother of Terao Magonojo, his closest disciple. He died in Reigandō cave around June 13, 1645 (*[Shōhō](Shōhō) 2, 19th day of the 5th month*). The *Hyoho senshi denki* described his passing:

Miyamoto Musashi died of what is believed to be [cancer](thoracic)(lung cancer). He died peacefully after finishing the text *[Dokkōdō](Dokkōdō)* ("The Way of Walking Alone", or "The Way of Self-Reliance"), 21 precepts on self-discipline to guide future generations.
Miyamoto Musashi's death is believed to have been caused by cancer, specifically lung cancer.

## History

### First wave: behavior therapy roots

[[File:John Broadus Watson.JPG|thumb|[B. Watson](John)(John B. Watson)]]

Groundbreaking work of behaviorism began with [B. Watson](John)(John B. Watson) and [Rayner](Rosalie)(Rosalie Rayner)'s studies of conditioning in 1920. Behaviorally-centered therapeutic approaches appeared as early as 1924 with [Cover Jones](Mary)(Mary Cover Jones)' work dedicated to the unlearning of fears in children. These were the antecedents of the development of [Wolpe](Joseph)(Joseph Wolpe)'s behavioral therapy in the 1950s. It was the work of Wolpe and Watson, which was based on [Pavlov](Ivan)(Ivan Pavlov)'s work on learning and conditioning, that influenced [Eysenck](Hans)(Hans Eysenck) and [Lazarus](Arnold)(Arnold Lazarus) to develop new behavioral therapy techniques based on [conditioning](classical)(classical conditioning).

During the 1950s and 1960s, behavioral therapy became widely used by researchers in the United States, the United Kingdom, and South Africa. Their inspiration was by the [behaviorist](Behaviorism) learning theory of [Pavlov](Ivan)(Ivan Pavlov), [B. Watson](John)(John B. Watson), and [L. Hull](Clark)(Clark L. Hull).

In Britain, [Wolpe](Joseph)(Joseph Wolpe), who applied the findings of animal experiments to his method of [desensitization](systematic)(systematic desensitization), applied behavioral research to the treatment of neurotic disorders. Wolpe's therapeutic efforts were precursors to today's fear reduction techniques. British psychologist [Eysenck](Hans)(Hans Eysenck) presented behavior therapy as a constructive alternative.

At the same time as Eysenck's work, [F. Skinner](B.)(B. F. Skinner) and his associates were beginning to have an impact with their work on [conditioning](operant)(operant conditioning). Skinner's work was referred to as [behaviorism](radical)(radical behaviorism) and avoided anything related to cognition. However, [Rotter](Julian)(Julian Rotter) in 1954 and [Bandura](Albert)(Albert Bandura) in 1969 contributed behavior therapy with their respective work on [learning theory](social)(social learning theory) by demonstrating the effects of cognition on learning and behavior modification. The work of the Australian [Weekes](Claire)(Claire Weekes) dealing with anxiety disorders in the 1960s is also seen as a prototype of behavior therapy.

The emphasis on behavioral factors constituted the "first wave" of CBT.
John B. Watson coined the term "behaviorism" in 1913 to describe the study of observable behavior.

## Career

### Film and television roles

[[File:Charles M Robinson Director with Kevin Hart.jpg|thumb|Hart and [M. Robinson](Charles)(Charles M. Robinson (video director)) in October 2009]]

Hart came to prominence from his guest appearance in *[Undeclared](Undeclared)*. He made his film debut in the film *[Soldiers](Paper)(Paper Soldiers)*. Hart then gained further recognition from his other films such as the *[Movie](Scary)(Scary Movie (film series))* franchise, *[Plane](Soul)(Soul Plane)*, *[40-Year-Old Virgin](The)(The 40-Year-Old Virgin)*, *[at a Funeral](Death)(Death at a Funeral (2010 film))* and *[Fockers](Little)(Little Fockers)*. He turned down a role in the 2008 film *[Thunder](Tropic)(Tropic Thunder)* because the character is gay, citing his own "insecurities".

He played Doug in the film *[Five-Year Engagement](The)(The Five-Year Engagement)* (2012) and appeared in *[Like a Man](Think)(Think Like a Man)* which was a box office success. He also appeared in the [sequel](Think Like a Man Too). He had a cameo as himself in *[Is the End](This)(This Is the End)*. In 2013, Hart played a boxing promoter in *[Match](Grudge)(Grudge Match)* and appeared in *[Strategy](Exit)(Exit Strategy (film))* as Mannequin Head Man. He also appeared in *[and Ticking](35)(35 and Ticking)*.

In 2014, Hart starred as Ben in *[Along](Ride)(Ride Along (film))*, opposite [Cube](Ice)(Ice Cube). The film received generally negative reviews from critics, but was a major box office success. Hart returned in the sequel, *[Along 2](Ride)(Ride Along 2)*, which was released on January 15, 2016.

In 2013, Hart co-created *[Husbands of Hollywood](Real)(Real Husbands of Hollywood)* with [Spencer](Chris)(Chris Spencer (actor)). The show follows Hart along with other married celebrities (each playing a comical fictionalized version of themselves) within the series including: [Kodjoe](Boris)(Boris Kodjoe), [Nelly](Nelly), [Martin](Duane)(Duane Martin), [Smoove](J.B.)(J.B. Smoove), [Cannon](Nick)(Nick Cannon) and [Thicke](Robin)(Robin Thicke). Thicke did not return for the second season due to his music career, though Hart has stated that the door is open for Thicke to return. (Archive link requires scrolldown.) The series is intentionally filmed in a style similar to [Bravo](Bravo (U.S. TV channel))'s *[Real Housewives](The)(The Real Housewives)*. Episodes often hinge on the "real" Hart's desperately unsuccessful attempts to climb Hollywood's celebrity social ladder (which always backfire in humiliating ways), and the character's barely-hidden jealousy of his more successful celebrity friends. A sneak peek was shown as a segment during the [BET Awards](2012)(2012 BET Awards) and the official promo was released in October 2012.

In 2015, Hart starred in the films *[Hard](Get)(Get Hard)* with [Ferrell](Will)(Will Ferrell) and *[Wedding Ringer](The)(The Wedding Ringer)*. In 2016, he starred in the movies *[Intelligence](Central)(Central Intelligence)*, with [Johnson](Dwayne)(Dwayne Johnson) and the animated *[Secret Life of Pets](The)(The Secret Life of Pets)*. In 2017, he starred in the movies *[Underpants: The First Epic Movie](Captain)(Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie)*, in a voice role, and *[Welcome to the Jungle](Jumanji:)(Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle)* with [Black](Jack)(Jack Black), [Gillan](Karen)(Karen Gillan), and reteaming again with Johnson. He earned an estimated $32.5 million in 2017.

In 2018, he produced his first film under his production company HartBeat Productions, *[School](Night)(Night School (2018 film))*. In October 2018, it was announced that through his production company, he has signed a first-look deal with [Nickelodeon](Nickelodeon). Under the deal, Hart and his HartBeat Productions banner will develop and produce live-action, scripted kids content for the network. Hart also has a first-look film deal with [Studios](Universal)(Universal Studios).

In 2019, Hart's film *[Upside](The)(The Upside)*, his first headlining role in a drama, was theatrically released. It also starred [Cranston](Bryan)(Bryan Cranston) and [Kidman](Nicole)(Nicole Kidman). Hart also reprised his role of Snowball in the sequel *[Secret Life of Pets 2](The)(The Secret Life of Pets 2)*.

In 2021, Hart starred in *[Fatherhood](Fatherhood (film))*, a [drama](Drama (modern genre)) about a man whose wife dies shortly after childbirth, leaving him to raise their daughter on his own. It premiered on Netflix on June 18, 2021.

In 2020, his series *[Hart](Die)(Die Hart)* premiered on [Quibi](Quibi) on July 20 and had a strong first weekend, with numerous households reportedly streaming the series. On June 9, [ROKU](Roku) and Hart's multi-platform comedy brand [Out Loud](Laugh)(Laugh Out Loud Productions) debuted the series' second season on [Roku Channel](The)(The Roku Channel). In addition to returning to his starring role, Hart executive produced the second season; Laugh Out Loud CEO and Hart's longtime business partner, Jeff Clanagan, serve as a producer on the project.

Hart later played Arnold Drummond in the ''[Strokes](Diff'rent)(Diff'rent Strokes)* portion of the third edition of *[in Front of a Studio Audience](Live)(Live in Front of a Studio Audience)''.

In 2022, Hart starred alongside [Wahlberg](Mark)(Mark Wahlberg) in the comedy film, *[Time](Me)(Me Time (film))*. The movie shows how Sonny (Hart) experiences a wild journey with his friend after finding a much-longed free weekend.
The 2021 drama film starring Kevin Hart that premiered on Netflix about a man raising his daughter alone after his wife's death is *Fatherhood*.

## Ships

[[File:Ships in Bombay Harbour, 1731.jpg|thumb|right|Ships in [Harbour](Bombay)(Bombay Harbour), c. 1731]]

Ships of the East India Company were called [Indiamen](East)(East Indiaman) or simply "Indiamen".Sutton, Jean (1981) *Lords of the East: The East India Company and Its Ships*. London: Conway Maritime Their names were sometimes prefixed with the initials "HCS", standing for "Honourable Company's Service" or "Honourable Company's Ship", such as  and .

[[Royal George.jpg|thumb|right| was one of the five East Indiamen the Spanish fleet captured in 1780](File:Indiaman)]

During the [Revolutionary](French)(French Revolutionary Wars) and [Wars](Napoleonic)(Napoleonic Wars), the East India Company arranged for [of marque](letters)(Letter of marque) for its vessels such as *Lord Nelson*. This was not so that they could carry cannon to fend off warships, privateers, and pirates on their voyages to India and China (that they could do without permission) but so that, should they have the opportunity to take a prize, they could do so without being guilty of piracy. Similarly, the *Earl of Mornington*, an East India Company [ship](packet)(packet ship) of only six guns, also sailed under a letter of marque.

In addition, the company had its own navy, the [Marine](Bombay)(History of the Indian Navy), equipped with warships such as . These vessels often accompanied vessels of the Royal Navy on expeditions, such as the [of Java](Invasion)(Invasion of Java (1811)).

At the [of Pulo Aura](Battle)(Battle of Pulo Aura), which was probably the company's most notable naval victory, [Dance](Nathaniel)(Nathaniel Dance), Commodore of a convoy of Indiamen and sailing aboard the , led several Indiamen in a skirmish with a French squadron, driving them off. Some six years earlier, on 28 January 1797, five Indiamen, *Woodford*, under Captain Charles Lennox, *Taunton-Castle*, Captain Edward Studd, *Canton*, Captain Abel Vyvyan, *Boddam*, Captain George Palmer, and , Captain John Christian Lochner, had encountered Admiral [Sercey](de)(Pierre César Charles de Sercey) and his squadron of frigates. On this occasion the Indiamen succeeded in bluffing their way to safety, and without any shots even being fired. Lastly, on 15 June 1795, *General Goddard* played a large role in the capture of seven Dutch East Indiamen off [Helena](St)(Saint Helena).

[Indiamen](East)(East Indiamen) were large and strongly built and when the [Navy](Royal)(Royal Navy) was desperate for vessels to escort merchant convoys it bought several of them to convert to warships. *Earl of Mornington* became HMS *Drake*. Other examples include:

*

*

*  (1795)

*  (1804)

*

*

Their design as merchant vessels meant that their performance in the warship role was underwhelming and the Navy converted them to transports.
The East India Company’s ships were commonly called "Indiamen" or simply "East Indiamen."

## Etymology

[[van Strij - Het Jacht van de kamer Rotterdam.jpg|thumb|An 18th-century Dutch *jacht*](File:Jacob)]

The term, *yacht*, originates from the [Dutch](Dutch language) word *jacht* (pl. *jachten*, which means "hunt"), and originally referred to light, fast sailing vessels that the [Republic](Dutch)(Dutch Republic) navy used to pursue [pirate](pirate)s and other transgressors around and into the shallow waters of the [Countries](Low)(Low Countries).

The word "yacht" originates from the Dutch word *jacht*, which means "hunt." Originally, it referred to light, fast sailing vessels used by the Dutch navy to pursue pirates and other transgressors in the shallow waters of the Low Countries.

# Mamoudou Athie

*Revision ID: 1159518237 | Timestamp: 2023-06-10T21:09:59Z*

---

| birth_place        = [Mauritania](Mauritania)

| education          = [Esper Studio](William)(William Esper Studio)[University](Yale)(Yale University) ([MFA](Master of Fine Arts))

| occupation         = Actor

| years_active       = 2012–present

}}

**Mamoudou Athie** ( ; born July 25, 1988) is a Mauritanian-American actor. He is best known for starring in the 2022 [Netflix](Netflix) horror series *[81](Archive)(Archive 81)* and supporting roles in films including [World: Dominion*](*Jurassic)(Jurassic World Dominion) (2022).

Athie began his career in theater—making his [debut](Broadway)(Broadway debut) in 2015—and subsequently had supporting roles in films like *[Cake$](Patti)(Patti Cake$)* (2017), *[Circle](The)(The Circle (2017 film))* (2017), *[Store](Unicorn)(Unicorn Store)* (2017), *[Front Runner](The)(The Front Runner (film))* (2018), and *[Underwater](Underwater (film))* (2020), and in the television series *[Get Down](The)(The Get Down)* (2016–2017), [Detour*](*The)(The Detour (TV series)) (2017), *[for Your Loss](Sorry)(Sorry for Your Loss)* (2018–2019), and the [FXX](FXX) anthology [*Cake*](Cake (2019 TV series)) (2019). He had first feature film starring roles in 2020, starring in Netflix's [*Uncorked*](Uncorked (2020 film)) and Amazon's [Box*](*Black)(Black Box (2020 film)).

Athie was nominated for [Emmy Award for Outstanding Actor in a Short Form Comedy or Drama Series](Primetime)(Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Actor in a Short Form Comedy or Drama Series) for his performance in *Cake*.
Mamoudou Athie starred in the Netflix horror series *81* during 2022.

[{'section_id': 'william_wallace:william_wallace', 'section_name': 'William Wallace'}, {'section_id': 'william_wallace:background', 'section_name': 'Background'}, {'section_id': 'william_wallace:military_career', 'section_name': 'Military career'}, {'section_id': 'william_wallace:political_crisis_in_scotland', 'section_name': 'Political crisis in Scotland'}, {'section_id': 'william_wallace:silent_years_prior_to_the_wars_of_independence', 'section_name': 'Silent years prior to the Wars of Independence'}, {'section_id': 'william_wallace:start_of_the_uprising', 'section_name': 'Start of the uprising'}, {'section_id': 'william_wallace:battle_of_stirling_bridge', 'section_name': 'Battle of Stirling Bridge'}, {'section_id': 'william_wallace:battle_of_falkirk', 'section_name': 'Battle of Falkirk'}, {'section_id': 'william_wallace:capture_and_execution', 'section_name': 'Capture and execution'}, {'section_id': 'william_wallace:in_popular_culture', 'section_name': 'In popular culture'}, {'section_id': 'william_wallace:film', 'section_name': 'Film'}, {'section_id': 'william_wallace:literature', 'section_name': 'Literature'}, {'section_id': 'william_wallace:gaming', 'section_name': 'Gaming'}, {'section_id': 'william_wallace:beer', 'section_name': 'Beer'}, {'section_id': 'william_wallace:see_also', 'section_name': 'See also'}, {'section_id': 'william_wallace:references', 'section_name': 'References'}, {'section_id': 'william_wallace:bibliography', 'section_name': 'Bibliography'}, {'section_id': 'william_wallace:external_links', 'section_name': 'External links'}]

### Political crisis in Scotland

[[edinburghcastle.jpg|thumb|left|Statue of Wallace at Edinburgh Castle](File:Braveheart)]

When Wallace was growing up, King [III](Alexander)(Alexander III of Scotland) ruled Scotland. His reign had seen a period of peace and economic stability. On 19 March 1286, however, Alexander died after falling from his horse.Traquair p. 15 The heir to the throne was Alexander's granddaughter, [Maid of Norway](Margaret,)(Margaret, Maid of Norway). As she was still a child and in Norway, the Scottish lords set up a government of guardians. Margaret fell ill on the voyage to Scotland and died in Orkney in late September 1290. The lack of a clear heir led to a period known as the "Great Cause", with a total of thirteen contenders laying claim to the throne. The most credible claims were [Balliol](John)(John Balliol) and [Bruce](Robert)(Robert Bruce, 5th Lord of Annandale), grandfather of the future king [the Bruce](Robert)(Robert the Bruce).Traquair pp. 23–35

With Scotland threatening to descend into civil war, King [I of England](Edward)(Edward I of England) was invited in by the Scottish nobility to arbitrate. Before the process could begin, he insisted that all of the contenders recognise him as [Paramount of Scotland](Lord)(Lord Paramount of Scotland). In early November 1292, at a great feudal court held in the castle at [Berwick-upon-Tweed](Berwick-upon-Tweed), judgment was given in favour of [Balliol](John)(John Balliol) having the strongest claim in law based on being senior in genealogical [primogeniture](primogeniture) even though not in [of blood](proximity)(proximity of blood).

Edward proceeded to take steps to progressively undermine John's authority, treating [Scotland](Scotland) as a feudal vassal state, demanding [homage](Homage (feudal)) be paid towards himself and military support in his war against France — even summoning King John Balliol to stand before the English court as a common plaintiff. The Scots soon tired of their deeply compromised king, and the direction of affairs was allegedly taken out of his hands by the leading men of the kingdom, who appointed a Council of Twelve—in practice, a new panel of Guardians—at [Stirling](Stirling) in July 1295. They went on to conclude a treaty of mutual assistance with France—known in later years as the [Alliance](Auld)(Auld Alliance).

In retaliation for Scotland's treaty with France, Edward I invaded, storming Berwick-upon-Tweed and commencing the [of Scottish Independence](Wars)(Wars of Scottish Independence). The Scots were defeated at [Dunbar](Battle of Dunbar (1296)) and the English took [Castle](Dunbar)(Dunbar Castle) on 27 April 1296. Edward forced John to abdicate, which he did at [Stracathro](Stracathro) near [Montrose](Montrose, Angus) on 10 July 1296.Dunbar, Sir Archibald H., Bt., *Scottish Kings – A Revised Chronology of Scottish History 1005–1625*, Edinburgh, 1899: p. 116 Here the arms of Scotland were formally torn from John's surcoat, giving him the abiding name of "Toom Tabard" (empty coat). By July, Edward had instructed his officers to receive formal homage from some 1,800 Scottish nobles (many of the rest being prisoners of war at that time).Traquair pp. 15–59
## Military career

### Start of the uprising

[[File:William Wallace statue, Scottish National Portrait Gallery, Edinburgh.JPG|thumb|upright|Wallace statue by D. W. Stevenson on the Scottish National Portrait Gallery, [Edinburgh](Edinburgh)]]

The first act definitely known to have been carried out by Wallace was his [of William de Heselrig](killing)(Action at Lanark), the English High Sheriff of Lanark, in May 1297. He then joined with [the Hardy, Lord of Douglas](William)(William the Hardy, Lord of Douglas), and they carried out the [of Scone](raid)(raid of Scone). This was one of several rebellions taking place across Scotland, including those of several Scottish nobles and [Moray](Andrew)(Andrew Moray) in the north.Traquair pp.63–67

The uprising suffered a blow when the nobles submitted to the English at [Irvine](Irvine, Scotland) in July. Wallace and Moray were not involved, and continued their rebellions. Wallace used the [Forest](Ettrick)(Selkirkshire) as a base for raiding, and attacked [Wishart](Robert Wishart)'s palace at [Ancrum](Ancrum). Wallace and Moray met and joined their forces, possibly at the siege of Dundee in early September.Traquair pp. 70–73

William Wallace served as a leader of the Scottish resistance during the Wars of Scottish Independence from 1297 to 1298. His primary role during this period was that of a military commander and national hero, leading rebellions against English rule. He played a key part in organizing resistance, including the raid on Scone and the Battle of Stirling Bridge, which marked a significant early victory for the Scottish cause.

## Television, film, and pop culture

Over the years, List and his crimes have furnished inspiration for documentaries, television dramas and feature films. Examples include "Savior," the season 6, episode 16 of the television series *[& Order](Law)(Law & Order)*; the 1987 film *[Stepfather](The)(The Stepfather (1987 film))* and its [remake](2009)(The Stepfather (2009 film)); the 1993 film *[Day: The John List Story](Judgment)(Judgment Day: The John List Story)*, in which List was portrayed by [Blake](Robert)(Robert Blake (actor)); and the character [Söze](Keyser)(Keyser Söze) in the 1995 film *[Usual Suspects](The)(The Usual Suspects)*.*The Usual Suspects* DVD commentary featuring [Singer](Bryan)(Bryan Singer) and [McQuarrie](Christopher)(Christopher McQuarrie), [2000]. Retrieved September 27, 2002.

In 2008, [Walsh](John)(John Walsh (television host)), the host of ''America's Most Wanted'', donated the age-progressed bust by Frank Bender that played a pivotal role in List's apprehension to a forensic science exhibit at the [Museum of Crime & Punishment](National)(National Museum of Crime & Punishment) in [D.C.](Washington,)(Washington, D.C.), whose collection was later moved to [East](Alcatraz)(Alcatraz East) Crime Museum in [Forge, Tennessee](Pigeon)(Pigeon Forge, Tennessee).

A 1996 episode of the series *[Files](Forensic)(Forensic Files)* discussed the List murders. A 2003 episode of the [A&E](A&E (TV channel)) series *[Justice](American)(American Justice)* also detailed the case and featured an interview with List. In 2015, the story was covered in the season 2, episode 2 of the [Discovery](Investigation)(Investigation Discovery) TV series *[Worst Nightmare](Your)(Your Worst Nightmare)*. The episode, "Murder House", premiered on November 18, 2015.

The movie *A Killer Next Door*, based on the events that led to the capture of John List, was released In July 2020.

In 2022, NJ Advance Media released "Father Wants Us Dead," a podcast serial on the events.

Also in 2022, [Netflix](Netflix) released a seven-part dramatic fictional miniseries called *[Watcher](The)(The Watcher (2022 TV series))*. Although it is a work of fiction, much of the character John Graff was borrowed from the story of the John List murders.Nolfi, Joey (2022-10-14). ["The Watcher's Grisly John Graff Murder Sequence Is Based on True Story of a Family Massacre."](https://ew.com/tv/the-watcher-john-graff-true-story-john-list-family-murders/) *[Weekly](Entertainment)(Entertainment Weekly)*. Retrieved 2022-10-20.  Played by [Mantello](Joe)(Joe Mantello), much of John Graff's story was identical such as his being an accountant, attending a Lutheran church, and murdering his family members and live-in mother, along with leaving music playing in the house and planning an alibi that would cause the bodies to remain undiscovered for several weeks.

John List Society are a band from Atlanta, GA who play "Punk / hardcore songs about serial killers" https://www.instagram.com/johnlistsociety/

The television program that featured an age-progressed bust helping lead to John List's capture was *America's Most Wanted*. John Walsh, the host of the show, donated the bust to a forensic science exhibit, highlighting its pivotal role in List's apprehension.

# Joe Pesci

*Revision ID: 1159548641 | Timestamp: 2023-06-11T01:42:52Z*

---

| birth_place        = [New Jersey](Newark,)(Newark, New Jersey), U.S.

**Joseph Frank Pesci** ( , ; born February 9, 1943) is an American actor and musician. He is known for portraying tough, volatile characters in a variety of genres and for his collaborations with [De Niro](Robert)(Robert De Niro) and [Scorsese](Martin)(Martin Scorsese) in the films *[Bull](Raging)(Raging Bull)* (1980), *[Goodfellas](Goodfellas)* (1990), *[Casino](Casino (1995 film))* (1995), and *[Irishman](The)(The Irishman)* (2019). He also appeared in *[Upon a Time in America](Once)(Once Upon a Time in America)* (1984), *[Moonwalker](Moonwalker)* (1988), *[JFK](JFK (film))* (1991), *[Bronx Tale](A)(A Bronx Tale)* (1993), and *[Good Shepherd](The)(The Good Shepherd (film))* (2006). Pesci's comedy roles include such films as the first two installments in the *[Alone](Home)(Home Alone (franchise))* franchise (1990–1992), *[Cousin Vinny](My)(My Cousin Vinny)* (1992), and the [Weapon* franchise](*Lethal)(Lethal Weapon (franchise)) (1989–1998).

Pesci won the [Award for Best Supporting Actor](Academy)(Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor) for his role as the gangster character [DeVito](Tommy)(Thomas DeSimone) in *Goodfellas* and received two other nominations in the same category for his portrayals of [LaMotta](Joey)(Joey LaMotta) and [Bufalino](Russell)(Russell Bufalino) in *Raging Bull* and *The Irishman*, respectively. He announced his retirement from acting in 1999, but has returned to act in four films since then.

Pesci is also a musician who has recorded three studio albums: *Little Joe Sure Can Sing!* (1968), *[LaGuardia Gambini Sings Just for You](Vincent)(Vincent LaGuardia Gambini Sings Just for You)* (1998), and *Pesci... Still Singing* (2019).
## Career

### Early career

In the 1960s, Pesci began working as a barber, following in his mother's footsteps. At the same time, he tried to start a musical career, playing guitar with several bands, including [Dee and the Starliters](Joey)(Joey Dee and the Starliters) who introduced the "[Twist](Peppermint)(Peppermint Twist)" record, dance, and Peppermint Lounge in New York City.

In 1968, he released his debut album *Little Joe Sure Can Sing!* (billed as *Joe Ritchie*), on which he sang covers of contemporary pop hits.

Pesci later joined [Vincent](Frank)(Frank Vincent) as a [duo](comedy)(Double act), performing as "Vincent and Pesci" from 1970 to 1976. Their act coupled [and Costello](Abbott)(Abbott and Costello)-inspired double act antics with [Rickles](Don)(Don Rickles)-style [comedy](insult)(insult comedy), which proved popular with crowds. During this time, both men developed a strong professional and personal friendship with one another. In 1975, they appeared in the Broadway show *The New Vaudevillians*, which only lasted one week.

The first film Pesci starred in was the 1976 [low-budget](Low-budget film) [film](crime)(crime film) *[Death Collector](The)(The Death Collector)* alongside Frank Vincent. After the film Pesci returned to The Bronx and lived above Amici's Restaurant, where he was an employee.

### Acting career

[[File:Cathy Moriarty and Joe Pesci, 1980.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.9|Pesci with co-star [Moriarty](Cathy)(Cathy Moriarty) on the set of *[Bull](Raging)(Raging Bull)*.]]

In 1979, Pesci received a telephone call from [Scorsese](Martin)(Martin Scorsese) and Robert De Niro, who were impressed with his performance in *The Death Collector* and asked him to co-star in Scorsese's *[Bull](Raging)(Raging Bull)* as [LaMotta](Joey)(Joey LaMotta). During the course of filming Pesci broke one of his ribs.

Pesci won the [Film Award for Newcomer to Leading Film Roles](BAFTA)(BAFTA Film Award for Newcomer to Leading Film Roles) in 1981 and was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor. Over the next few years, Pesci appeared in several smaller films, including *[Mr. Wonderful](Dear)(Dear Mr. Wonderful)* (1982), *[Eureka](Eureka (1983 film))* (1983) and *[Money](Easy)(Easy Money (1983 film))* (1983).

In 1984, he was cast in *[Upon a Time in America](Once)(Once Upon a Time in America)*, again appearing alongside De Niro. The following year he starred as private detective Rocky Nelson in the short-lived television comedy series *[Nelson](Half)(Half Nelson (TV series))*.

In 1988, Pesci appeared in the [Jackson](Michael)(Michael Jackson) musical anthology film *[Moonwalker](Moonwalker)*, in the film's sixth and longest segment, "[Criminal](Smooth)(Smooth Criminal)." He played the antagonist, crime boss Frankie "Mr. Big" LiDeo (an anagram for one of the film's producers and longtime Jackson manager [DiLeo](Frank)(Frank DiLeo), with whom Pesci later acted in *Goodfellas*).

He appeared as Leo Getz, a comedic sidekick and best friend to protagonist detectives Martin Riggs ([Gibson](Mel)(Mel Gibson)) and Roger Murtaugh ([Glover](Danny)(Danny Glover)) in the *[Weapon](Lethal)(Lethal Weapon (franchise))* sequels, released in [1989](Lethal Weapon 2), [1992](Lethal Weapon 3) and [1998](Lethal Weapon 4).

In 1990, he reunited with Scorsese and De Niro for *[Goodfellas](Goodfellas)*, in which he played mobster Tommy DeVito, based on real-life mobster [DeSimone](Thomas)(Thomas DeSimone) (Tommy DeVito also being the name of Pesci's old acquaintance from Belleville, New Jersey, and a member of The Four Seasons, but contrary to popular belief, the naming is coincidental). Pesci's old friend [Vincent](Frank)(Frank Vincent) also appears in the film. Pesci's character kills Vincent's character in a rage in one of the best-remembered scenes in the film after the Vincent character contemptuously tells him to "go home and get your fucking shine box." According to Pesci, improvisation and ad-libbing came out of rehearsals wherein Scorsese let the actors do whatever they wanted. He made transcripts of these sessions, took the lines the actors came up with that he liked best, and put them into a revised script that the cast worked from during principal photography.

For example, the scene where Tommy tells a story and Henry is responding to him—the "Funny how? Do I amuse you?" scene—is based on an actual event that Pesci experienced. Pesci was working as a waiter when he thought he was making a compliment to a mobster by saying he was "funny"; however, the comment was not taken well. It was worked on in rehearsals where he and Liotta improvised, and Scorsese recorded four to five takes, rewrote their dialogue, and inserted it into the script. The dinner scene with Tommy's mother was largely improvised. Pesci received the [Award for Best Supporting Actor](Academy)(Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor) for the role, which he accepted with one of the shortest speeches in Oscar history, saying simply, "It's my privilege. Thank you" before leaving the stage.

Pesci also co-starred in the blockbuster *[Alone](Home)(Home Alone)* in 1990, playing Harry Lyme, one of two bumbling burglars (along with good friend [Stern](Daniel)(Daniel Stern (actor))) who attempt to burgle the house of the young character played by [Culkin](Macaulay)(Macaulay Culkin). Pesci's use of "cartoon cursing," or menacing gibberish, garnered comparisons to *[Tunes](Looney)(Looney Tunes)* character [Sam](Yosemite)(Yosemite Sam). Two years later, Pesci reprised his role in the sequel *[Alone 2: Lost in New York](Home)(Home Alone 2: Lost in New York)*.

In 1991, Pesci played [Ferrie](David)(David Ferrie) in *[JFK](JFK (film))*. In 1992, he appeared as the title character in the comedy *[Cousin Vinny](My)(My Cousin Vinny)* with [Macchio](Ralph)(Ralph Macchio), [Tomei](Marisa)(Marisa Tomei) and [Gwynne](Fred)(Fred Gwynne). During the same year Pesci headed up the cast of *[Public Eye](The)(The Public Eye (film))* as Leon "Bernzy" Bernstein, a photographer. His performance in the film, a departure from his usual characters, has been critically acclaimed.

Pesci hosted the sketch comedy show *[Night Live](Saturday)(Saturday Night Live)* on October 10, 1992, while doing publicity for *My Cousin Vinny*. During his monologue, he restored a picture of [John Paul II](Pope)(Pope John Paul II) that had been torn by [O'Connor](Sinéad)(Sinéad O'Connor) on the previous broadcast.

In 1993, Pesci made an appearance in *[Bronx Tale](A)(A Bronx Tale)* as Carmine. The film starred Robert De Niro, who also directed, and [Palminteri](Chazz)(Chazz Palminteri), who wrote the play from which the film was adapted. Both De Niro and Palminteri personally offered Pesci the role. In 1995, Pesci had his third collaboration with Scorsese and De Niro in the film *[Casino](Casino (1995 film))*, playing Nicky Santoro, based on real-life Mob enforcer [Spilotro](Anthony)(Anthony Spilotro), along with [Stone](Sharon)(Sharon Stone) and [Woods](James)(James Woods); Pesci had previously co-starred with the latter in *Once Upon a Time in America*. During filming, Pesci broke the same rib that had been broken 15 years prior during the production of *[Bull](Raging)(Raging Bull)*. In 1996, Pesci was considered to play Myron Larabee, the stressed-out postman, in *[All the Way](Jingle)(Jingle All the Way)* opposite [Schwarzenegger](Arnold)(Arnold Schwarzenegger), but the part was ultimately given to [Sinbad](Sinbad (entertainer)), whose physical size was more comparable to Schwarzenegger's.

He had starring roles in several other films, including *[on Fire](Man)(Man on Fire (1987 film))* (1987), *[Super](The)(The Super (1991 film))* (1991), *[Hollywood](Jimmy)(Jimmy Hollywood)* (1994), *[Honors](With)(With Honors (film))* (also 1994) and ''[Fishin'](Gone)(Gone Fishin' (film))'' (1997). Pesci's role in *With Honors* was a dramatic role in which he played a homeless man living on the campus of Harvard.
Joe Pesci played one of two bumbling burglars named Harry Lyme in the 1990 comedy film *Home Alone*.

### 2010s: Ireland headquarters

Accenture announced on 26 May 2009 that its board of directors unanimously approved changing the company's place of incorporation from [Bermuda](Bermuda) to [Ireland](Ireland) and would become **Accenture plc**.

In 2012, it was revealed Accenture was paying only 3.5% in tax in the Republic of Ireland as opposed to the average rate of 24% it would pay if instead based in the UK.

In January 2014, Accenture was chosen to replace [Group](CGI)(CGI Group) as the lead contractor for [HealthCare.gov](HealthCare.gov), signing a $563 million contract to provide ongoing maintenance, software development and technology support for HealthCare.gov through 2019.

In April 2014, Accenture acquired i4C Analytics, an advanced analytics software platform provider based in Italy that specialized in helping clients solve complex business problems through easy to use analytics applications.

In July 2015, the United States Department of Defense awarded a major [Health Records](Electronic)(Electronic Health Records) contract to [Cerner](Cerner), [Leidos](Leidos) and Accenture. The contract valued $4.33 billion will serve 55 hospitals and 600 clinics. Accenture Federal Services and Leidos will play the role of configuration specialist, while Cerner is the prime contractor. In 2015, the company had about 150,000 employees in [India](India), 48,000 in the [US](US), and 50,000 in the [Philippines](Philippines).

On 29 August 2017, [Inc.](Apple)(Apple Inc.) announced a partnership with Accenture to create [iOS](iOS) business software.

In June 2018, Accenture generated controversy over the amount the firm has been charging to recruit 7,500 [and Border Protection](Customs)(U.S. Customs and Border Protection) officers. Under the $297 million contract, Accenture had been charging the US Government nearly $40,000 per hire, which is more than the annual salary of the average officer.  According to a report published by the DHS Office of Inspector General in December 2018, Accenture had been paid $13.6M through the first ten months of the contract. They had hired two agents against a contract goal of 7,500 hires over 5 years. The report was issued as a 'management alert', indicating an issue requiring immediate attention, stating that "Accenture has already taken longer to deploy and delivered less capability than promised". The contract was terminated in 2019.

In January 2019, CEO Pierre Nanterme stepped down from his position, citing health reasons. Twenty days after stepping down, he died in France at the age of 59 after being diagnosed with colon cancer. Chief Financial Officer David Rowland was named as the interim CEO. In July 2019, [Sweet](Julie)(Julie Sweet), previously CEO of Accenture North America, was named the new chief executive officer of the firm, effective September 2019. In February 2019, [contractors](Independent contractor) from Accenture's [Texas](Austin,)(Austin, Texas), location who performed [moderation](content)(content moderation) tasks for [Facebook](Facebook) wrote an [letter](open)(open letter) to Facebook describing poor working conditions and a "[Brother](Big)(Big Brother (Nineteen Eighty-Four)) environment" that included restricted [breaks](work)(Break (work)) and strict [agreement](non-disclosure)(non-disclosure agreement)s. A counselor in the Austin office stated that the content moderators could develop [stress disorder](posttraumatic)(posttraumatic stress disorder) as a result of the work, which included evaluating videos and images containing [violence](graphic)(graphic violence), [speech](hate)(hate speech), [abuse](animal)(animal abuse), and [abuse](child)(child abuse). Accenture issued a statement saying the company offers opportunities for moderators to advance, increase their wages, and provide input "to help shape their experience".
Accenture plc is headquartered in Dublin, Ireland.

## Etymology

The term *Khmers rouges*, [French](French language) for [red](Political colour#Red) [Khmers](Khmer people), was coined by King Norodom Sihanouk and later adopted by English speakers (in the form of the corrupted version Khmer Rouge). It was used to refer to a succession of communist parties in Cambodia which evolved into the Communist Party of Kampuchea and later the [of Democratic Kampuchea](Party)(Party of Democratic Kampuchea). Its military was known successively as the [Revolutionary Army](Kampuchean)(Kampuchean Revolutionary Army) and the [Army of Democratic Kampuchea](National)(National Army of Democratic Kampuchea).

Since the serious deterioration in relations between [Republic of Vietnam](Socialist)(Socialist Republic of Vietnam) and [Kampuchea](Democratic)(Democratic Kampuchea), the [communism](Vietnamese)(Communist Party of Vietnam) authority no longer recognize the legitimacy of Khmer Rouge, and calls it **Pol Pot-Ieng Sary group** () or **Pol Pot-Ieng Sary reactionary group** ().
The term "Khmer Rouge" was coined by King Norodom Sihanouk in the 1960s.

## Early life

Kiernan Brennan Shipka was born in [Chicago](Chicago), [Illinois](Illinois), to John Young Shipka, a real estate developer, and Erin Ann Brennan. Shipka started taking [dancing](ballroom)(ballroom dancing) classes at the age of five, and was still attending classes as of March 2012. Her family relocated to [Angeles](Los)(Los Angeles), [California](California) when she was six to help with her acting career.

# Richard Linklater

*Revision ID: 1147782455 | Timestamp: 2023-04-02T04:18:18Z*

---

| children      = 3, including [Lorelei](Lorelei Linklater)

| notable_works = *[Boyhood](Boyhood (2014 film))*, *[and Confused](Dazed)(Dazed and Confused (film))*, *[trilogy](Before)(Before trilogy)*, *[of Rock](School)(School of Rock)*, *[Life](Waking)(Waking Life)*, *[Slacker](Slacker (film))*

| website       =

}}

**Richard Stuart Linklater** (; born July 30, 1960)According to the State of Texas. *Texas Birth Index, 1903–1997*. At Ancestry.com is an American film director, producer, and screenwriter. He is known for films that revolve mainly around [culture](suburban)(Suburb) and the effects of the [of time](passage)(Time). His films include the comedies *[Slacker](Slacker (film))* (1990) and *[and Confused](Dazed)(Dazed and Confused (film))* (1993); the [trilogy](*Before*)(Before trilogy) of [romance](Romance film) films, *[Sunrise](Before)(Before Sunrise)* (1995), *[Sunset](Before)(Before Sunset)* (2004), and *[Midnight](Before)(Before Midnight (2013 film))* (2013); the music-themed comedy *[of Rock](School)(School of Rock)* (2003); the [animated](adult)(adult animated) films *[Life](Waking)(Waking Life)* (2001), *[Scanner Darkly](A)(A Scanner Darkly (film))* (2006), and *[10 1⁄2: A Space Age Childhood](Apollo)(Apollo 10 1⁄2: A Space Age Childhood)* (2022); the coming-of-age drama *[Boyhood](Boyhood (2014 film))* (2014); and the comedy film *[Wants Some!!](Everybody)(Everybody Wants Some!! (film))* (2016).

Linklater is known to have a distinct style and method of filmmaking. Many of his films are noted for their loosely structured narrative. The *Before* trilogy and *Boyhood* both feature the same actors filmed over an extended period of years. He has received several [Award](Academy)(Academy Awards) nominations and won the [Bear for Best Director](Silver)(Silver Bear for Best Director) at the [International Film Festival](Berlin)(Berlin International Film Festival) for his work on *Before Sunrise*. He also won a [Globe Award](Golden)(Golden Globe Award for Best Director) for directing *Boyhood*. In 2015, Linklater was included on the annual [100 list of the most influential people in the world](*Time*)(Time 100).

### 1985–2000: Early directing

Linklater founded the [Film Society](Austin)(Austin Film Society) in 1985 with his college professor Chale Nafus, [of Texas](University)(University of Texas at Austin) professor Charles Ramirez-Berg, [SXSW](South by Southwest) founder [Black](Louis)(Louis Black), and his frequent collaborator [Daniel](Lee)(Lee Daniel). One of the mentors for the Film Society was former New York City critic for the *[Weekly News](SoHo)(SoHo Weekly News)* George Morris, who had relocated to Austin and taught film there.

For several years, Linklater made many short films that were exercises and experiments in film techniques. He finally completed his first feature, ''[Impossible to Learn to Plow by Reading Books](It's)(It's Impossible to Learn to Plow by Reading Books)* (which is available in [Criterion Collection](The)(The Criterion Collection) edition of his second feature, *[Slacker](Slacker (film))*), a Super-8 feature that took a year to shoot and another year to edit.

Linklater created Detour Filmproduction (an homage to the [low budget](1945)(Detour (1945 film)) [noir](film)(film noir) by [G. Ulmer](Edgar)(Edgar G. Ulmer)), and subsequently made *Slacker* for only $23,000. It went on to gross more than $1.25 million. The film shows an aimless day in the life of the city of Austin, Texas showcasing its more eccentric characters.

While gaining a cult following in the [film](independent)(independent film) world, he made his third film, *[and Confused](Dazed)(Dazed and Confused (film))*, based on his years at Huntsville High School and the people he encountered there. The film garnered critical praise and grossed $8 million in the United States while becoming a hit on VHS. This film was also responsible for the breakout of fellow Texas native [McConaughey](Matthew)(Matthew McConaughey).

In 1995, Linklater won the [Bear for Best Director](Silver)(Silver Bear for Best Director) for the film *[Sunrise](Before)(Before Sunrise)* at the [Berlin International Film Festival](45th)(45th Berlin International Film Festival). His next feature, *[subUrbia](subUrbia (film))*, had mixed reviews critically, and did very poorly at the box office. In 1998, he took on his first Hollywood feature, *[Newton Boys](The)(The Newton Boys)*, which received mixed reviews while tanking at the box office.
The filmmaker who used the PXL2000 in his 1991 debut film *Slacker* is Richard Linklater.
