**James Oliver Cromwell** (born January 27, 1940) is an American actor and activist. Known for his extensive work as a [actor](character)(character actor), he has received a [Emmy Award](Primetime)(Primetime Emmy Award) as well a nomination for the [Award for Best Supporting Actor](Academy)(Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor) for *[Babe](Babe (film))* (1995). Other notable roles include in *[Trek: First Contact](Star)(Star Trek: First Contact)* (1996), *[Confidential](L.A.)(L.A. Confidential (film))* (1997), *[Green Mile](The)(The Green Mile (film))* (1999), *[Queen](The)(The Queen (2006 film))* (2006), *[W.](W. (film))* (2008), *[Secretariat](Secretariat (film))* (2010), *[Artist](The)(The Artist (film))* (2011), *[Mine](Still)(Still Mine)* (2013), and *[Marshall](Marshall (film))* (2017).["Canadian Screen Awards raises the star wattage"](https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/movies/2013/03/03/canadian_screen_awards_raises_the_star_wattage.html) . *[Star](Toronto)(Toronto Star)*, March 3, 2013. He has also voiced roles in *[Stallion of the Cimarron](Spirit:)(Spirit: Stallion of the Cimarron)* (2002), and *[Hero 6](Big)(Big Hero 6 (film))* (2014).

Cromwell is also well known for his roles in television including *[in America](Angels)(Angels_in_America_(miniseries))* (2003), *[Feet Under](Six)(Six Feet Under (TV series))* (2003–2005), *[Horror Story: Asylum](American)(American Horror Story: Asylum)* (2012–2013), *[Empire](Boardwalk)(Boardwalk Empire (season 3))* (2012-2013), *[Young Pope](The)(The Young Pope)* (2016), *[Succession](Succession (TV series))* (2018–2023), and *[Counterpart](Counterpart (TV series))* (2018–2019). He won the [Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Limited Series or Movie](Primetime)(Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Miniseries or a Movie) for his role in *[Horror Story: Asylum](American)(American Horror Story: Asylum)* (2012).

## Career

Cromwell's first television performance was in a 1974 episode of *[Rockford Files](The)(The Rockford Files)* playing Terry, a tennis instructor. A few weeks later, he began a recurring role as Stretch Cunningham on *[in the Family](All)(All in the Family)*. In 1975, he took his first lead role on television as Bill Lewis in the short-lived *[l Baltimore](Hot)(Hot l Baltimore)*, and appeared on *[M*A*S*H](M*A*S*H (TV series))* as Captain Leo Bardonaro in the episode "Last Laugh". A year later, he made his film debut in [Simon](Neil)(Neil Simon)'s classic detective spoof *[by Death](Murder)(Murder by Death)*. Cromwell portrayed four different characters in four episodes of *[Miller](Barney)(Barney Miller)* (1977-1981).

In 1977 he appeared in [Company](Three's)(Three's Company) episode- "Chrissy's Night Out" as Detective Lannigan.

In 1980, Cromwell guest-starred in the two-part episode "Laura Ingalls Wilder" of the long-running television series *[House on the Prairie](Little)(Little House on the Prairie (TV series))*. He played Harve Miller, one of Almanzo Wilder's old friends.

While Cromwell continued with regular television work throughout the 1980s, he made appearances in films with supporting roles in *[Tank](Tank (film))* and *[of the Nerds](Revenge)(Revenge of the Nerds)* (both 1984). He guest starred on the sitcom *[Court](Night)(Night Court)*, playing a mental patient, along with [Peter Hall](Kevin)(Kevin Peter Hall). He had starring roles in the critically acclaimed films *[Babe](Babe (film))* (1995), *[People vs. Larry Flynt](The)(The People vs. Larry Flynt)* (1996), *[Education of Little Tree](The)(The Education of Little Tree (film))* (1997), *[Confidential](L.A.)(L.A. Confidential (film))* (1997), *[Green Mile](The)(The Green Mile (film))* (1999), ''[General's Daughter](The)(The General's Daughter (film))*, (1999) and *[Falling on Cedars](Snow)(Snow Falling on Cedars (film))'' (1999). Cromwell's first *[Trek](Star)(Star Trek)* role was on *[Trek: The Next Generation](Star)(Star Trek: The Next Generation)* in 1990, in the season 3 episode "[Hunted](The)(The Hunted (Star Trek: The Next Generation))", followed by the 1993 episode "[Part 1](Birthright,)(Birthright (Star Trek: The Next Generation))" as Jaglom Shrek. He also played Dr. [Cochrane](Zefram)(Zefram Cochrane) in *[Trek: First Contact](Star)(Star Trek: First Contact)* (1996), the *[Trek: Enterprise](Star)(Star Trek: Enterprise)* pilot episode "[Bow](Broken)(Broken Bow (Star Trek: Enterprise))", and the 2022 *[Trek: Lower Decks](Star)(Star Trek: Lower Decks)* season 3 premiere episode, "Grounded". The *Star Trek: Enterprise* episode "[a Mirror, Darkly](In)(In a Mirror, Darkly)" reused some of the *First Contact* footage. Cromwell appeared in another *Star Trek* role on the television series *[Space Nine](Deep)(Deep Space Nine)*, in the episode "[Down](Starship)(Starship Down)" as Hanok. He also voiced the Colonel in [DreamWorks](DreamWorks Animation)' *[Stallion of the Cimarron](Spirit:)(Spirit: Stallion of the Cimarron)*.

Cromwell's role as newspaper tycoon [Randolph Hearst](William)(William Randolph Hearst) in the television film *[281](RKO)(RKO 281)* earned him an [Award nomination for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Television Movie](Emmy)(Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor – Miniseries or a Movie). The following year, he received his second Emmy Award nomination for playing Bishop Lionel Stewart on the [NBC](NBC) medical drama series *[ER](ER (TV series))*. In 2004, he guest-starred as former President D. Wire Newman in *[West Wing](The)(The West Wing)* episode "[Stormy Present](The)(The Stormy Present)". From 2003 to 2005, Cromwell played [Sibley](George)(George Sibley (Six Feet Under)) in the [HBO](HBO) drama series *[Feet Under](Six)(Six Feet Under (TV series))*, which earned him his third Emmy Award nomination in 2003. Along with the rest of his castmates, he was also nominated for two [Actors Guild Awards for Best Ensemble in a Drama Series](Screen)(Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by an Ensemble in a Drama Series) in 2005 and 2006. The following year, Cromwell played [Philip, Duke of Edinburgh](Prince)(Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh) in *[Queen](The)(The Queen (2006 film))* (2006), that earned [Mirren](Helen)(Helen Mirren) an [Award for Best Actress](Academy)(Academy Award for Best Actress). He also guest starred as [Bauer](Phillip)(List of 24 characters#Phillip Bauer), father of lead character [Jack](Jack Bauer), in the [season](sixth)(24 (season 6)) of the [Fox](Fox Broadcasting Company) thriller drama series *[24](24 (TV series))*.

In October 2007, Cromwell played the lead role of James Tyrone Sr. in the [Theatre Company](Druid)(Druid Theatre Company)'s production of [O'Neill](Eugene)(Eugene O'Neill)'s ''[Day's Journey into Night](Long)(Long Day's Journey into Night)'', at the [in Dublin](Gaiety)(Gaiety Theatre, Dublin) as part of the [Bank Dublin Theatre Festival's](Ulster)(Dublin Theatre Festival) 50th Anniversary.[Gaiety Theatre Dublin, Ireland – Irish Theatre](http://www.gaietytheatre.ie/shows/LongDaysJourneyIntoNight.htm)  That same year he received the King Vidor Memorial Award from the [Luis Obispo International Film Festival](San)(San Luis Obispo International Film Festival) for his artistic achievements in film. Cromwell played [H. W. Bush](George)(George H. W. Bush) in [Stone](Oliver)(Oliver Stone)'s *[W.](W. (film))* (2008), that chronicles the rise to power of [son](Bush's)(George W. Bush) up until the [invasion of Iraq](2003)(2003 invasion of Iraq). Cromwell also provided the voice of the main villain Professor Robert Callaghan/Yokai in the Disney movie *[Hero 6](Big)(Big Hero 6 (film))*.

In 2015, Cromwell executive produced the documentary *[Threat](Imminent)(Imminent Threat)* which tackles the War on Terror's impact on civil liberties.

In 2016 Cromwell starred in [HBO](HBO)'s series *[Young Pope](The)(The Young Pope)* alongside [Law](Jude)(Jude Law) and [Keaton](Diane)(Diane Keaton). In 2018, he appeared in [HBO](HBO)'s *[Succession](Succession (TV series))*, and [Starz](Starz)'s *[Counterpart](Counterpart (TV series))*.

In 2020, Cromwell starred in the Australian comedy-drama film *[Too Late](Never)(Never Too Late (2020 film))*.Maddox, Garry (16 April 2019) [Life is still busy over 70 for stars of new 'triumph over ageing' film](https://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/movies/life-is-still-busy-over-70-for-stars-of-new-triumph-over-ageing-film-20190408-p51bxg.html), *[Sydney Morning Herald](The)(The Sydney Morning Herald)*. Retrieved 20 February 2020. Cromwell starred in *[Buffalo](Operation)(Operation Buffalo (TV series))*, an Australian television comedy-drama series about the atomic bomb tests in outback Australia, which screened on [ABC](ABC TV (Australian TV network)) from 31 May 2020.

He is currently featured in the [Max](HBO)(HBO Max) show *[Julia](Julia (2022 TV series))*, as Julia Child's father, John McWilliams.

In 2021, Cromwell executive produced the psychedelic comedy *[Hollywoodland](Mondo)(Mondo Hollywoodland)*, directed by Janek Ambros, who also directed *Imminent Threat*.
James Cromwell played the character George Sibley in the television series *Six Feet Under*.

## Early life

He was born Alfredo Molina on 24 May 1953 in the [Paddington](Paddington) district of London. His father, Esteban J. Molina, was a Spanish immigrant from [Murcia](Murcia), who came to England in 1939, and worked as a waiter and chauffeur. His mother, Giovanna (née Bonelli), was an Italian immigrant who moved to Britain after [War II](World)(World War II), and who cleaned rooms in a hotel, and worked as a cook and housekeeper. Molina grew up in a working-class district in [Hill](Notting)(Notting Hill) that was inhabited by many other immigrant families. He attended a Roman Catholic secondary school there. He decided to become an actor after seeing *[Spartacus](Spartacus (film))* at the age of nine, and attended the [School of Music and Drama](Guildhall)(Guildhall School of Music and Drama), as well as auditioning for and becoming a member of the [Youth Theatre](National)(National Youth Theatre). At the age of 21, he changed his name to Alfred, at the urging of his first agent.
Alfred Molina attended the Guildhall School of Music and Drama.

# Rock and roll

*Revision ID: 1159956168 | Timestamp: 2023-06-13T16:05:15Z*

---

early 1950s, Southern United States

| derivatives       = * [Rock](Rock music)

* [beat](Beat music)

* [pop](Pop music)

| regional_scenes   = *[Kingdom](United)(British rock and roll)

| other_topics      = *[of rock and roll](Origins)(Origins of rock and roll)

*[of artists](list)(List of rock and roll artists)

}}

**Rock and roll** (often written as **rock & roll**, '''rock 'n' roll**, or **rock n roll''') is a [genre](Genre (music)) of [music](popular)(popular music) that evolved in the United States during the late 1940s and early 1950s. It [originated](Origins of rock and roll) from African-American music such as [jazz](jazz), [and blues](rhythm)(rhythm and blues), [boogie-woogie](boogie-woogie), [gospel](gospel music), [blues](jump)(jump blues), as well as [music](country)(country music).Larry Birnbaum, ''Before Elvis: The Prehistory of Rock 'n' Roll'', Scarecrow Press, 2013, p.vii-x. While rock and roll's formative elements can be heard in blues records from the 1920sDavis, Francis. *[History of the Blues](The)(iarchive:historyofblues00davi)* (New York: Hyperion, 1995), . and in country records of the 1930s,Peterson, Richard A. *[Creating Country Music: Fabricating Authenticity](https://books.google.com/books?id=J3zWpIOLB-MC&pg=PA9)* (1999), p. 9, . the genre did not acquire its name until 1954."The Roots of Rock 'n' Roll 1946–1954". 2004. Universal Music Enterprises.

According to journalist [Kot](Greg)(Greg Kot), "rock and roll" refers to a style of popular music originating in the United States in the 1950s. By the mid-1960s, rock and roll had developed into "the more encompassing international style known as [music](rock)(rock music), though the latter also continued to be known in many circles as rock and roll."Kot, Greg, ["Rock and roll"](https://www.britannica.com/art/rock-and-roll-early-style-of-rock-music) , in the *[Britannica](Encyclopædia)(Encyclopædia Britannica)*, published [online](Encyclopædia Britannica Online) 17 June 2008 and also in print and in the *Encyclopædia Britannica Ultimate Reference* DVD; Chicago : Encyclopædia Britannica, 2010 For the purpose of differentiation, this article deals with the first definition.

In the earliest rock and roll styles, either the [piano](piano) or [saxophone](saxophone) was typically the lead instrument. These instruments were generally replaced or supplemented by guitar in the middle to late 1950s. The beat is essentially a dance rhythmBusnar, Gene, It's Rock 'n' Roll: A musical history of the fabulous fifties, Julian Messner, New York, 1979, p. 45 with an accentuated [backbeat](backbeat), almost always provided by a [drum](snare)(snare drum).P. Hurry, M. Phillips, and M. Richards, *Heinemann advanced music* (Heinemann, 2001), pp. 153–4. Classic rock and roll is usually played with one or two [guitar](electric)(electric guitar)s (one [lead](lead guitar), one [rhythm](rhythm guitar)) and a [bass](double)(double bass) (string bass). After the mid-1950s, electric [guitar](bass)(bass guitar)s ("Fender bass") and [kits](drum)(drum kits) became popular in classic rock.S. Evans, "The development of the Blues" in A. F. Moore, ed., *[Cambridge companion to blues and gospel music](The)(Cambridge Companions to Music)* (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2002), pp. 40–42.

Rock and roll had a polarizing influence on lifestyles, fashion, attitudes, and language. It is often portrayed in movies, fan magazines, and on television. Some people believe that the music had a positive influence on the [rights movement](civil)(civil rights movement), because both [American](Black)(Black American) and [American](White)(White American) teenagers enjoyed it.G. C. Altschuler, ''All shook up: how rock 'n' roll changed America'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press US, 2003), p. 35.

### Origins

The origins of rock and roll have been fiercely debated by commentators and historians of music. There is general agreement that it arose in the Southern United States – a region that would produce most of the major early rock and roll acts – through the meeting of various influences that embodied a merging of the African musical tradition with European instrumentation.M. T. Bertrand, *Race, Rock, and Elvis: Music in American Life* (University of Illinois Press, 2000), pp. 21–22. [migration of many former slaves and their descendants to major urban centers](The)(Second Great Migration (African American)) such as [Louis](St.)(St. Louis), [Memphis](Memphis, Tennessee), [York City](New)(New York City), [Detroit](Detroit), [Chicago](Chicago), [Cleveland](Cleveland), and [Buffalo](Buffalo, New York) meant that black and white residents were living in close proximity in larger numbers than ever before, and as a result heard each other's music and even began to emulate each other's fashions.R. Aquila, *That old-time rock & roll: a chronicle of an era, 1954–1963* (Chicago: University of Illinois Press, 2000), pp. 4–6.J. M. Salem, ''The late, great Johnny Ace and the transition from R & B to rock 'n' roll Music in American life* (University of Illinois Press, 2001), p. 4. Radio stations that made white and black forms of music available to both groups, the development and spread of the [record](gramophone)(gramophone record), and African-American musical styles such as [jazz](jazz) and [swing](Swing music) which were taken up by white musicians, aided this process of "cultural collision".M. T. Bertrand, *Race, rock, and Elvis Music in American life'' (University of Illinois Press, 2000), p. 99.

[[File:Chuck Berry 1957.jpg|thumb|right|[Berry](Chuck)(Chuck Berry) in 1957]]

The immediate roots of rock and roll lay in the [and blues](rhythm)(rhythm and blues), then called "[music](race)(race music)", in combination with either boogie-woogie and shouting gospel or with [music](country)(country music) of the 1940s and 1950s. Particularly significant influences were jazz, [blues](blues), [gospel](Gospel music), country, and [folk](folk music). Commentators differ in their views of which of these forms were most important and the degree to which the new music was a re-branding of African-American [and blues](rhythm)(rhythm and blues) for a white market, or a new hybrid of black and white forms.A. Bennett, *Rock and Popular Music: Politics, Policies, Institutions* (Routledge, 1993), pp. 236–238.K. Keightley, "Reconsidering rock", in S. Frith, W. Straw and J. Street, eds, *The Cambridge Companion to Pop and Rock* (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2001), p. 116.N. Kelley, *R&B, Rhythm and Business: The Political Economy of Black Music* (Akashic Books, 2005), p. 134.

[[File:Roll Em Pete.jpg|alt=A picture of the 7" single for "Roll 'Em Pete"|thumb|161x161px|[Joe Turner](Big)(Big Joe Turner) and [Johnson](Pete)(Pete Johnson (musician))'s record "['Em Pete](Roll)(Roll 'Em Pete)" is regarded as a precursor to rock and roll.]]

Contradicting Larry Birnbaum, the author of ''Before Elvis: The Prehistory of Rock 'n' Roll'', and notwithstanding early forms of white rock and roll then called "country boogie", musicologist and rock historian [Blum](Bruno)(Bruno Blum) argues that early, fully-formed rock and roll music really surged in America at least as early as 1945, but was segregated, thus making it unavailable to the general public and widely undocumented. According to Blum, true rock tracks from the 1940s included "Rock Woogie" by Jim Wynn's Bobalibans (1945), "Rockin' the House" by Memphis Slim and the House Rockers (1946), "Aladdin Boogie" by Amos Milburn (1947), "Rock and Rye" by Jimmy McCracklin (1947), "We're Gonna Rock" (1947) and "Rock and Roll" (1948) by Wild Bill Moore, and many others. His discussion of the topic is as follows:, text in both English pp17-18 and French pp 3-4.

The music was also called "blues" (*My Baby Left Me* by [Crudup](Arthur)(Arthur Crudup)), "rhythm music" ("Hambone" by [Saunders](Red)(Red Saunders (musician))), "rhythm and blues" ("Honey Hush" by [Joe Turner](Big)(Big Joe Turner)), "R&B" (the abbreviation of "rhythm and blues" and the name given to "black" music styles in the charts of Billboard magazine post-summer 1949), "jump blues" ("Rock Around the Clock" by [Singer](Hal)(Hal Singer)), "big beat", "rock 'n' roll" or "race music", was the label used by the press and Billboard in particular.}}

In the 1930s, [jazz](jazz), and particularly [swing](Swing music), both in urban-based dance bands and blues-influenced country swing ([Rodgers](Jimmie)(Jimmie Rodgers), [Mullican](Moon)(Moon Mullican) and other similar singers), were among the first music to present African-American sounds for a predominantly white audience.E. Wald, *How the Beatles Destroyed Rock N Roll: An Alternative History of American Popular Music* (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2009), pp. 111–125. One particularly noteworthy example of a jazz song with recognizably rock and roll elements is [Joe Turner](Big)(Big Joe Turner) with pianist [Johnson](Pete)(Pete Johnson (musician))'s 1939 single "['Em Pete](Roll)(Roll 'Em Pete)", which is regarded as an important precursor of rock and roll.[Tosches](Nick)(Nick Tosches), ''Unsung Heroes of Rock 'n' Roll*, Secker & Warburg, 1991, Peter J. Silvester, *A Left Hand Like God: a history of boogie-woogie piano* (1989), .M. Campbell, ed., *Popular Music in America: And the Beat Goes on* (Cengage Learning, 3rd edn, 2008), p. 99.  The 1940s saw the increased use of blaring horns (including saxophones), shouted lyrics and boogie-woogie beats in jazz-based music. During and immediately after [War II](World)(World War II), with shortages of fuel and limitations on audiences and available personnel, large jazz bands were less economical and tended to be replaced by smaller combos, using guitars, bass and drums.P. D. Lopes, *The rise of a jazz art world* (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2002), p. 132 In the same period, particularly on the [Coast](West)(West Coast of the United States) and in the [Midwest](Midwestern United States), the development of [blues](jump)(jump blues), with its guitar riffs, prominent beats and shouted lyrics, prefigured many later developments. In the documentary film *[Hail! Rock 'n' Roll](Hail!)(Hail! Hail! Rock 'n' Roll)*, [Richards](Keith)(Keith Richards) proposes that [Berry](Chuck)(Chuck Berry) developed his brand of rock and roll by transposing the familiar two-note lead line of jump blues piano directly to the electric guitar, creating what is instantly recognizable as rock guitar. This proposal by Richards neglects the black guitarists who did the same thing before Berry, such as [Carter](Goree)(Goree Carter),Robert Palmer, "Church of the Sonic Guitar", pp. 13–38 in Anthony DeCurtis, Present Tense, Duke University Press, 1992, p. 19. . [Brown](Gatemouth)(Clarence "Gatemouth" Brown),*Encyclopedia of Louisiana Musicians: Jazz, Blues, Cajun, Creole, Zydeco, Swamp Pop, and Gospel*. Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press. p. 57. . and the originator of the style, [Walker](T-Bone)(T-Bone Walker).Dance, Helen Oakley, "Walker, Aaron Thibeaux (T-Bone)", *The Handbook of Texas Online*. Denton: Texas State Historical Association. [boogie](Country)(Country boogie) and [electric blues](Chicago)(Chicago blues) supplied many of the elements that would be seen as characteristic of rock and roll. Inspired by [blues](electric)(electric blues), Chuck Berry introduced an aggressive guitar sound to rock and roll, and established the electric guitar as its centerpiece,Michael Campbell & James Brody, *Rock and Roll: An Introduction*, [pp. 110–111](https://books.google.com/books?id=RK-JmVbv4OIC&pg=PA110)  adapting his rock band instrumentation from the basic blues band instrumentation of a lead guitar, second chord instrument, bass and drums.Michael Campbell & James Brody, [*Rock and Roll: An Introduction''](https://books.google.com/books?id=RK-JmVbv4OIC&pg=PA80), , pp. 80–81. In 2017, [Christgau](Robert)(Robert Christgau) declared that "Chuck Berry did in fact invent rock 'n' roll", explaining that this artist "came the closest of any single figure to being the one who put all the essential pieces together".

Rock and roll arrived at a time of considerable technological change, soon after the development of the electric guitar, [amplifier](amplifier) and [microphone](microphone), and the [rpm record](45)(45 rpm record). There were also changes in the record industry, with the rise of independent labels like [Atlantic](Atlantic records), [Sun](Sun Records) and [Chess](Chess Records) servicing [audiences](niche)(niche market) and a similar rise of radio stations that played their music. It was the realization that relatively affluent white teenagers were listening to this music that led to the development of what was to be defined as rock and roll as a distinct genre. Because the development of rock and roll was an evolutionary process, no single record can be identified as unambiguously "the first" rock and roll record.[Dawson](Jim)(Jim Dawson) and Steve Propes, ''[Was The First Rock'n'Roll Record](What)(iarchive:whatwasfirstrock0000daws)'', 1992,  Contenders for the title of "[rock and roll record](first)(first rock and roll record)" include [Rosetta Tharpe](Sister)(Sister Rosetta Tharpe)'s "[Things Happening Every Day](Strange)(Strange Things Happening Every Day)" (1944), "[All Right](That's)(That's All Right)" by [Crudup](Arthur)(Arthur Crudup) (1946),  "[It On Over](Move)(Move It On Over (song))" by [Williams](Hank)(Hank Williams) (1947), "[Fat Man](The)(The Fat Man (song))" by [Domino](Fats)(Fats Domino) (1949), [Carter](Goree)(Goree Carter)'s "[Awhile](Rock)(Rock Awhile)" (1949),[Palmer](Robert)(Robert Palmer (writer)), "Church of the Sonic Guitar", pp. 13–38 in Anthony DeCurtis, *Present Tense*, [University Press](Duke)(Duke University Press), 1992, p. 19.  and [Preston](Jimmy)(Jimmy Preston)'s "[the Joint](Rock)(Rock the Joint)" (1949) (later [covered](cover version) by [Haley & His Comets](Bill)(Bill Haley & His Comets) in 1952),

"[88](Rocket)(Rocket 88)" by [Brenston](Jackie)(Jackie Brenston) and his Delta Cats ([Turner](Ike)(Ike Turner) and his band [Kings of Rhythm](The)(Kings of Rhythm) and sung by Brenston), was recorded by [Phillips](Sam)(Sam Phillips) in March 1951. This is often cited as the first rock n' roll record.M. Campbell, ed., *Popular Music in America: and the Beat Goes on* (Boston, Massachusetts: Cengage Learning, 3rd ed., 2008), , pp. 157–8. In an interview however, Ike Turner offered this comment: "I don't think that 'Rocket 88' is rock 'n' roll. I think that 'Rocket 88' is R&B, but I think 'Rocket 88' is the cause of rock and roll existing".

[[File:BillHaley.JPG|upright=1.05|thumb|[Haley](Bill)(Bill Haley) and his Comets performing in the 1954 Universal International film *Round Up of Rhythm*]]

In terms of its wide cultural impact across society in the US and elsewhere, [Haley](Bill)(Bill Haley (musician))'s "[Around the Clock](Rock)(Rock Around the Clock)", recorded in April 1954 but not a commercial success until the following year, is generally recognized as an important milestone, but it was preceded by many recordings from earlier decades in which elements of rock and roll can be clearly discerned.Robert Palmer, "Rock Begins", in *[Stone](Rolling)(Rolling Stone) Illustrated History of Rock and Roll*, 1976/1980,  (UK edition), pp. 3–14.

Journalist [Petridis](Alexis)(Alexis Petridis) argued that neither Haley's "Rock Around the Clock" nor Presley's version of "That's Alright Mama" heralded a new genre: "They were simply the first white artists' interpretations of a sound already well-established by black musicians almost a decade before. It was a raucous, driving, unnamed variant of rhythm and blues that came complete with lyrics that talked about rocking".

Other artists with early rock and roll hits included [Berry](Chuck)(Chuck Berry), [Diddley](Bo)(Bo Diddley), [Richard](Little)(Little Richard), [Lee Lewis](Jerry)(Jerry Lee Lewis), and [Vincent](Gene)(Gene Vincent). Chuck Berry's 1955 classic "[Maybellene](Maybellene)" in particular features a [distorted](distortion (music)) [guitar](electric)(electric guitar) solo with warm [overtone](overtone)s created by his small [amplifier](valve)(valve amplifier). However, the use of distortion was predated by electric blues guitarists such as [Hill Louis](Joe)(Joe Hill Louis), [Slim](Guitar)(Guitar Slim),. [Johnson](Willie)(Willie Johnson (guitarist)) of [Wolf](Howlin')(Howlin' Wolf)'s band, and [Hare](Pat)(Pat Hare); the latter two also made use of distorted [chord](power)(power chord)s in the early 1950s.[Palmer](Robert)(Robert Palmer (writer)), "Church of the Sonic Guitar", pp. 13–38 in Anthony DeCurtis, *Present Tense*, [University Press](Duke)(Duke University Press), 1992, pp. 24–27. . Also in 1955, Bo Diddley introduced the "[Diddley beat](Bo)(Bo Diddley beat)" and a unique electric guitar style,P. Buckley, *The rough guide to rock* (Rough Guides, 3rd ed., 2003), p. 21. influenced by [African](Music of Africa) and [music](Afro-Cuban)(Afro-Cuban music) and in turn influencing many later artists.
## Early rock and roll

# Rock and roll

*Revision ID: 1159956168 | Timestamp: 2023-06-13T16:05:15Z*

---

early 1950s, Southern United States

| derivatives       = * [Rock](Rock music)

* [beat](Beat music)

* [pop](Pop music)

| regional_scenes   = *[Kingdom](United)(British rock and roll)

| other_topics      = *[of rock and roll](Origins)(Origins of rock and roll)

*[of artists](list)(List of rock and roll artists)

}}

**Rock and roll** (often written as **rock & roll**, '''rock 'n' roll**, or **rock n roll''') is a [genre](Genre (music)) of [music](popular)(popular music) that evolved in the United States during the late 1940s and early 1950s. It [originated](Origins of rock and roll) from African-American music such as [jazz](jazz), [and blues](rhythm)(rhythm and blues), [boogie-woogie](boogie-woogie), [gospel](gospel music), [blues](jump)(jump blues), as well as [music](country)(country music).Larry Birnbaum, ''Before Elvis: The Prehistory of Rock 'n' Roll'', Scarecrow Press, 2013, p.vii-x. While rock and roll's formative elements can be heard in blues records from the 1920sDavis, Francis. *[History of the Blues](The)(iarchive:historyofblues00davi)* (New York: Hyperion, 1995), . and in country records of the 1930s,Peterson, Richard A. *[Creating Country Music: Fabricating Authenticity](https://books.google.com/books?id=J3zWpIOLB-MC&pg=PA9)* (1999), p. 9, . the genre did not acquire its name until 1954."The Roots of Rock 'n' Roll 1946–1954". 2004. Universal Music Enterprises.

According to journalist [Kot](Greg)(Greg Kot), "rock and roll" refers to a style of popular music originating in the United States in the 1950s. By the mid-1960s, rock and roll had developed into "the more encompassing international style known as [music](rock)(rock music), though the latter also continued to be known in many circles as rock and roll."Kot, Greg, ["Rock and roll"](https://www.britannica.com/art/rock-and-roll-early-style-of-rock-music) , in the *[Britannica](Encyclopædia)(Encyclopædia Britannica)*, published [online](Encyclopædia Britannica Online) 17 June 2008 and also in print and in the *Encyclopædia Britannica Ultimate Reference* DVD; Chicago : Encyclopædia Britannica, 2010 For the purpose of differentiation, this article deals with the first definition.

In the earliest rock and roll styles, either the [piano](piano) or [saxophone](saxophone) was typically the lead instrument. These instruments were generally replaced or supplemented by guitar in the middle to late 1950s. The beat is essentially a dance rhythmBusnar, Gene, It's Rock 'n' Roll: A musical history of the fabulous fifties, Julian Messner, New York, 1979, p. 45 with an accentuated [backbeat](backbeat), almost always provided by a [drum](snare)(snare drum).P. Hurry, M. Phillips, and M. Richards, *Heinemann advanced music* (Heinemann, 2001), pp. 153–4. Classic rock and roll is usually played with one or two [guitar](electric)(electric guitar)s (one [lead](lead guitar), one [rhythm](rhythm guitar)) and a [bass](double)(double bass) (string bass). After the mid-1950s, electric [guitar](bass)(bass guitar)s ("Fender bass") and [kits](drum)(drum kits) became popular in classic rock.S. Evans, "The development of the Blues" in A. F. Moore, ed., *[Cambridge companion to blues and gospel music](The)(Cambridge Companions to Music)* (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2002), pp. 40–42.

Rock and roll had a polarizing influence on lifestyles, fashion, attitudes, and language. It is often portrayed in movies, fan magazines, and on television. Some people believe that the music had a positive influence on the [rights movement](civil)(civil rights movement), because both [American](Black)(Black American) and [American](White)(White American) teenagers enjoyed it.G. C. Altschuler, ''All shook up: how rock 'n' roll changed America'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press US, 2003), p. 35.

The "Architect of Rock and Roll" is widely known to be **Chuck Berry**. He is credited with putting together the essential elements of the genre, including the use of the electric guitar, a strong backbeat, and a distinctive song structure. As journalist Robert Christgau stated in 2017, "Chuck Berry did in fact invent rock 'n' roll," explaining that he "came the closest of any single figure to being the one who put all the essential pieces together."

## Early life

Smit-McPhee was born on 13 June 1996 in [Adelaide](Adelaide), South Australia, the son of Sonja Smit and Andy McPhee. His father is an actor and former professional wrestler. His older sister is actress and singer [Smit-McPhee](Sianoa)(Sianoa Smit-McPhee).

At age 16, Smit-McPhee was diagnosed with [spondylitis](ankylosing)(ankylosing spondylitis), a degenerative form of [arthritis](arthritis) which causes vertebrae in the spine to fuse and can lead to chronic pain and loss of vision. Due to the condition, he is [blind](Blindness) in his left eye.
Kodi Smit-McPhee was diagnosed with ankylosing spondylitis at age 16, a degenerative form of arthritis that can lead to chronic pain and loss of vision, causing him to be blind in his left eye.

### Eigenvalues and the characteristic polynomial

Equation () has a nonzero solution *v* [and only if](if)(if and only if) the [determinant](determinant) of the matrix  is zero. Therefore, the eigenvalues of *A* are values of *λ* that satisfy the equation

}}

Using the [formula for determinants](Leibniz)(Leibniz formula for determinants), the left-hand side of Equation () is a [polynomial](polynomial) function of the variable *λ* and the [degree](degree of a polynomial) of this polynomial is *n*, the order of the matrix *A*. Its [coefficient](coefficient)s depend on the entries of *A*, except that its term of degree *n* is always (−1)*n**λ**n*. This polynomial is called the *[polynomial](characteristic)(characteristic polynomial)* of *A*. Equation () is called the *characteristic equation* or the *secular equation* of *A*.

The [theorem of algebra](fundamental)(fundamental theorem of algebra) implies that the characteristic polynomial of an *n*-by-*n* matrix *A*, being a polynomial of degree *n*, can be [factored](factorization) into the product of *n* linear terms,

}}

where each *λ**i* may be real but in general is a complex number. The numbers *λ*1, *λ*2, ..., *λ**n*, which may not all have distinct values, are roots of the polynomial and are the eigenvalues of *A*.

As a brief example, which is described in more detail in the examples section later, consider the matrix

A = \begin{bmatrix}

2 & 1\\

1 & 2

\end{bmatrix}.

Taking the determinant of , the characteristic polynomial of *A* is

|A - \lambda I| = \begin{vmatrix}

2 - \lambda & 1 \\

1           & 2 - \lambda

\end{vmatrix} =

3 - 4\lambda + \lambda^2.

Setting the characteristic polynomial equal to zero, it has roots at  and , which are the two eigenvalues of *A*. The eigenvectors corresponding to each eigenvalue can be found by solving for the components of **v** in the equation  In this example, the eigenvectors are any nonzero scalar multiples of

\mathbf v_{\lambda=1} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \end{bmatrix}, \quad \mathbf v_{\lambda=3} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}.

If the entries of the matrix *A* are all real numbers, then the coefficients of the characteristic polynomial will also be real numbers, but the eigenvalues may still have nonzero imaginary parts. The entries of the corresponding eigenvectors therefore may also have nonzero imaginary parts. Similarly, the eigenvalues may be [number](irrational)(irrational number)s even if all the entries of *A* are [number](rational)(rational number)s or even if they are all integers. However, if the entries of *A* are all [number](algebraic)(algebraic number)s, which include the rationals, the eigenvalues must also be algebraic numbers (that is, they cannot magically become [number](transcendental)(transcendental number)s).

The non-real roots of a real polynomial with real coefficients can be grouped into pairs of [conjugate](complex)(complex conjugate)s, namely with the two members of each pair having imaginary parts that differ only in sign and the same real part. If the degree is odd, then by the [value theorem](intermediate)(intermediate value theorem) at least one of the roots is real. Therefore, any [matrix](real)(real matrix) with odd order has at least one real eigenvalue, whereas a real matrix with even order may not have any real eigenvalues. The eigenvectors associated with these complex eigenvalues are also complex and also appear in complex conjugate pairs.

The characteristic polynomial of the 2×2 matrix $ A = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ 1 & 2 \end{bmatrix} $ is found by computing the determinant of $ A - \lambda I $:

$$
\det(A - \lambda I) = \begin{vmatrix} 2 - \lambda & 1 \\ 1 & 2 - \lambda \end{vmatrix} = (2 - \lambda)(2 - \lambda) - (1)(1) = \lambda^2 - 4\lambda + 3.
$$

Thus, the characteristic polynomial is $ \lambda^2 - 4\lambda + 3 $.

### Adoption and formalisation of the Commonwealth

In the [Declaration](Balfour)(Balfour Declaration of 1926) at the [Imperial Conference](1926)(1926 Imperial Conference), the United Kingdom and its dominions agreed they were "equal in status, in no way subordinate one to another in any aspect of their domestic or external affairs, though united by common allegiance to the Crown, and freely associated as members of the British Commonwealth of Nations". The term "[Commonwealth](Commonwealth)" was officially adopted to describe the community.

These aspects to the relationship were formalised by the [of Westminster](Statute)(Statute of Westminster 1931) in 1931, which applied to Canada without the need for ratification, but Australia, [Zealand](New)(New Zealand), and [Newfoundland](Dominion of Newfoundland) had to ratify the statute for it to take effect. Newfoundland never did as due to economic hardship and the need for financial assistance from London, Newfoundland voluntarily accepted the suspension of self-government in 1934 and governance reverted to direct control from London. Newfoundland later joined Canada as its [province](tenth)(Provinces and territories of Canada) in 1949. [Australia](Australia) and New Zealand ratified the Statute in [1942](Statute of Westminster Adoption Act 1942) and [1947](Statute of Westminster Adoption Act 1947) respectively.

Although the Union of South Africa was not among the Dominions that needed to adopt the Statute of Westminster for it to take effect, two laws—the Status of the Union Act, 1934, and the Royal Executive Functions and Seals Act of 1934—were passed to confirm South Africa's status as a sovereign state.
## History

### Origins of the concept and establishment of the term

[[File:British Commonealth of Nations handwritten on Anglo-Irish Treaty draft.png|thumb|upright=1.3|Draft of the 1921 [Treaty](Anglo-Irish)(Anglo-Irish Treaty), with "British Empire" crossed out and "British Commonwealth of Nations" added by hand.]]

[[File:CommonwealthPrimeMinisters1944.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|The prime ministers of five members at the 1944 [Prime Ministers' Conference](Commonwealth)(Commonwealth Prime Ministers' Conference). (L-R) [King](Mackenzie)(William Lyon Mackenzie King) (Canada), [Smuts](Jan)(Jan Smuts) ([Africa](South)(Union of South Africa)), [Churchill](Winston)(Winston Churchill) (United Kingdom), [Fraser](Peter)(Peter Fraser (New Zealand politician)) (New Zealand) and [Curtin](John)(John Curtin) (Australia)]]

[Elizabeth II](Queen)(Queen Elizabeth II), in her address to Canada on [Day](Dominion)(Canada Day) in 1959, pointed out that the [of Canada](Confederation)(Confederation of Canada) on 1 July 1867 had been the birth of the "first independent country within the British Empire". She declared: "So, it also marks the beginning of that free association of independent states which is now known as the Commonwealth of Nations." As long ago as 1884 [Rosebery](Lord)(Archibald Primrose, 5th Earl of Rosebery), while visiting [Australia](Australia), had described the changing British Empire, as some of its colonies became more independent, as a "Commonwealth of Nations". Conferences of British and colonial prime ministers occurred periodically from [first one in 1887](the)(First Colonial Conference), leading to the creation of the [Conference](Imperial)(Imperial Conference)s in 1911.

The Commonwealth developed from the imperial conferences. A specific proposal was presented by [Smuts](Jan)(Jan Smuts) in 1917 when he coined the term "the British Commonwealth of Nations" and envisioned the "future constitutional relations and readjustments in essence" at the [Peace Conference of 1919](Paris)(Paris Peace Conference, 1919), attended by delegates from the Dominions as well as the United Kingdom.F.S. Crafford, *Jan Smuts: A Biography* (2005) p. 142The Irish [of Allegiance](Oath)(Oath of Allegiance (Ireland)), agreed in 1921, included the [Free State](Irish)(Irish Free State)'s "adherence to and membership of the group of nations forming the British Commonwealth of Nations". The term first received imperial statutory recognition in the [Treaty](Anglo-Irish)(Anglo-Irish Treaty) of 1921, when the term *British Commonwealth of Nations* was substituted for *British Empire* in the wording of the oath taken by members of parliament of the [Free State](Irish)(Irish Free State).

The **Commonwealth of Nations**, simply referred to as **the Commonwealth**, is a political association of [member states](56)(member states of the Commonwealth of Nations), the vast majority of which are former [territories](territorial evolution of the British Empire) of the [Empire](British)(British Empire). The chief institutions of the organisation are the [Secretariat](Commonwealth)(Commonwealth Secretariat), which focuses on intergovernmental aspects, and the [Foundation](Commonwealth)(Commonwealth Foundation), which focuses on non-governmental relations among member states. Numerous [organisations](Commonwealth organisation) are associated with and operate within the Commonwealth.

The Commonwealth dates back to the first half of the 20th century with the [decolonisation](Decolonization) of the British Empire through increased self-governance of its territories. It was originally created as the **British Commonwealth of Nations** through the [Declaration](Balfour)(Balfour Declaration of 1926) at the [Imperial Conference](1926)(1926 Imperial Conference), and formalised by the United Kingdom through the [of Westminster](Statute)(Statute of Westminster 1931) in 1931. The current Commonwealth of Nations was formally constituted by the [Declaration](London)(London Declaration) in 1949, which modernised the community and established the member states as "free and equal".

The [of the Commonwealth](head)(head of the Commonwealth) is [III](Charles)(Charles III).  He is king of 15 member states, known as the [realm](Commonwealth)(Commonwealth realm)s, while 36 other members are [republics](Republics in the Commonwealth of Nations), and five others have different monarchs.

Member states have no legal obligations to one another but are connected through their [of the English language](use)(Anglosphere) and historical ties. [of a Commonwealth nation](Citizenship)(Commonwealth citizen) affords benefits in some member countries, particularly in the [Kingdom](United)(United Kingdom). The [Charter](Commonwealth)(Charter of the Commonwealth) defines their shared values of [democracy](democracy), [rights](human)(human rights), and the [of law](rule)(rule of law), as promoted by the quadrennial [Games](Commonwealth)(Commonwealth Games).
The Commonwealth of Nations was formally constituted by the London Declaration in 1949.

## Contracts for marriage

Lady Jane acted as chief mourner at Catherine Parr's funeral; Thomas Seymour showed continued interest to keep her in his household, and she returned there for about two months before he was arrested at the end of 1548. Seymour's brother, the [Protector](Lord)(Lord Protector), [Seymour, 1st Duke of Somerset](Edward)(Edward Seymour, 1st Duke of Somerset), felt threatened by Thomas' popularity with the young King Edward. Among other things, Thomas Seymour was charged with proposing Jane as a bride for the king.

In the course of Thomas Seymour's following [attainder](attainder) and execution, Jane's father was lucky to stay largely out of trouble. After his fourth interrogation by the [Council](King's)(Privy Council of England), he proposed his daughter Jane as a bride for the Protector's eldest son, [Hertford](Lord)(Edward Seymour, 1st Earl of Hertford). Nothing came of this, however, and Jane was not engaged until 25 May 1553, her bridegroom being [Guildford Dudley](Lord)(Lord Guildford Dudley), a younger son of [Dudley, 1st Duke of Northumberland](John)(John Dudley, 1st Duke of Northumberland). The Duke, [President](Lord)(Lord President of the Council) of the [Council](King's)(privy council) from late 1549, was then the most powerful man in the country. On 25 May 1553, the couple were married at [House](Durham)(Durham House (London)) in a triple wedding, in which Jane's sister [Catherine](Lady Catherine Grey) was matched with the heir of the [of Pembroke](Earl)(William Herbert, 1st Earl of Pembroke (1551 creation)), [Herbert](Lord)(Henry Herbert, 2nd Earl of Pembroke), and another [Katherine](Katherine Hastings, Countess of Huntingdon), Lord Guildford's sister, with [Hastings](Henry)(Henry Hastings, 3rd Earl of Huntingdon), the [of Huntingdon](Earl)(Francis Hastings, 2nd Earl of Huntingdon)'s heir.; .
Lady Jane Grey was married to Guildford Dudley, a younger son of John Dudley, 1st Duke of Northumberland.

## Early life

Emmanuelle Grey Rossum was born on September 12, 1986, in New York City. She is the only child of Cheryl Rossum, a single mother who worked as a corporate photographer. Her parents separated while her mother was pregnant, and as of 2007, she had met her father only twice.

Rossum's mother is Jewish of [Jewish](Russian)(History of the Jews in Russia) descent, and her father is [Protestant](Protestant) of English and Dutch ancestry. Rossum identifies as Jewish and has stated that her mother instilled in her the "Jewish code of ethics and morals". She was named for her great-grandfather, whose first name was Emanuel, using the feminine spelling.

Upon singing "[Birthday](Happy)(Happy Birthday to You)" in all 12 keys,Joffe, Jessica. "Emmy Rossum: Hollywood's newest It Girl." Glamour: September 2006. p 326-7, 392 Rossum was welcomed to join the [Opera](Metropolitan)(Metropolitan Opera) Children's Chorus by chorus director Elena Doria at age seven. Over the course of five years she sang onstage with the chorus and had the chance to perform with singers such as [Domingo](Plácido)(Plácido Domingo) and [Pavarotti](Luciano)(Luciano Pavarotti). For anywhere from $5 to $10 a night, Rossum sang in six languages in 20 operas, including *[bohème](La)(La bohème)*, *[Turandot](Turandot)*, a [Hall](Carnegie)(Carnegie Hall) presentation of *[damnation de Faust](La)(La damnation de Faust)*, and ''[ A Midsummer Night's Dream](A Midsummer Night's Dream (opera) )''."It's Evening in America". *[Fair](Vanity)(Vanity Fair (magazine))*. May 2012. Page 152. She also worked under the direction of [Zeffirelli](Franco)(Franco Zeffirelli) in *[Carmen](Carmen)*.

An increasing interest in pursuing acting led to taking classes with Flo Salant Greenberg of [New Actors Workshop](The)(The New Actors Workshop) in New York City. She has also worked with acting coach Terry Knickerbocker.

Rossum attended the [School](Spence)(Spence School), a private school in [Manhattan](Manhattan), before dropping out to pursue career opportunities. She received her high school diploma at fifteen years old via online-extension courses offered by [University](Stanford)(Stanford University)'s [Program for Gifted Youth](Education)(Education Program for Gifted Youth) (EPGY). She enrolled at [University](Columbia)(Columbia University), studying French, art history and philosophy.
Emmy Rossum attended Columbia University, where she studied French, art history, and philosophy.

### Time in Texas and Juneteenth

[[File:General Order No. 3.jpg|thumb|right|[Order No. 3](General)(General Order No. 3), June 19, 1865]]When the war ended, Granger was given command of the [of Texas](District)(Department of Texas).Dupuy, p. 290 On June 19, 1865, in the city of [Galveston](Galveston, Texas), one of the first orders of business was to read to the people of Texas Granger's [Order No. 3](General)(General Order No. 3) which began with:[From Texas: Important Orders by General Granger.](https://www.nytimes.com/1865/07/07/news/texas-important-orders-general-granger-surrender-senator-johnson-arkansas.html) *The New York Times,* July 7, 1865.

This set off joyous demonstrations by the freed people, originating the annual [Juneteenth](Juneteenth) celebration, which commemorates the abolition of slavery in Texas.
The Union general who issued General Order No. 3 in Texas on June 19, 1865, leading to the celebration of Juneteenth, was Gordon Granger.

**Greta Jiehan Lee** (born March 7, 1983) is an American actress. She is best known for starring as Maxine in the [Netflix](Netflix) comedy-drama series *[Doll](Russian)(Russian Doll (TV series))* and for her role in the second season of [TV+](Apple)(Apple TV+) drama series *[Morning Show](The)(The Morning Show (American TV series))*.

She gained wider recognition for her role as Nora in the 2023 film *[Lives](Past)(Past Lives (film))*.
Greta Lee is married to Russ Armstrong.

# Quran

*Revision ID: 1159677220 | Timestamp: 2023-06-11T21:04:28Z*

---

The **Quran** (, ;, , , ;dictionary.reference.com: [koran](http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/Koran) especially with the spelling *quran* , ;dictionary.reference.com: [quran](http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/Quran) especially in British English .Cambridge dictionary: [koran](http://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/british/the-koran)Cambridge dictionary: [quran](http://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/british/the-qur-an?q=qur%27an)|group=lower-roman}} [Arabic](vocalized)(tashkil): }}, [Arabic](Quranic)(Classical Arabic): }}  }},. The actual pronunciation in [Arabic](Literary)(Modern Standard Arabic) varies regionally. The first vowel varies from  to , while the second vowel varies from  to  to . For example, the pronunciation in Egypt is  and in Central East Arabia . |group=lower-roman}} 'the recitation'), also romanized '''Qur'an** or **Koran**, The form **Koran** was most predominant from the second half of the 18th century till the 1980s, when it has been superseded by either **Qur'an** or **Quran'*. Other transliterations include *al-Coran*, *Coran*, *Kuran* and *al-Qur'an*. The adjectives vary as well and include *Koranic*, *Quranic* and *Qur'anic'' (sometimes in lowercase).

|group=lower-roman}} is the central [text](religious)(religious text) of [Islam](Islam), believed by [Muslim](Muslim)s to be a [revelation](revelation in Islam) from [God](God in Islam). It is organized in 114 [chapters](surah) (pl.:  , sing.:  ), which consist of [verses](āyah) (pl.:  , sing.:  , [cons.](construct case): ). In addition to its religious significance, it is widely regarded as the finest work in [literature](Arabic)(Arabic literature), and has significantly influenced the [language](Arabic)(Arabic language).

Muslims believe that the Quran was orally revealed by God to the [prophet](final)(Khatam an-Nabiyyin), [Muhammad](Muhammad in Islam), through the archangel [Gabriel](Gabriel) incrementally over a period of some 23 years, beginning on [Al Qadr](Laylat)(Night of Power),[Quran 97:1-5](https://quran.com/97) when Muhammad was 40; and concluding in 632, the year of his death. Muslims regard the Quran as Muhammad's most important [miracle](miracle), a proof of his [prophethood](prophethood); and the culmination of a series of divine messages starting with those revealed to [Adam](Adam in Islam), including the [Tawrat](Tawrat), the [Zabur](Zabur) ([Psalms](Psalms)) and the [Injil](Injil) (Gospel). The word *Quran* occurs some 70 times in the text itself, and other names and words are also said to refer to the Quran.

The Quran is believed by Muslims to be not simply divinely inspired, but the literal [of God](word)(Biblical inspiration). Muhammad did not write it as he did not know how to write. In Muslim theology, the Qur'an is considered to be either "[created](Quranic createdness)" or "uncreated".[*Ibn Ḥanbal and the Miḥna*, 1897](Patton,)(#WMP1897): p.54 According to tradition, several of Muhammad's [companions](Companions of the Prophet) served as scribes, recording the revelations. Shortly after the prophet's death, the Quran was compiled by the companions, who had written down or memorized parts of it. Caliph [Uthman](Uthman) established a standard version, now known as the [codex](Uthmanic)(Uthmanic codex), which is generally considered the archetype of the Quran known today. There are, however, [readings](variant)(Qiraʼat), with mostly minor differences in meaning.

The Quran assumes [with major narratives](familiarity)(Biblical and Quranic narratives) recounted in the [Biblical](Books of the Bible) and [scriptures](apocryphal)(Apocrypha). It summarizes some, dwells at length on others and, in some cases, presents alternative accounts and interpretations of events. The Quran describes itself as a book of guidance for humankind ( ). It sometimes offers detailed accounts of specific historical events, and it often emphasizes the moral significance of an event over its narrative sequence. Supplementing the Quran with explanations for some cryptic Quranic narratives, and rulings that also provide the basis for Islamic law in most denominations of Islam, are *[hadith](hadith)s*—oral and written traditions believed to describe words and actions of Muhammad.  During prayers, the Quran is recited only in [Arabic](Arabic).

Someone who has memorized the entire Quran is called a *[hafiz](Hafiz (Quran))*. Ideally, verses are recited with a special kind of [prosody](Prosody (linguistics)) reserved for this purpose, called *[tajwid](tajwid)*. During the month of Ramadan, Muslims typically complete the recitation of the whole Quran during *[tarawih](tarawih)* prayers. In order to extrapolate the meaning of a particular Quranic verse, Muslims rely on [exegesis](exegesis), or commentary rather than a direct translation of the text.

## Contents

The Quranic content is concerned with basic Islamic beliefs including the existence of [God](God in Islam) and the [resurrection](Islamic eschatology). Narratives of the early [prophets](Prophets in Islam), ethical and legal subjects, historical events of Muhammad's time, charity and [prayer](Salat) also appear in the Quran. The Quranic verses contain general exhortations regarding right and wrong and historical events are related to outline general moral lessons. Verses pertaining to natural phenomena have been interpreted by Muslims as an indication of the authenticity of the Quranic message. The style of the Quran has been called "allusive," with commentaries needed to explain what is being referred to—"events are referred to, but not narrated; disagreements are debated without being explained; people and places are mentioned, but rarely named."

### Prophetic era

Islamic tradition relates that [Muhammad](Muhammad in Islam) received [first revelation](his)(Muhammad's first revelation) in the [of Hira](Cave)(Jabal al-Nour) during one of his isolated retreats to the mountains. Thereafter, he received revelations over a period of 23 years. According to *[hadith](hadith)* and [history](Muslim)(History of Islam), after Muhammad [to Medina](immigrated)(Hijra (Islam)) and formed an independent Muslim community, he ordered many of his [companions](sahabah) to recite the Quran and to learn and teach the laws, which were revealed daily. It is related that some of the [Quraysh](Quraysh) who were taken prisoners at the [of Badr](Battle)(Battle of Badr) regained their freedom after they had taught some of the Muslims the simple writing of the time. Thus a group of Muslims gradually became literate. As it was initially spoken, the Quran was recorded on tablets, bones, and the wide, flat ends of date palm fronds. Most suras were in use amongst early Muslims since they are mentioned in numerous sayings by both [Sunni](Sunni) and [Shia](Shia) sources, relating Muhammad's use of the Quran as a call to Islam, the making of prayer and the manner of recitation. However, the Quran did not exist in book form at the time of Muhammad's death in 632. There is agreement among scholars that Muhammad himself did not write down the revelation.

*[al-Bukhari](Sahih)(Sahih al-Bukhari)* narrates Muhammad describing the revelations as, "Sometimes it is (revealed) like the ringing of a bell" and [Aisha](Aisha) reported, "I saw the Prophet being inspired Divinely on a very cold day and noticed the sweat dropping from his forehead (as the Inspiration was over)."|group=lower-roman}} Muhammad's first revelation, according to the Quran, was accompanied with a vision. The agent of revelation is mentioned as the "one mighty in power," the one who "grew clear to view when he was on the uppermost horizon. Then he drew nigh and came down till he was (distant) two bows' length or even nearer." The Islamic studies scholar Welch states in the *[of Islam](Encyclopaedia)(Encyclopaedia of Islam)* that he believes the graphic descriptions of Muhammad's condition at these moments may be regarded as genuine, because he was severely disturbed after these revelations. According to Welch, these seizures would have been seen by those around him as convincing evidence for the superhuman origin of Muhammad's inspirations. However, Muhammad's critics accused him of being a possessed man, a [soothsayer](Clairvoyant) or a [magician](magician (paranormal)) since his experiences were similar to those claimed by such figures well known in [Arabia](ancient)(Pre-Islamic Arabia). Welch additionally states that it remains uncertain whether these experiences occurred before or after Muhammad's initial claim of prophethood.

[[File:Iqra.jpg|thumb|200px|[Muhammad](Muhammad)'s first revelation, [Al-Alaq](Surah)(Al-Alaq), later placed 96th in the Qur'anic regulations, in current writing style]]

The Quran describes Muhammad as "," which is traditionally interpreted as 'illiterate', but the meaning is rather more complex. Medieval commentators such as [Al-Tabari](Muhammad ibn Jarir al-Tabari) maintained that the term induced two meanings: first, the inability to read or write in general; second, the inexperience or ignorance of the previous books or scriptures (but they gave priority to the first meaning). Muhammad's illiteracy was taken as a sign of the genuineness of his prophethood. For example, according to [al-Din al-Razi](Fakhr)(Fakhr al-Din al-Razi), if Muhammad had mastered writing and reading he possibly would have been suspected of having studied the books of the ancestors. Some scholars such as [Watt](William Montgomery Watt) prefer the second meaning of —they take it to indicate unfamiliarity with earlier sacred texts.

The final verse of the Quran was revealed on the 18th of the Islamic month of [al-Hijjah](Dhu)(Dhu al-Hijjah) in the year 10 [A.H.](Hijri year), a date that roughly corresponds to February or March 632. The verse was revealed after [Prophet finished delivering his sermon at Ghadir Khumm](the)(Event of Ghadir Khumm).

### Levels of meaning

[[File:Quran rzabasi1.JPG|thumb|9th-century Quran in [Abbasi Museum](Reza)(Reza Abbasi Museum)]] [[File:IslamicGalleryBritishMuseum3.jpg|thumb| An 11th-century North African Quran at the [Museum](British)(British Museum) ]]

Unlike the Salafis and Zahiri, Shias and Sufis as well as some other [philosophers](Muslim)(Islamic philosophy) believe the meaning of the Quran is not restricted to the literal aspect. For them, it is an essential idea that the Quran also has inward aspects. [Corbin](Henry)(Henry Corbin) narrates a *[hadith](hadith)* that goes back to [Muhammad](Muhammad):

The Quran possesses an external appearance and a hidden depth, an exoteric meaning and an esoteric meaning. This esoteric meaning in turn conceals an esoteric meaning (this depth possesses a depth, after the image of the celestial Spheres, which are enclosed within each other). So it goes on for seven esoteric meanings (seven depths of hidden depth).

According to this view, it has also become evident that the inner meaning of the Quran does not eradicate or invalidate its outward meaning. Rather, it is like the soul, which gives life to the body. Corbin considers the Quran to play a part in [philosophy](Islamic)(Islamic philosophy), because [gnosiology](gnosiology) itself goes hand in hand with [prophetology](prophet#Islam).

Commentaries dealing with the *[zahir](Zahir (Islam))* ('outward aspects') of the text are called , and hermeneutic and esoteric commentaries dealing with the *[batin](Batin (Islam))* are called ''[ta'wil](Esoteric interpretation of the Quran)'' ('interpretation' or 'explanation'), which involves taking the text back to its beginning. Commentators with an esoteric slant believe that the ultimate meaning of the Quran is known only to God. In contrast, [literalism](Quranic)(Bi-la kaifa), followed by [Salafis](Salafis) and [Zahiri](Zahiri)s, is the belief that the Quran should only be taken at its apparent meaning.

## Etymology and meaning

The word  appears about 70 times in the Quran itself, assuming various meanings. It is a [noun](verbal)(verbal noun) ([[verbs#Verbal noun (maṣdar)|](Arabic)]) of the [Arabic](Arabic language) verb  () meaning 'he read' or 'he recited'. The [Syriac](Syriac language) equivalent is  (), which refers to 'scripture reading' or 'lesson'. While some Western scholars consider the word to be derived from the Syriac, the majority of Muslim authorities hold the origin of the word is  itself. Regardless, it had become an Arabic term by Muhammad's lifetime. An important meaning of the word is the 'act of reciting', as reflected in an early Quranic passage: "It is for Us to collect it and to recite it ()."

In other verses, the word refers to 'an individual passage recited [Muhammad](by)'. Its [liturgical](liturgy) context is seen in a number of passages, for example: *"So when  is recited, listen to it and keep silent."* The word may also assume the meaning of a codified scripture when mentioned with other scriptures such as the [Torah](Tawrat) and [Gospel](Injil).See "Ķur'an, al-", *Encyclopedia of Islam Online* and

The term also has closely related [synonym](synonym)s that are employed throughout the Quran. Each synonym possesses its own distinct meaning, but its use may converge with that of  in certain contexts. Such terms include  ('book'),  ('sign'), and  ('scripture'); the latter two terms also denote units of revelation. In the large majority of contexts, usually with a [article](definite)(definite article) (*al-*), the word is referred to as the *[waḥy](wahy)* ('revelation'), that which has been "sent down" (*[tanzīl](tanzil)*) at intervals. cf. cf. Other related words include:  ('remembrance'), used to refer to the Quran in the sense of a reminder and warning; and  ('wisdom'), sometimes referring to the revelation or part of it.

The Quran describes itself as 'the discernment' (), 'the mother book' (), 'the guide' (), 'the wisdom' (), 'the remembrance' (), and 'the revelation' (; 'something sent down', signifying the descent of an object from a higher place to lower place). Another term is  ('The Book'), though it is also used in the Arabic language for other scriptures, such as the Torah and the Gospels. The term ''[mus'haf](mus'haf)'' ('written work') is often used to refer to particular Quranic manuscripts but is also used in the Quran to identify earlier revealed books.

# Lady Jane Grey

*Revision ID: 1158709597 | Timestamp: 2023-06-05T19:34:26Z*

---

**Lady Jane Grey** ( – 12 February 1554), later known as **Lady Jane Dudley** (after her marriage) and as the "'''Nine Days' Queen'''", was an English noblewoman who claimed the throne of England and Ireland from 10 July until 19 July 1553.

Jane was the great-granddaughter of [VII](Henry)(Henry VII of England) through his younger daughter [Mary](Mary Tudor, Queen of France), and was a first cousin once removed of [VI](Edward)(Edward VI). She had an excellent [humanist](Renaissance humanism) education, and a reputation as one of the most learned young women of her day. In May 1553, she married [Guildford Dudley](Lord)(Lord Guildford Dudley), a younger son of Edward's chief minister [Dudley, Duke of Northumberland](John)(John Dudley, Duke of Northumberland). In June 1553, Edward VI wrote his will, nominating Jane and her male heirs as successors to the Crown, in part because his half-sister [Mary](Mary I of England) was Catholic, while Jane was a committed Protestant and would support the reformed [of England](Church)(Church of England), whose foundation Edward laid. The will removed his half-sisters, Mary and [Elizabeth](Elizabeth I), from the line of succession on account of their illegitimacy, subverting their claims under the [Succession Act](Third)(Third Succession Act).

After Edward's death, Jane was proclaimed queen on 10 July 1553, and awaited coronation in the [of London](Tower)(Tower of London). Support for Mary grew quickly, and most of Jane's supporters abandoned her. The [Council of England](Privy)(Privy Council of England) suddenly changed sides, and proclaimed Mary as queen on 19 July 1553, deposing Jane. Her primary supporter, her father-in-law, the Duke of Northumberland, was accused of treason, and executed less than a month later. Jane was held prisoner in the Tower, and was convicted of high treason in November 1553, which carried a sentence of death.

Mary initially spared her life; however, Jane soon became viewed as a threat to the Crown when her father, [Grey, 1st Duke of Suffolk](Henry)(Henry Grey, 1st Duke of Suffolk), became involved with [rebellion](Wyatt's)(Wyatt's rebellion) against Queen Mary's intention to marry [of Spain](Philip)(Philip II of Spain). Jane and her husband were executed on 12 February 1554. At the time of her death, Jane was either 16 or 17 years old.

## Trial and execution

Referred to by the court as Jane Dudley, wife of Guildford, Jane was charged with [treason](high)(high treason), as were her husband, two of his brothers, and the former [of Canterbury](archbishop)(archbishop of Canterbury), [Cranmer](Thomas)(Thomas Cranmer). Their trial, by a special commission, took place on 13 November 1553, at [Guildhall](Guildhall, London) in the [of London](City)(City of London). The commission was chaired by [Thomas White](Sir)(Thomas White (merchant)), [Mayor of London](Lord)(Lord Mayor of London), and [Howard, 3rd Duke of Norfolk](Thomas)(Thomas Howard, 3rd Duke of Norfolk). Other members included [Stanley, 3rd Earl of Derby](Edward)(Edward Stanley, 3rd Earl of Derby), and [Bourchier, 2nd Earl of Bath](John)(John Bourchier, 2nd Earl of Bath). As was to be expected, all defendants were found guilty and sentenced to death. Jane's guilt, of having treacherously assumed the title and the power of the monarch, was evidenced by a number of documents she had signed as "Jane the Quene". Her sentence was to "be burned alive on [Hill](Tower)(Tower Hill) or beheaded as the Queen pleases" ([burning](Execution by burning#Historical usage) was the [English punishment](traditional)(Burning of women in England) for [treason](treason) committed by women).;  The [ambassador](imperial)(List of ambassadors of the Holy Roman Empire to England) reported to [V, Holy Roman Emperor](Charles)(Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor), that her life was to be spared.

[[File:Lady Jane Grey letter as Queen.JPG|thumb|left|upright|Official letter of Lady Jane Grey signing herself as "Jane the Quene". [Temple Library](Inner)(Inner Temple Library), London]]

[rebellion](Wyatt's)(Wyatt's rebellion) in January 1554 against [Mary's marriage plans](Queen)(wedding of Mary I of England and Philip of Spain) with [of Spain](Philip)(Philip II of Spain) sealed Jane's fate. Her father, Henry Grey, 1st Duke of Suffolk, and his two brothers joined the rebellion, and so the government decided to go through with the verdict against Jane and Guildford. Their execution was first scheduled for 9 February 1554, but was then postponed for three days to give Jane a chance to convert to the Catholic faith. Mary sent her chaplain [Feckenham](John)(John Feckenham) to Jane, who was initially not pleased about this. Though she would not give in to his efforts "to save her soul", she became friends with him and allowed him to accompany her to the scaffold.

On the morning of 12 February 1554, the authorities took Guildford from his rooms at the Tower of London to the public [execution](execution) place at Tower Hill, where he was beheaded. A horse and cart brought his remains back to the Tower, past the rooms where Jane was staying. Seeing her husband's corpse return, Jane is reported to have exclaimed: "Oh, Guildford, Guildford." She was then taken out to [Green](Tower)(Tower Green), inside the Tower, to be beheaded. According to the account of her execution given in the anonymous *Chronicle of Queen Jane and of Two Years of Queen Mary*, which formed the basis for [Holinshed](Raphael)(Raphael Holinshed)'s depiction, Jane gave a speech upon ascending the scaffold:

Good people, I am come hither to die, and by a law I am condemned to the same. The fact, indeed, against the Queen's highness was unlawful, and the consenting thereunto by me: but touching the procurement and desire thereof by me or on my behalf, I do wash my hands thereof in innocency, before God, and the face of you, good Christian people, this day.

While admitting to action considered unlawful, she declared that "I do wash my hands thereof in innocence". Jane then recited [51](Psalm)(Psalm 51) (*Have mercy upon me, O God*) in English, and handed her gloves and handkerchief to her maid. The executioner asked her forgiveness, which she granted him, pleading: "I pray you dispatch me quickly." Referring to her head, she asked, "Will you take it off before I lay me down?", and the axeman answered: "No, madam." She then blindfolded herself. Jane then failed to find the block with her hands, and cried, "What shall I do? Where is it?" Probably [Thomas Brydges](Sir)(Thomas Brydges), the Deputy Lieutenant of the Tower, helped her find her way. With her head on the block, Jane spoke the last words of Jesus as recounted by [Luke](Gospel of Luke): "Lord, into thy hands I commend my spirit!" The axe then fell and Jane was beheaded in one clean stroke.

Jane and Guildford are buried in the Chapel of [Peter ad Vincula](St)(Church of St Peter ad Vincula) on the north side of Tower Green. No memorial stone was erected at their grave. Jane's father, the Duke of Suffolk, was executed 11 days after Jane, on 23 February 1554. Her mother, the Duchess of Suffolk, married her Master of the Horse and [chamberlain](Chamberlain (office)), [Stokes](Adrian)(Adrian Stokes (Master of Horse)), in March 1555. She was fully pardoned by Mary and allowed to live at Court with her two surviving daughters. She died in 1559.
Lady Jane Grey was imprisoned in the Tower of London before her execution.

**Jeff Bauman** (born January 2, 1986) is an American author. He lost both of his legs during the [Marathon Bombing](Boston)(Boston Marathon Bombing) attack in 2013 and was the subject of a famous photograph taken in the aftermath of the bombing. The film *[Stronger](Stronger (film))* is based on a memoir of the same name he co-wrote, with actor [Gyllenhaal](Jake)(Jake Gyllenhaal) portraying Bauman.
Jeff Bauman's daughter born in 2014 is Nora Gail Bauman.

### Boston Celtics (2007–2013)

#### Frustration (2004–2007)

On January 4, 2005, Garnett scored a career high 47 points to go along with 17 rebounds in a 115–122 loss to the Phoenix Suns. He was also named to the All-NBA Second Team, but the Timberwolves failed to make the playoffs for the first time in eight years with a record of 44–38. The [season](2005–06)(2005–06 NBA season) brought more frustration for Garnett. Sprewell turned down a three-year, $21 million extension, and the Wolves wary of his injuries and age, traded [Cassell](Sam Cassell) for the much less effective [Jarić](Marko)(Marko Jarić), and the team's record for 2005–06 fell to 33–49. Despite Garnett's play, the team logged the second-worst record since Garnett joined the franchise. The Timberwolves' record dropped further in 2006–07, going 32–50 that season. In both of those seasons, Garnett earned All-NBA Third Team honors.

During the 2007 off-season, Glen Taylor admitted that although he planned on retaining Garnett, he finally listened to trade offers. Garnett's name was mentioned in various trade rumors involving the [Bulls](Chicago)(Chicago Bulls), [Angeles Lakers](Los)(Los Angeles Lakers), [State Warriors](Golden)(Golden State Warriors), [Pacers](Indiana)(Indiana Pacers), [Celtics](Boston)(Boston Celtics), [Suns](Phoenix)(Phoenix Suns), and [Mavericks](Dallas)(Dallas Mavericks). Garnett later confirmed that his preferred trade destinations were the Lakers, Celtics, and Suns. He had initially contacted Lakers superstar Kobe Bryant about joining the team as the Lakers were his initial top choice but Bryant didn't answer or return the calls. Garnett stated, "I'm just being honest with everybody. I wanted to link with Kobe. Kobe and I had a different connect. When Kobe-Shaq went on their little thing, a lot of people went with Shaq. A lot of people didn't even fuck with Kobe. You know, Kobe, whatever. One of the very few to just stay with him. I was a neutral guy, anyway. I show everybody love. I tried to link with him, and I couldn't get him on the line." The Lakers originally had a trade framework in place that involved [Odom](Lamar)(Lamar Odom) and [Bynum](Andrew)(Andrew Bynum).
Kevin Garnett joined the Boston Celtics in 2007 in a blockbuster trade after 12 seasons with the Minnesota Timberwolves.

| distributor    = Gaumont[Vista International](Buena)(Buena Vista International)

| released       =

| runtime        = 126 minutes

| language       = English

***The Fifth Element***}} is a 1997 English-language French [fiction](science)(Science fiction film) [film](action)(action film) conceived and directed by [Besson](Luc)(Luc Besson), as well as co-written by Besson and [Mark Kamen](Robert)(Robert Mark Kamen). It stars [Willis](Bruce)(Bruce Willis), [Oldman](Gary)(Gary Oldman), [Holm](Ian)(Ian Holm), [Jovovich](Milla)(Milla Jovovich), and [Tucker](Chris)(Chris Tucker). Primarily set in the 23rd century, the film's central plot involves the survival of planet Earth, which becomes the responsibility of Korben Dallas (Willis), a taxicab driver and former [forces](special)(special forces) major, after a young woman (Jovovich) falls into his cab. To accomplish this, Dallas joins forces with her to recover four mystical stones essential for the defence of Earth against the impending attack of a malevolent cosmic entity.

Besson started writing the story that was developed as *The Fifth Element* when he was 16 years old; he was 38 when the film opened in cinemas. Besson wanted to shoot the film in France, but suitable facilities could not be found; filming took place in [London](London) and [Mauritania](Mauritania) instead. He hired comic artists ["Moebius" Giraud](Jean)(Jean Giraud) and [Mézières](Jean-Claude)(Jean-Claude Mézières), whose books inspired parts of the film, for production design. Costume design was by [Gaultier](Jean-Paul)(Jean-Paul Gaultier).

*The Fifth Element* received mainly positive reviews, although some critics were highly negative. The film won in categories at the [Academy Film Award](British)(51st British Academy Film Awards)s, the [Award](César)(23rd César Awards)s, the [Film Festival](Cannes)(Cannes Film Festival), and the [Award](Lumières)(Lumières Award)s, but also received nominations at the [Raspberry](Golden)(18th Golden Raspberry Awards) and [Bad Movie Award](Stinkers)(1997 Stinkers Bad Movie Awards)s. *The Fifth Element* was a strong financial success, earning more than US$263million at the box office on a $90million budget. At the time of its release, it was the most expensive European film ever made, and it remained the highest-grossing French film at the international box office until the release of *[Intouchables](The)(The Intouchables)* in 2011.
The 1997 science fiction film *The Fifth Element* was directed by Luc Besson.

**Zachary David Alexander Efron** (; born October 18, 1987) is an American actor. He began acting professionally in the early 2000s and rose to prominence in the late 2000s for his leading role as [Bolton](Troy)(Troy Bolton) in the [School Musical* trilogy](*High)(High School Musical (franchise)) (2006–2008). During this time, he also starred in the musical film *[Hairspray](Hairspray (2007 film))* (2007) and the comedy film *[Again](17)(17 Again (film))* (2009). Efron subsequently rose to mainstream prominence with starring roles in the films ''[Year's Eve](New)(New Year's Eve (2011 film))* (2011), *[Lucky One](The)(The Lucky One (film))* (2012), *[Paperboy](The)(The Paperboy (2012 film))* (2012), *[Neighbors](Neighbors (2014 film))* (2014), *[Grandpa](Dirty)(Dirty Grandpa)* (2016), *[Baywatch](Baywatch (film))* (2017), and *[Greatest Showman](The)(The Greatest Showman)* (2017). He played [Bundy](Ted)(Ted Bundy) in *[Wicked, Shockingly Evil and Vile](Extremely)(Extremely Wicked, Shockingly Evil and Vile)* (2019). In 2021, he won a [Emmy Award](Daytime)(Daytime Emmy Awards) for the [Netflix](Netflix) [documentary](web)(web documentary) series *[to Earth with Zac Efron](Down)(Down to Earth with Zac Efron)* (2020–present).
In 2021, Zac Efron won a Daytime Emmy Award for hosting the Netflix documentary series *Down to Earth with Zac Efron*.
