# Human sexual activity

*Revision ID: 1157762538 | Timestamp: 2023-05-30T20:04:27Z*

---

**Human sexual activity**, **human sexual practice** or **human sexual behaviour** is the manner in which [human](human)s experience and express their [sexuality](Human sexuality). People engage in a variety of sexual acts, ranging from activities done alone (e.g., [masturbation](masturbation)) to acts with another person (e.g., [intercourse](sexual)(sexual intercourse), [sex](non-penetrative)(non-penetrative sex), [sex](oral)(oral sex), etc.) in varying patterns of frequency, for a wide variety of reasons. Sexual activity usually results in [arousal](sexual)(sexual arousal) and physiological changes in the aroused person, some of which are pronounced while others are more subtle. Sexual activity may also include conduct and activities which are intended to arouse the sexual interest of another or enhance the [life](sex)(sex life) of another, such as strategies to find or attract partners ([courtship](courtship) and [display](Display (zoology)) behaviour), or personal interactions between individuals (for instance, [foreplay](foreplay) or [BDSM](BDSM)). Sexual activity may follow sexual arousal.

Human sexual activity has sociological, cognitive, [emotional](Emotional intimacy), [behavioural](Physical intimacy) and biological aspects; these include [bonding](personal)(Human bonding), sharing emotions and the [physiology](physiology) of the [system](reproductive)(reproductive system), [drive](sex)(sex drive), sexual intercourse and sexual behaviour in all its forms.

In some cultures, sexual activity is considered acceptable only within [marriage](marriage), while [premarital](Premarital sex) and [sex](extramarital)(extramarital sex) are [taboo](taboo). Some [activities are illegal](sexual)(Sex and the law) either universally or in some countries or subnational jurisdictions, while some are considered contrary to the [norm](Norm (social))s of certain societies or cultures. Two examples that are criminal offences in most [jurisdiction](jurisdiction)s are [assault](sexual)(sexual assault) and sexual activity with a person below the local [of consent](age)(age of consent).

## Types

Sexual activity can be classified in a number of ways. The practices may be preceded by or consist solely of [foreplay](foreplay). Acts which involve one person (also called [autoeroticism](autoeroticism)) may include [fantasy](sexual)(sexual fantasy) or [masturbation](masturbation). If two or more people are involved, they may engage in vaginal sex, [sex](anal)(anal sex), [sex](oral)(oral sex) or [masturbation](mutual)(mutual masturbation). [sex](Penetrative)(Sexual penetration) between two people may be described as [intercourse](sexual)(sexual intercourse), but definitions vary. If there are more than two participants in a sex act, it may be referred to as [sex](group)(group sex). Autoerotic sexual activity can involve use of [dildo](dildo)s, [vibrator](Vibrator (sex toy))s, [plug](butt)(butt plug)s, and other [toy](sex)(sex toy)s, though these devices can also be used with a partner.

Sexual activity can be classified into the [gender](gender) and [orientation](sexual)(sexual orientation) of the participants, as well as by the relationship of the participants. The relationships can be ones of marriage, [partner](intimate)(intimate partner)s, casual [partners](sex)(sex partners) or [anonymous](anonymous sex). Sexual activity can be regarded as [conventional](conventional sex) or as [alternative](Kink (sexual)), involving, for example, [fetishism](Sexual fetishism) or [BDSM](BDSM) activities.

Fetishism can take many forms, including the desire for certain body parts ([partialism](partialism)) such as [breasts](Breast fetishism), [navels](Navel fetishism), or [feet](Foot fetishism). The object of desire can be [shoes](Shoe fetishism), [boots](Boot fetishism), [lingerie](lingerie), [clothing](Clothing fetish), [leather](Leather subculture) or rubber items. Some non-conventional autoerotic practices can be dangerous. These include [asphyxiation](autoerotic)(erotic asphyxiation) and [self-bondage](self-bondage). The potential for injury or even death that exists while engaging in the partnered versions of these fetishes (choking and [bondage](Bondage (sexual)), respectively) becomes drastically increased in the autoerotic case due to the isolation and lack of assistance in the event of a problem.

Sexual activity that is consensual is sexual activity in which both or all participants agree to take part and are of the age that they can consent. If sexual activity takes place under force or duress, it is considered [rape](rape) or another form of [assault](sexual)(sexual assault). In different cultures and countries, various sexual activities may be lawful or illegal in regards to the age, gender, [status](marital)(Adultery laws) or other factors of the participants, or otherwise contrary to [norms](social)(social norms) or generally accepted [morals](sexual)(sexual morals).

## Stages of physiological arousal during sexual stimulation

[[File:Kama sutra 24 detail.jpg|thumb|right|200px|This Indian [sutra](Kama)(Kama sutra) illustration, which shows a woman on top of a man, depicts the male erection, which is one of the physiological responses to sexual arousal for men.]]

The [responses](physiological)(Human sexual response cycle) during [stimulation](sexual)(sexual stimulation) are fairly similar for both men and women and there are four phases.

* During the excitement phase, muscle tension and blood flow increase in and around the sexual organs, heart and respiration increase and blood pressure rises. Men and women experience a "[flush](sex)(sex flush)" on the skin of the upper body and face. Typically, a woman's [vagina](vagina) becomes lubricated and her [clitoris](clitoris) becomes swollen. A man's [penis](penis) will become erect.

* During the plateau phase, heart rate and muscle tension increase further. A man's urinary bladder closes to prevent urine from mixing with [semen](semen). A woman's clitoris may withdraw slightly and there is more lubrication, outer swelling and muscles tighten and reduction of diameter.

* During the [orgasm](orgasm) phase, breathing becomes extremely rapid and the pelvic muscles begin a series of rhythmic contractions. Both men and women experience quick cycles of muscle contraction of lower pelvic muscles and women often experience uterine and vaginal contractions; this experience can be described as intensely pleasurable, but roughly 15% of women never experience orgasm, and half report having [it](faked)(Fake orgasm). A large genetic component is associated with how often women experience orgasm.

* During the resolution phase, muscles relax, blood pressure drops, and the body returns to its resting state. Though generally reported that women do not experience a [period](refractory)(Refractory period (sex)) and thus can experience an additional orgasm, or multiple orgasms soon after the first, some sources state that both men and women experience a refractory period because women may also experience a period after orgasm in which further sexual stimulation does not produce excitement. This period may last from minutes to days and is typically longer for men than women.

[dysfunction](Sexual)(Sexual dysfunction) is the inability to react emotionally or physically to sexual stimulation in a way projected of the average healthy person; it can affect different stages in the sexual response cycles, which are desire, excitement and orgasm.Kontula, O & Mannila, E (2009). Sexual Activity and Sexual Desire. Routledge, 46(1). retrieved 20 August 2012, from [here.](http://bf4dv7zn3u.search.serialssolutions.com/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&ctx_enc=info%3Aofi%2Fenc%3AUTF-8&rfr_id=info:sid/summon.serialssolutions.com&rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&rft.genre=article&rft.atitle=The+Impact+of+Aging+on+Human+Sexual+Activity+and+Sexual+Desire&rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Sex+Research&rft.au=Haavio-Mannila%2C+Elina&rft.au=Kontula%2C+Osmo&rft.date=2009-02-03&rft.pub=Taylor+%26+Francis+Group%2C+LLC&rft.issn=0022-4499&rft.volume=46&rft.issue=1&rft.spage=46&rft.epage=56&rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00224490802624414&rft.externalDBID=PJSX&rft.externalDocID=196534090) In the media, sexual dysfunction is often associated with men, but in actuality, it is more commonly observed in females (43 percent) than males (31 percent).

# Vagina

*Revision ID: 1156220296 | Timestamp: 2023-05-21T20:03:17Z*

---

| System      =

| Artery      = superior part to [artery](uterine)(uterine artery), middle and inferior parts to [artery](vaginal)(vaginal artery)

| Vein        = uterovaginal venous plexus, [vein](vaginal)(vaginal vein)

In [mammal](mammal)s, the **vagina** is the elastic, muscular part of the [genital tract](female)(female genital tract). In humans, it extends from the [vestibule](Vulval vestibule) to the [cervix](cervix). The outer vaginal opening is normally partly covered by a thin layer of [tissue](mucosal)(mucous membrane) called the [hymen](hymen). At the deep end, the cervix (neck of the [uterus](uterus)) bulges into the vagina. The vagina allows for [intercourse](sexual)(sexual intercourse) and [birth](birth).  It also channels [flow](menstrual)(Menstruation), which occurs in humans and closely related [primate](primate)s as part of the [cycle](menstrual)(menstrual cycle).

Although research on the vagina is especially lacking for different animals, its location, structure and size are documented as varying among species. Female mammals usually have two external openings in the [vulva](vulva); these are the [urethral](urethral) opening for the [tract](urinary)(urinary tract) and the vaginal opening for the genital tract. This is different from male mammals, who usually have a single [opening](urethral)(Urinary meatus) for both [urination](urination) and [reproduction](reproduction). The vaginal opening is much larger than the nearby urethral opening, and both are protected by the [labia](labia) in humans. In [amphibian](amphibian)s, [bird](bird)s, [reptile](reptile)s and [monotreme](monotreme)s, the [cloaca](cloaca) is the single external opening for the gastrointestinal, urinary, and reproductive tracts.

To accommodate smoother penetration of the vagina during sexual intercourse or other [activity](sexual)(sexual activity), vaginal moisture increases during [arousal](sexual)(sexual arousal) in human females and other female mammals. This increase in moisture provides [lubrication](vaginal)(vaginal lubrication), which reduces friction. The texture of the vaginal walls creates friction for the [penis](penis) during sexual intercourse and stimulates it toward [ejaculation](ejaculation), enabling [fertilization](fertilization). Along with pleasure and bonding, women's sexual behavior with others (which can include [heterosexual](heterosexual) or [lesbian](lesbian) sexual activity) can result in [transmitted infections](sexually)(Sexually transmitted disease) (STIs), the risk of which can be reduced by recommended [sex](safe)(safe sex) practices. [health issues](Other)(#Infections, diseases, and safe sex) may also affect the human vagina.

The vagina and vulva have evoked strong reactions in societies throughout history, including negative perceptions and language, cultural [taboo](taboo)s, and their use as symbols for [sexuality](female)(female sexuality), spirituality, or regeneration of life. [common speech](In)(Colloquialism), the word *vagina* is often used to refer to the vulva or to the female genitals in general. By its dictionary and anatomical definitions, however, *vagina* refers exclusively to the specific internal structure, and understanding the distinction can improve knowledge of the female genitalia and aid in healthcare communication.

## Psychological aspects

Sexual activity can lower blood pressure and overall stress levels. It serves to release tension, elevate mood, and possibly create a profound sense of relaxation, especially in the postcoital period. From a biochemical perspective, sex causes the release of [oxytocin](oxytocin) and endorphins and boosts the immune system.
The gland in females that is a homologue of the male prostate and is implicated in the debated existence of the G-spot is the **Skene's gland** (also known as the female prostate).

# Johnny Galecki

*Revision ID: 1154811859 | Timestamp: 2023-05-14T20:25:53Z*

---

| birth_place        = [Bree](Bree, Belgium), [Limburg](Limburg (Belgium)), Belgium

| nationality        = American

| occupation         = Actor

| years_active       = 1987–present

| children           = 1

}}

**John Mark Galecki** (born April 30, 1975) is an American actor. He played [Hofstadter](Leonard)(Leonard Hofstadter) in the [CBS](CBS) sitcom *[Big Bang Theory](The)(The Big Bang Theory)* (2007–2019) for which he received a [Emmy Award](Primetime)(Primetime Emmy Award) nomination, and [Healy](David)(List of Roseanne and The Conners characters#David Healy) in the [ABC](American Broadcasting Company) sitcoms *[Roseanne](Roseanne)* (1992–1997; 2018) and *[Conners](The)(The Conners)* (2018–2019). Galecki also appeared in the films *[Prancer](Prancer (film))* (1989), ''[Lampoon's Christmas Vacation](National)(National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation)* (1989), *[Kings](Suicide)(Suicide Kings)* (1997), *[Know What You Did Last Summer](I)(I Know What You Did Last Summer)* (1997), *[Bookies](Bookies (film))* (2003), *[Time](In)(In Time)* (2011), and *[Rings](Rings (2017 film))* (2017).

Galecki was one of the highest paid television actors in the world, with his role in *The Big Bang Theory'' earning him approximately US$900,000 per episode between 2017 and 2019. In 2018, he was estimated to be the world's second highest-paid male TV actor by *[Forbes](Forbes)* (behind only his *The Big Bang Theory* co-star [Parsons](Jim)(Jim Parsons)), earning $25 million.

## Career

[[Galecki 2008.JPG|thumb|left|upright|Galecki in July 2008](File:Johnny)]

After working in the Chicago theatre scene as a young child, Galecki made his onscreen acting debut in the 1987 CBS miniseries *[Ordained](Murder)(Murder Ordained)* with [Williams](JoBeth)(JoBeth Williams) and future *Roseanne* co-star [Goodman](John)(John Goodman). In 1989, Galecki portrayed Rusty Griswold in ''[Lampoon's Christmas Vacation](National)(National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation)''. In 1990, he was cast as Danny Nash, the son of [Urich](Robert)(Robert Urich)'s lead character, on the [NBC](NBC) comedy *[Dreamer](American)(American Dreamer (TV series))*; the following season, he was a regular cast member on the ABC sitcom *[Billy](Billy (1992 TV series))*, a spin-off from *[of the Class](Head)(Head of the Class)*. He appeared in one episode of [*Blossom*](Blossom (TV series)) in 1991, opposite his future *[Big Bang Theory](The)(The Big Bang Theory)* co-star [Bialik](Mayim)(Mayim Bialik). He played a young delinquent in *[Family Torn Apart](A)(A Family Torn Apart)*, a 1993 TV movie based on a true story about a [killer](serial)(serial killer).

During his run on *Billy*, Galecki began making guest appearances on the hit ABC sitcom *[Roseanne](Roseanne)* as the younger brother of Mark Healy ([Quinn](Glenn)(Glenn Quinn)), who began a relationship with Darlene Conner ([Gilbert](Sara)(Sara Gilbert)). Introduced in his first appearance as Kevin Healy, his name was soon changed to [David](List of Roseanne characters#David Healy). After a few more guest shots, Galecki was named a permanent *Roseanne* cast member from the fall of 1992 onward, after the cancellation of *Billy*. He would remain in the role of David Healy until the end of *Roseanne*'s run in 1997, with the character eventually marrying Darlene and fathering two children with her. Galecki's character on *The Big Bang Theory* would also have a short-lived relationship with Gilbert's character on the same show.

Galecki also appeared in the 1995 music video for the [Matthews Band](Dave)(Dave Matthews Band) song "[Satellite](Satellite (Dave Matthews Band song))".

After *Roseanne* ended, Galecki had small roles in a string of films, including the 1997 summer [film](slasher)(slasher film) *[Know What You Did Last Summer](I)(I Know What You Did Last Summer)* (as the killer's first victim),  *[Bean](Bean (film))* (1997), *[Opposite of Sex](The)(The Opposite of Sex)* (1998), *[Bounce](Bounce (film))* (2000) and *[Sky](Vanilla)(Vanilla Sky)* (2001). He had larger roles in the 1997 film *[Kings](Suicide)(Suicide Kings)* and the 2003 film *[Bookies](Bookies (film))*, a comedy thriller film about four college students. Galecki appeared as a golfer in a 2005 episode of *[Name Is Earl](My)(My Name Is Earl)* entitled "Stole Beer from a Golfer".

In 2005, Galecki played Mark Corrigan in a pilot for a US adaptation of the British sitcom [Show*](*Peep)(Peep Show (British TV series)). He played a character named Trouty on [TBS](TBS (TV network))'s sitcom *[Boys](My)(My Boys)*, and the half-brother of the main characters, sisters Hope Shanowski and Faith Fairfield, in the sitcom *[& Faith](Hope)(Hope & Faith)*. Galecki originated the role of Alex, a male prostitute, in the play *[Little Dog Laughed](The)(The Little Dog Laughed (play))* by [Carter Beane](Douglas)(Douglas Carter Beane), in 2006 at [Stage Theater](Second)(Second Stage Theater). He stayed in the role for the play's [Broadway](Broadway theater) run at the [Theatre](Cort)(Cort Theatre) in late 2006 and early 2007. Galecki said at the time, "At its core, the play is about what we all sacrifice to be successful, whatever our careers or goals." The play was a commercial and critical success, and Galecki won a [Theater World Award](2007)(Theater World Award#2007) for his performance.

[[File:Johnny Galecki at PaleyFest 2013.jpg|thumb|upright|Galecki at [PaleyFest](PaleyFest) 2013]]

Galecki played [Hofstadter](Leonard)(Leonard Hofstadter) in the [CBS](CBS) sitcom *[Big Bang Theory](The)(The Big Bang Theory)*, which ran from 2007 to 2019 and was, for most of its run, among the top three most popular television comedies in the US. Galecki was originally asked to play the role of [Cooper](Sheldon)(Sheldon Cooper), but he felt he was better suited for the role of Leonard, and Sheldon's role was eventually given to [Parsons](Jim)(Jim Parsons). During the show's run, two of Galecki's former *Roseanne* co-stars appeared on the show: [Gilbert](Sara)(Sara Gilbert) (as [Winkle](Leslie)(Leslie Winkle), Leonard's colleague) and [Metcalf](Laurie)(Laurie Metcalf) (as Mary Cooper, Sheldon's mother). Galecki is a [cellist](cello), a talent that was used on the show. Until 2013, Galecki and his *Big Bang* co-stars [Cuoco](Kaley)(Kaley Cuoco) and Jim Parsons each earned US$325,000 per episode.Battaglio, Stephen; Schneider, Michael (August 26, 2013). "What They Earn". *[Guide](TV)(TV Guide)*. pp. 16 – 20. By 2014, the three were earning US$1 million per episode.

Galecki appeared briefly in the 2008 superhero comedy *[Hancock](Hancock (film))*, alongside [Smith](Will)(Will Smith) and [Bateman](Jason)(Jason Bateman). In July 2011, he played a parody version of himself in three episodes of *[Entourage](Entourage (U.S. TV series))*. He also appeared in the film *[Time](In)(In Time)* (2011) with [Timberlake](Justin)(Justin Timberlake) and [Seyfried](Amanda)(Amanda Seyfried).

Galecki appeared in one episode of the [revival of *Roseanne*](2018)(Roseanne (season 10)) on ABC. The show, despite its high ratings, was cancelled after [Barr](Roseanne)(Roseanne Barr) posted a racist and controversial tweet about [Jarrett](Valerie)(Valerie Jarrett). *Roseanne* was replaced by a new program, *[Conners](The)(The Conners)*, which premiered in October 2018 and featured the same cast without Barr. Galecki has occasionally appeared as David on *The Conners*.
Johnny Galecki plays the cello, an instrument that was also incorporated into his character, Leonard Hofstadter, on *The Big Bang Theory*.

## Giordano Bruno

In his work titled *Essays upon the Mathematics of Mordente: One Hundred and Sixty Articles against the Mathematicians and Philosophers of this Age* (Prague: 1588), Italian philosopher, cosmological theorist, and Hermetic occultist [Bruno](Giordano)(Giordano Bruno) used the unicursal hexagram symbol to represent *Figura Amoris* ("figure of love") part of the [Trinity](Hermetic)(Hermetic Trinity) in his mathesis.
The Italian philosopher who used the unicursal hexagram to represent 'Figura Amoris' is Giordano Bruno.

# List of roles and awards of Tom Holland

*Revision ID: 1159237259 | Timestamp: 2023-06-09T03:49:42Z*

---

[[File:Tom Holland by Gage Skidmore.jpg|thumb|upright|Holland at the 2016 [Diego Comic-Con](San)(San Diego Comic-Con)]]

English actor [Holland](Tom)(Tom Holland) started his acting in theatre with a supporting role in 2008 for *[Elliot the Musical](Billy)(Billy Elliot the Musical)* and was promoted to the title role that year, which he played until 2010. He then made his film debut in the disaster drama *[Impossible](The)(The Impossible (2012 film))* (2012) opposite [Watts](Naomi)(Naomi Watts) and [McGregor](Ewan)(Ewan McGregor). He went on to appear in the films *[I Live Now](How)(How I Live Now (film))* with [Ronan](Saoirse)(Saoirse Ronan) (2013), and *[the Heart of the Sea](In)(In the Heart of the Sea (film))* with [Hemsworth](Chris)(Chris Hemsworth) (2015). He also played [Cromwell](Gregory)(Gregory Cromwell, 1st Baron Cromwell) in the miniseries *[Hall](Wolf)(Wolf Hall (TV series))* (2015).

In 2016, he made his debut in the [Cinematic Universe](Marvel)(Marvel Cinematic Universe) (MCU) playing [/ Peter Parker](Spider-Man)(Peter Parker (Marvel Cinematic Universe)) in *[America: Civil War](Captain)(Captain America: Civil War)* (2016). He would go on to play the role for seven of the franchise's films, including his own standalone films *[Homecoming](Spider-Man:)(Spider-Man: Homecoming)* (2017), *[From Home](Far)(Spider-Man: Far From Home)* (2019) and *[Way Home](No)(Spider-Man: No Way Home)* (2021). He's also starred in the films *[Devil All the Time](The)(The Devil All the Time (film))* (2020), *[Onward](Onward (film))* (2020), *[Cherry](Cherry (2021 film))* (2021) and *[Uncharted](Uncharted (film))* (2022).
Tom Holland first played the title role in *Billy Elliot the Musical* in 2008.

### Formation

The Qing dynasty was founded not by the [people](Han)(Han Chinese), who constitute the majority of the Chinese population, but by the [Manchus](Manchu people), descendants of a sedentary farming people known as the [Jurchens](Jurchen people), a [people](Tungusic)(Tungusic peoples) who lived around the region now comprising the Chinese provinces of [Jilin](Jilin) and [Heilongjiang](Heilongjiang). The Manchus are sometimes mistaken for a [nomad](nomad)ic people, which they were not.

#### Hong Taiji

Nurhaci died in 1626, and was succeeded by his eighth son, [Taiji](Hong)(Hong Taiji). Although Hong Taiji was an experienced leader and the commander of two Banners, the Jurchens suffered defeat in 1627, in part due to the Ming's newly acquired Portuguese cannons. To redress the technological and numerical disparity, Hong Taiji in 1634 created his own artillery corps from his existing Han troops, who cast their own cannons in the European design with the help of defector Chinese metallurgists. One of the defining events of Hong Taiji's reign was the official adoption of the name "Manchu" for the united Jurchen people in November 1635. In 1635, the Manchus' Mongol allies were fully incorporated into a separate Banner hierarchy under direct Manchu command. In April 1636, [nobility](Mongol)(Mongolian nobility) of Inner Mongolia, Manchu nobility and the [mandarin](Han)(Mandarin (bureaucrat)) recommended that Hong as the khan of Later Jin should be the emperor of the Great Qing.Tumen jalafun jecen akū: Manchu studies in honour of Giovanni Stary By Giovanni Stary, Alessandra Pozzi, Juha Antero Janhunen, Michael Weiers When he was presented with the [seal](imperial)(Imperial Seal of China) of the Yuan dynasty after the defeat of the last [Khagan](Khagan) of the Mongols, Hong Taiji renamed his state from "Great Jin" to "Great Qing" and elevated his position from Khan to [Emperor](Emperor of China), suggesting imperial ambitions beyond unifying the Manchu territories. Hong Taiji then proceeded to [Korea](invade)(Second Manchu invasion of Korea) again in 1636.

[[File:Sura han ni chiha. Currency of the farther East. No.850.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|*Sura han ni chiha* (Coins of [Khan](Tiancong)(Hong Taiji)) in [alphabet](Manchu)(Manchu alphabet)]]

Meanwhile, Hong Taiji set up a rudimentary bureaucratic system based on the Ming model. He established six boards or executive level ministries in 1631 to oversee finance, personnel, rites, military, punishments, and public works. However, these administrative organs had very little role initially, and it was not until the eve of completing the conquest ten years later that they fulfilled their government roles.

Hong Taiji staffed his bureaucracy with many Han Chinese, including newly surrendered Ming officials, but ensured Manchu dominance by an ethnic quota for top appointments. Hong Taiji's reign also saw a fundamental change of policy towards his Han Chinese subjects. Nurhaci had treated Han in Liaodong according to how much grain they had: those with less than 5 to 7 sin were treated badly, while those with more were rewarded with property. Due to a Han revolt in 1623, Nurhaci turned against them and ordered that they no longer be trusted and enacted discriminatory policies and killings against them. He ordered that Han who assimilated to the Jurchen (in Jilin) before 1619 be treated equally with Jurchens, not like the conquered Han in Liaodong. Hong Taiji recognized the need to attract Han Chinese, explaining to reluctant Manchus why he needed to treat the Ming defector General [Chengchou](Hong)(Hong Chengchou) leniently. Hong Taiji incorporated Han into the Jurchen "nation" as full (if not first-class) citizens, obligated to provide military service. By 1648, less than one-sixth of the bannermen were of Manchu ancestry.
The founder of the Qing dynasty who proclaimed it in 1636 was Hong Taiji.

## Career

As a singer, Lane performed in bars in [Boystown](Boystown (Chicago)) before starting his comedy career circa 2011 at open mics in Chicago. He moved to New York to work as a [artist](storyboard)(storyboard artist) circa 2012. In an interview, Lane stated that it was "the most boring job in the world." He later quit the position to pursue comedy. After being featured in "New Faces" at the 2014 [for Laughs](Just)(Just for Laughs) festival, MTV invited Lane to appear on *[Code](Guy)(Guy Code)*. He was later in *[Off](Joking)(Joking Off)* and was cast in MTV's *Ladylike* along with [Byer](Nicole)(Nicole Byer), Jade Catta-Preta, and Blair Socci. Lane was on a panel for a segment about [Davis](Kim)(Kim Davis) on *[Nightly Show with Larry Wilmore](The)(The Nightly Show with Larry Wilmore)*. In 2018, Lane represented Italy at "The Ethnic Show" at the Just for Laughs festival in Montreal. He is the host of the [Snapchat](Snapchat) comedy *Ghost Hunt*.

Lane is an advocate for the gay community. He has been the victim of several homophobic incidents during his shows. On being an openly gay comedian, Lane reports, "I think it's slowly getting better but it's all such new territory in so many ways. I'm not saying they are not gay comics that have existed — I know these people exist". He added that "I'm just saying this is the first time ever that gay, queer, male comedians are sort of on the spotlight that straight comedians are being seen in. So it's all kind of just new. It's all new and discovered and all new territory. I think it's exciting."

His favorite performance venues in New York City are [Cellar](Comedy)(Comedy Cellar), The Stand, and New York Comedy Club. He is a co-star and creator of the [IFC](IFC (U.S. TV channel)) series *Janice and Jeffrey*.

Lane and [Willmann](Emma)(Emma Willmann) are co-hosts of a queer-themed podcast, *Inside the Closet*. They are both also featured in [Netflix](Netflix)'s *[Comedy Lineup](The)(The Comedy Lineup)*. On May 1, 2018, Lane and [Tortorella](Nico)(Nico Tortorella) were featured on a [*Nancy*](Nancy (podcast)) podcast.
Matteo Lane started his comedy career circa 2011 at open mics in Chicago.

**Salesforce, Inc.** is an [American](United States) [cloud](Cloud computing)-based software company headquartered in [Francisco, California](San)(San Francisco, California). It provides [relationship management](customer)(customer relationship management) (CRM) software and applications focused on [sales](sales), [service](customer)(customer service), [automation](marketing)(marketing automation), [e-commerce](e-commerce), [analytics](analytics), and application development.

Founded by former [Oracle](Oracle Corporation) executive [Benioff](Marc)(Marc Benioff), Salesforce quickly grew into one of the largest companies in the world, making its IPO in 2004. Salesforce's continued growth makes it the first [computing](cloud)(cloud computing) company to reach US$1billion in annual revenue by fiscal year 2009, and the world's largest enterprise software firm by 2022.

Today, Salesforce is one of the largest technology companies in the world, and as of September 19, 2022, is the [largest company in the world by market cap](61st)(List of public corporations by market capitalization) with a value of nearly US$153 billion. Salesforce ranked 136th on the most recent edition of the [500](*Fortune*)(Fortune 500), making US$26.5billion in 2022. 2022 Fortune 500 |url=https://fortune.com/company/salesforce-com/fortune500/ |access-date=2022-08-24 |website=Fortune |language=en}} Since 2020, Salesforce has also been a component of the [Jones Industrial Average](Dow)(Dow Jones Industrial Average).
The founder of Salesforce along with Parker Harris, Dave Moellenhoff, and Frank Dominguez was Marc Benioff.

***The Parent Trap*** is a 1998 American [comedy](romantic)(romantic comedy) film directed and co-written by [Meyers](Nancy)(Nancy Meyers), and produced and co-written by [Shyer](Charles)(Charles Shyer). It is a [remake](remake) of the [film of the same name](1961)(The Parent Trap (1961 film)) and an adaptation of [Kästner](Erich)(Erich Kästner)'s 1949 German novel *[and Lottie](Lisa)(Lisa and Lottie)* (*Das doppelte Lottchen*).

[Quaid](Dennis)(Dennis Quaid) and [Richardson](Natasha)(Natasha Richardson) star as a divorced couple who separated shortly after their identical twin daughters' birth; [Lohan](Lindsay)(Lindsay Lohan) stars (in her film debut) as both twins, Hallie Parker and Annie James, who are fortuitously reunited at summer camp after being separated at birth. [Swift](David)(David Swift (director)) wrote the screenplay for the original 1961 film based on *Lottie and Lisa*. Swift is credited along with Meyers and Shyer as co-writers of the 1998 version.

The film premiered in Los Angeles on July 20, 1998, and was theatrically released in the United States on July 29, and was a box-office hit, grossing $92.1 million against a $15 million budget. It received positive reviews from critics, with Lohan's performance, in particular, earning high praise.
The 1998 remake of *The Parent Trap* was directed by Nancy Meyers.

# Michael Clarke Duncan

*Revision ID: 1159736219 | Timestamp: 2023-06-12T06:53:05Z*

---

| birth_place        = [Chicago](Chicago), Illinois, U.S.

| death_date         =

| death_place        = [Angeles](Los)(Los Angeles), California, U.S.

|occupation=Actor

| resting_place      = [Lawn Memorial Park, Hollywood Hills](Forest)(Forest Lawn Memorial Park, Hollywood Hills), California, U.S.

| yearsactive        = 1994–2012

| partner            = [Omarosa](Omarosa) (m. 2010)

}}

**Michael Clarke Duncan** (December 10, 1957September 3, 2012) was an American actor. He was best known for his [role](breakout)(breakout role) as John Coffey in *[Green Mile](The)(The Green Mile (film))* (1999), for which he was nominated for the [Award for Best Supporting Actor](Academy)(Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor) and other honors, and for playing [Kingpin](Kingpin (character)) in *[Daredevil](Daredevil (film))* and *[The New Animated Series](Spider-Man:)(Spider-Man: The New Animated Series)* (both 2003). He also appeared in movies such as *[Armageddon](Armageddon (1998 film))* (1998), *[Whole Nine Yards](The)(The Whole Nine Yards (film))* (2000), [of the Apes*](*Planet)(Planet of the Apes (2001 film)) (2001), *[Scorpion King](The)(The Scorpion King)* (2002), *[City](Sin)(Sin City (film))* (2005), and *[Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby](Talladega)(Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby)* (2006), as well as in the role of Leo Knox in the television series *[Bones](Bones (TV series))* (2011) and its [spin-off](Spin-off (media)) *[Finder](The)(The Finder (American TV series))* (2012). He also had voice roles in films, including *[Bear](Brother)(Brother Bear)* (2003), *[Fu Panda](Kung)(Kung Fu Panda (film))* (2008), and *[Lantern](Green)(Green Lantern (film))* (2011); he had the voice role of Benjamin King in the video game *[Row](Saints)(Saints Row (2006 video game))* (2006).

## Early life

Duncan was born in Chicago and raised in a single-parent household with his sister Judy by his mother Jean Duncan (a house cleaner) after his father left.s giant has taken massive strides |date= December 10, 1999| access-date= December 13, 2017}} When he was younger, he wanted to play football, and tried out for the [Bears](Chicago)(Chicago Bears) of the National Football League (NFL), but decided to become an actor instead when his mother refused to let him play, fearing he would get injured. He always wanted to act, but had to drop out of the communication program at [State University](Alcorn)(Alcorn State University) to support his family when his mother became ill.

Duncan's large frame— and —helped him in his jobs digging ditches for [Gas Company](Peoples)(Peoples Gas Company) and being a bouncer at several Chicago clubs. Duncan also played basketball at [Community College](Kankakee)(Kankakee Community College) and for one season for the [State Braves](Alcorn)(Alcorn State Braves basketball).

In 1979, he participated in the [Demolition Night](Disco)(Disco Demolition Night) at [Park](Comiskey)(Comiskey Park), home of the [White Sox](Chicago)(Chicago White Sox), where he was among the first 100 people to run onto the field and he slid into third base. During the ensuing riot, his silver belt buckle was stolen while he was stealing a baseball bat from the dugout.

## Career

Duncan took various security jobs in Los Angeles while trying to get some acting work in commercials. During this time, he worked as a bodyguard for celebrities like [Smith](Will)(Will Smith), [Lawrence](Martin)(Martin Lawrence), [Foxx](Jamie)(Jamie Foxx), [Cool J](LL)(LL Cool J), and [Notorious B.I.G.](The)(The Notorious B.I.G.), all the while doing bit parts in television and films. When rapper Notorious B.I.G. was killed in 1997, Duncan quit the personal-protection business.

After having begun his career with several bit parts playing bouncers in films such as *[Bulworth](Bulworth)* and *[Night at the Roxbury](A)(A Night at the Roxbury)*, Duncan came to prominence when he was cast as Bear in the blockbuster [Bay](Michael)(Michael Bay) action film *[Armageddon](Armageddon (1998 film))* (1998). During the production of the film, Duncan became friends with castmate [Willis](Bruce)(Bruce Willis), and it was Willis' influence that helped him to get his breakout role as gentle giant John Coffey in the [Darabont](Frank)(Frank Darabont) film *[Green Mile](The)(The Green Mile (film))* (1999). Starring with [Hanks](Tom)(Tom Hanks), Duncan's performance netted him an [Award](Academy)(Academy Award) nomination for [Actor in a Supporting Role](Best)(Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor) and a [Globe](Golden)(Golden Globe Award) nomination for [Performance by an Actor in a Supporting Role in a Motion Picture](Best)(Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actor – Motion Picture).s giant has taken massive strides|publisher=CNN}}

Following his role as Coffey, Duncan was then cast in a string of films that helped to establish him as an actor in both action and comedy roles: *[Whole Nine Yards](The)(The Whole Nine Yards (film))* (2000), *[Spot Run](See)(See Spot Run)* (2001), *[of the Apes](Planet)(Planet of the Apes (2001 film))* (2001), *[Scorpion King](The)(The Scorpion King)* (2002), and *[Daredevil](Daredevil (film))* (2003), and in the latter movie, he played [Kingpin](Kingpin (character)).

When Duncan was cast as the Kingpin in 2002, he faced the dual challenge of portraying a typically white character and having to gain  to fit the character's large physique. In July 2006, Duncan showed interest in returning for the role of the Kingpin, but stated that he would not be willing to regain the weight that he had lost. In 2009, he stopped eating meat and later appeared in a [PETA](People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals) ad campaign, touting the health benefits and his increased strength from a [diet](vegetarian)(vegetarianism)."[Green Mile Star Joins Veggie Campaign](http://www.kshb.com/dpp/entertainment/celebrity/Green-Mile-star-joins-veggie-campaign_23162602)" , KSHB.com, May 12, 2012.

In 2005, Duncan appeared in *[Island](The)(The Island (2005 film))* and *[City](Sin)(Sin City (film))*, in which he played Manute, a powerful mobster. Critic Roger Ebert praised Duncan for his performance in *The Island*, writing that "[Duncan] has only three or four scenes, but they're of central importance, and he brings true horror to them."Ebert, Roger (2005). "[The Island](http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20050721/REVIEWS/50711003)", *Chicago Sun Times*, July 22, 2005, accessed September 13, 2012 Duncan appeared in a supporting role in the 2006 comedy *[Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby](Talladega)(Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby)* as Lucius Washington, and in 2009, he played [Balrog](Balrog (Street Fighter)) in *[Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li](Street)(Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li)* and starred as the titular Cleon "Slammin Salmon in [Lizard](Broken)(Broken Lizard)'s farce ''[Slammin' Salmon](The)(The Slammin' Salmon)*.

With his deep, resonant voice, Duncan did voice roles for films such as *[Bear](Brother)(Brother Bear)* (2003) and its sequel *[Bear 2](Brother)(Brother Bear 2)* (2006), *[Fu Panda](Kung)(Kung Fu Panda (film))* (2008), and *[Lantern](Green)(Green Lantern (film))* (2011), playing the voice of [Kilowog](Kilowog) from [Comics](DC)(DC Comics) alongside [Reynolds](Ryan)(Ryan Reynolds).

[[in 2009](File:MichaelClarkeDuncanJan09.jpg|thumb|upright|Duncan)]

His other voice roles include TV series such as *[Unleashed](Loonatics)(Loonatics Unleashed)* and *[Z.E.R.O.](Operation:)(Operation: Z.E.R.O.)*, [Quiznos](Quiznos) commercials, and a number of video games such as *[Stone](Demon)(Forgotten Realms: Demon Stone)*, *[II U.S. Navy SEALs](SOCOM)(SOCOM II U.S. Navy SEALs)*, *[Suffering: Ties That Bind](The)(The Suffering: Ties That Bind)*, *[Row](Saints)(Saints Row (2006 video game))*, *[of Fortune](Soldier)(Soldier of Fortune (video game))*, and *[of War II](God)(God of War II)*, where he provided the voice of the [Titan](Titan (mythology)) [Atlas](Atlas (mythology)). He additionally reprised his role as the Kingpin in *[The New Animated Series](Spider-Man:)(Spider-Man: The New Animated Series)*.

In addition to his film roles, Duncan guest-starred in numerous television shows. Two included an episode of *[Suite Life of Zack & Cody](The)(The Suite Life of Zack & Cody)* and a first-season episode of *[NY](CSI:)(CSI: NY)*. In 2008, he appeared as Mr. Colt in the second-season premiere of *[Chuck](Chuck (TV series))'', "[Versus the First Date](Chuck)(Chuck Versus the First Date)" and as a guest star on two episodes of *[and a Half Men](Two)(Two and a Half Men)*. Most notably, in April 2011, Duncan guest-starred on an episode of TV series *[Bones](Bones (TV series))* as Leo Knox which, in 2012, led to Duncan's receiving his first starring role as the same character in the spinoff series *[Finder](The)(The Finder (U.S. TV series))*. The *Bones* Season 8 episode "[Partners in the Divorce](The)(Bones (season 8)#ep144)", which aired three weeks after his death, was dedicated to him.

During the week of May 14, 2012, Duncan appeared as a guest on the late night talk show *[Late Late Show with Craig Ferguson](The)(The Late Late Show with Craig Ferguson)* when the show was taping for a week in Scotland. Duncan was one of the show's more frequent guests, appearing a total of 18 times, and, the day after Duncan's death in September, Ferguson began his show with a tribute to him. In January 2013 during *The Late Late Show*s winter break, reruns of the Scotland episodes were broadcast with a tribute to Duncan at the beginning of each of the five episodes, featuring Duncan’s photo on a pink background and the text "In memory of our friend Michael Clarke Duncan."
Michael Clarke Duncan practiced Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu, earning a purple belt.

### 2002–2008: Velvet Revolver

[[File:Velvet Revolver live in London 5 June 2007 03.jpg|thumb|right|180px|Slash and [Weiland](Scott)(Scott Weiland) during a [Revolver](Velvet)(Velvet Revolver) concert in [London](London) in 2007]]

In 2002, Slash reunited with [McKagan](Duff)(Duff McKagan) and [Sorum](Matt)(Matt Sorum) for a [Castillo](Randy)(Randy Castillo) tribute concert. Realizing that they still had the chemistry of their days in Guns N' Roses, they decided to form a new band together. Former Guns N' Roses guitarist [Stradlin](Izzy)(Izzy Stradlin) was initially involved, but left after the others decided to find a lead singer. [Kushner](Dave)(Dave Kushner), who had previously played with McKagan in [Loaded](Loaded (band)), then joined the band on rhythm guitar. For many months, the four searched for a lead singer by listening to offered demo tapes, a monotonous process documented by [VH1](VH1). Eventually, former [Temple Pilots](Stone)(Stone Temple Pilots) vocalist [Weiland](Scott)(Scott Weiland) joined the band.

In 2003, Velvet Revolver played several concerts during the summer and released their first single, "[Me Free](Set)(Set Me Free (Velvet Revolver song))". In June 2004, they released their debut album, *[Contraband](Contraband (Velvet Revolver album))*, which debuted at No.1 on the U.S. chart and sold two million copies, re-establishing Slash as a mainstream performer. A year-and-a-half-long tour followed in support of the album. In 2005, the band was nominated for three Grammy Awards: Rock Album of the Year, Rock Song, and Hard Rock Performance for their *Contraband* single "[Slither](Slither (song))" which won their first and only Grammy. In July 2007, Velvet Revolver released their second album, *[Libertad](Libertad (Velvet Revolver album))*, and embarked on a second tour. During a show in March 2008, Weiland announced to the audience that it would be the band's final tour; he was fired from the band in April 2008 and Slash insisted "chemical issues" led to the split. The following month Weiland rejoined Stone Temple Pilots. Despite Weiland's departure, Velvet Revolver did not officially disband.

In early 2010, Velvet Revolver began writing new songs and auditioning new singers. By January 2011, the band had recorded nine demos, and was reportedly due to make a decision on their singer. However, the following April, Slash stated that they had been unable to find a suitable singer and that Velvet Revolver would remain on hiatus for the next few years while its members focus on other projects.
Slash co-founded Velvet Revolver in 2002 with vocalist Scott Weiland.

# David Foster Wallace

*Revision ID: 1160140515 | Timestamp: 2023-06-14T16:59:03Z*

**David Foster Wallace** (February 21, 1962 – September 12, 2008) was an American novelist, short story writer, essayist, and university professor of English and [writing](creative)(creative writing). Wallace is widely known for his 1996 novel *[Jest](Infinite)(Infinite Jest)*, which *[Time](Time (magazine))* magazine cited as one of the 100 best English-language novels from 1923 to 2005. His posthumous novel, *[Pale King](The)(The Pale King)* (2011), was a finalist for the [Prize for Fiction](Pulitzer)(Pulitzer Prize for Fiction) in 2012.  The *[Angeles Times](Los)(Los Angeles Times)*s David Ulin called Wallace "one of the most influential and innovative writers of the last twenty years".

Wallace grew up in Illinois and attended [College](Amherst)(Amherst College). He taught English at [College](Emerson)(Emerson College), [State University](Illinois)(Illinois State University), and [College](Pomona)(Pomona College). After struggling with [depression](Depression (mood)) for many years, he died by [suicide](suicide) in 2008, at age 46.

### Nonfiction

Wallace covered Senator John McCain's [presidential campaign](2000)(John McCain 2000 presidential campaign) "The Weasel, Twelve Monkeys and The Shrub" was [parodied](parody) in the Salon.com article ["David Foster Wallace: Ain't McCain Grand"](http://www.salon.com/2000/04/04/wallace_6/). and the [11 attacks](September)(September 11 attacks) for *[Stone](Rolling)(Rolling Stone)*; cruise ships (in what became the title essay of his first nonfiction book), [fair](state)(state fair)s, and [tornado](tornado)es for ''[Magazine](Harper's)(Harper's Magazine)*; the [Open](US)(US Open (tennis)) tournament for *[Tennis](Tennis (magazine))* magazine; the director [Lynch](David)(David Lynch) and the [industry](pornography)(Sex industry) for *[Première](Première (magazine))* magazine; the [tennis](tennis) player [Joyce](Michael)(Michael Joyce (tennis)) for *[Esquire](Esquire (magazine))*; the movie-special-effects industry for *[Waterstone's](Waterstones)* magazine; conservative talk radio host [Ziegler](John)(John Ziegler (talk show host)) for *[Atlantic](The)(The Atlantic)*; and a [Maine](Maine) lobster festival for *[Gourmet](Gourmet (magazine))* magazine. He also reviewed books in several genres for the *Los Angeles Times*, *[Washington Post](The)(The Washington Post)*, *[New York Times](The)(The New York Times)*, and *[Philadelphia Inquirer](The)(The Philadelphia Inquirer)*. In the November 2007 issue of *The Atlantic'', which commemorated the magazine's 150th anniversary, Wallace was among the authors, artists, politicians and others who wrote short pieces on "the future of the American idea".

These and other essays appear in three collections, ''[Supposedly Fun Thing I'll Never Do Again](A)(A Supposedly Fun Thing I'll Never Do Again)*, *[the Lobster](Consider)(Consider the Lobster)* and the posthumous *[Flesh and Not](Both)(Both Flesh and Not)'', the last of which contains some of Wallace's earliest work, including his first published essay, "Fictional Futures and the Conspicuously Young".

Some writers have found parts of Wallace's nonfiction implausible. [Franzen](Jonathan)(Jonathan Franzen) has said that he believes Wallace made up dialogue and incidents: "those things didn't actually happen". Of the essays "Shipping Out" and "Welcome to the Fair", John Cook has remarked that in Wallace's nonfiction: Wallace encounters pitch-perfect characters who speak comedically crystalline lines and place him in hilariously absurd situations...I used both stories [teaching journalism](when) as examples of the inescapable temptation to shave, embellish, and invent narratives.
## Work

### Career

*[Broom of the System](The)(The Broom of the System)* (1987) garnered national attention and critical praise. In *The New York Times*, [James](Caryn)(Caryn James) called it a "manic, human, flawed extravaganza … emerging straight from the excessive tradition of [Elkin](Stanley)(Stanley Elkin)'s *The Franchiser*, [Pynchon](Thomas)(Thomas Pynchon)'s *[V.](V.)*, [and] [Irving](John)(John Irving)'s *[According to Garp](World)(The World According to Garp)*".

[[File:Infinite Jest 2.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Autographed opening page of *[Jest](Infinite)(Infinite Jest)*]]

In 1991, Wallace began teaching literature as an adjunct professor at [College](Emerson)(Emerson College) in Boston. The next year, at the suggestion of colleague and supporter [Moore](Steven)(Steven Moore (author)), Wallace obtained a position in the [English](English studies) department at [State University](Illinois)(Illinois State University). He had begun work on his second novel, *[Jest](Infinite)(Infinite Jest)*, in 1991, and submitted a draft to his editor in December 1993. After the publication of excerpts throughout 1995, the book was published in 1996.

In 1997, Wallace received a [Fellowship](MacArthur)(MacArthur Fellows Program). He also received the [Khan Prize for Fiction](Aga)(Aga Khan Prize for Fiction), awarded by editors of *[Paris Review](The)(The Paris Review)* for one of the stories in *[Interviews with Hideous Men](Brief)(Brief Interviews with Hideous Men)*, which had been published in the magazine.

In 2002, Wallace moved to [California](Claremont,)(Claremont, California), to become the first [E. Disney](Roy)(Roy E. Disney) Professor of Creative Writing and Professor of English at [College](Pomona)(Pomona College). He taught one or two undergraduate courses per semester and focused on writing.

Wallace delivered the commencement address to the 2005 graduating class at [College](Kenyon)(Kenyon College). The speech was published as a book, *[Is Water](This)(This Is Water)*, in 2009. In May 2013 parts of the speech were used in a popular online video, also titled "This Is Water".

Bonnie Nadell was Wallace's literary agent during his entire career. Michael Pietsch was his editor on *Infinite Jest*.

Wallace died in 2008. In March 2009, [Brown and Company](Little,)(Little, Brown and Company) announced that it would publish the manuscript of an unfinished novel, *[Pale King](The)(The Pale King)*, that Wallace had been working on before his death. Pietsch pieced the novel together from pages and notes Wallace left behind. [excerpts](Several)(The Pale King#Published excerpts) were published in *[New Yorker](The)(The New Yorker)* and other magazines. *The Pale King* was published on April 15, 2011, and received generally positive reviews. Michiko Kakutani of *The New York Times* wrote that *The Pale King* "showcases [Wallace's] embrace of discontinuity; his fascination with both the meta and the microscopic, postmodern pyrotechnics and old-fashioned storytelling; and his ongoing interest in contemporary America's obsession with self-gratification and entertainment." The book was nominated for the Pulitzer Prize.

Throughout his career, Wallace published short fiction in periodicals such as *The New Yorker*, *[GQ](GQ)*, ''[Magazine](Harper's)(Harper's Magazine)*, *[Playboy](Playboy)*, *The Paris Review*, *[Review](Mid-American)(Mid-American Review)*, *[Conjunctions](Conjunctions (journal))*, *[Esquire](Esquire (magazine))*, *[City](Open)(Open City (magazine))*, *[del Sol](Puerto)(Puerto del Sol)*, and *[McSweeney's Quarterly Concern](Timothy)(Timothy McSweeney's Quarterly Concern)''.
The title of David Foster Wallace's 2005 commencement address at Kenyon College, later published as a book, is *This Is Water*.

### Early career (NASA)

Rober joined [NASA](NASA)'s [Propulsion Laboratory](Jet)(Jet Propulsion Laboratory) (JPL) in 2004. He worked there for nine years, seven of which were spent working on the [rover](Curiosity)(Curiosity (rover)), which is now on [Mars](Mars). He designed and delivered hardware on several JPL missions, including AMT, [GRAIL](Gravity Recovery and Interior Laboratory), [SMAP](Soil Moisture Active Passive), and [Science Laboratory](Mars)(Mars Science Laboratory). While at NASA, Rober was one of the primary architects for "JPL Wired", which was a comprehensive knowledge capture [wiki](wiki). He published a case study about applying wiki technology in a high-tech organization to develop an "Intrapedia" for the capture of corporate knowledge.
Mark Rober worked on the NASA Curiosity rover for seven years.

### Formation and early years

Accenture began as the business and technology consulting division of accounting firm [Andersen](Arthur)(Arthur Andersen) in the early 1950s when it conducted a feasibility study for [Electric](General)(General Electric) to install a computer at [Park](Appliance)(Appliance Park) in [Kentucky](Louisville,)(Louisville, Kentucky), which led to GE's installation of a [I](UNIVAC)(UNIVAC I) computer and printer, believed to be the first commercial use of a computer in the U.S. [Glickauf](Joseph)(Joseph Glickauf), an early pioneer of computer consulting, held a position as head of Arthur Andersen's administrative services division.
Accenture originated as the business and technology consulting division of the accounting firm Arthur Andersen.
